[h1] What was that ending!!!!!???? [/h1]

That was my first amazed thought when finishing this game [spoiler] not talking about "Endgame", but about the credits' ending [/spoiler]. I entered this game without any idea of what would it be, but it progressively surpassed every initial expectation.
This game sure isn't for everyone, as it could make you lose patience more than a few times (I actually had to get away from the screen sometimes because of frustration). That said, I believe it's one of the greatest puzzle games ever made. Everything, from ambiance to sound and light contributes to it, and it's meticulously curated to be beautiful and philosophical. More than a game, it's "artwork" at its finest.

Most reviewers suffer about its ending, but I choose to think it's part of its mystery. If you really grasp what the "Challenge" tells you, you'll understand it's not ment to be closed, let alone be solved. Please, don't play this game expecting it to REWARD YOU, because you'll be disappointed. But, then again, you have to sit patiently to hear what the "Challenge" is about, and considering the fact that only 5% of the players got it at the time of writing this, and the fact that you HAVE to understand the logic behind the puzzles to get it, I'm not expecting everyone to figure it out.

[spoiler] Bach died before finishing "Die Kunst der Fuge", the most extense and complex fugue of his lifetime: hearing this made it all make sense to me. [/spoiler]
Standing ovation for everyone involved in this game.
Love it or hate it, it's one of a kind. There will never be another like it. Maybe....

The main theme of "The Witness" is the brief moments of "enlightenment" that come when you find a solution to an seemingly unsolvable problem. The game develops this theme to the point of absurdity. From the simplest puzzles on the screen to the geography of the entire game world, every part of "The Witness" serves this purpose. The game drives you through an obsession with the search for "meaning," treating meaning as the ultimate problem, and it does this well. Even the pause menu is black like closed eyes, with outlines of puzzle shapes, emphasizing the omnipresence and obsession with solving riddles, as if the player thinks only about this and sees nothing else.

But that is also a problem with "The Witness". The sheer number of variations on the same puzzle becomes overwhelming and tedious, and the moments of enlightenment are no longer enough to keep up with the quantity of puzzles. You begin to wish for concrete answers regarding what is happening on the island, and at some point, you just want the game to end. Everything the game offers you up to that point—through audiobooks, petrified people in ordinary and extraordinary situations, and films—is not sufficient; it might even be discouraging, as these pieces of information are half-puzzles themselves, leaving you without any real motivation to engage with them seriously.

There is no concrete resolution. I won’t spoil the ending, but after struggling through the last puzzles, you receive no answer.  Maybe I missed some crucial information in the remaining films or audiobooks, but as I said, I didn't have the will to seek them out, and now I even doubt they would reveal anything new to me. 

Don’t get me wrong; "The Witness" is a phenomenal study of puzzles and should be played as such. I’m giving it a negative rating solely because the ending disappointed me so much that my main impression after the whole game is that I wasted too much time, which isn’t good.

The game with the best puzzles, even if it's not the best game with puzzles.

It's truly incredible to see how much can be squeezed out of a grid and a path. The game does a great job of organically introducing you to new concepts, and confounding you when you're not ready for more advanced ones. The way that so many puzzles break out and interact with the game world is amazing. Yes, some types are better than others, but the game still allows you to get the "main" ending if you skip a few sections.

That said, a lot of the criticism about the rest of the game is fair. Traversal is often unnecessarily slow. The "story" is insubstantial and/or pretentious. And the less said about the ending the better. But if you love challenging yourself with cleverly iterative puzzles, you can approach the game with that lens and not let the rest of it bother you.

You should only take what you want from this game. You don't have to solve EVERYTHING (which seems tedious even to a completionist like me). There is no achievement for it, or even a real progress tracker. In fact the harder stuff can be so obtuse that it seems designed for collaboration.

Just carve out your own path through this world. Enjoy it, and be okay knowing that it's bigger than any one person.

The Witness is a masterpiece that transcended my expectations and fundamentally changed the way I perceive not only games but the world around me. At its core, this is more than just a puzzle game—it’s an experience that invites you to question how you see and understand reality. From the moment I set foot on its mysterious island, I knew I was in for something profound, but I never anticipated how deeply it would rewire my thought processes.

As you progress, The Witness steadily expands your mind. Each puzzle is a test of perception, and the beauty of the game lies in its quiet, yet full of beautiful sound design and ambience, elegant genius. The further you go, the more you realize that the only thing limiting your understanding is your own perspective. The game doesn’t hand anything to you; it gives you the tools to succeed in a non-verbal way, but you have to be willing to look closer, to notice the subtle, intricate patterns hidden in plain sight.

The feeling of solving each puzzle is euphoric, but it’s more than that—it’s a revelation. You begin to understand that you aren’t just solving puzzles; you’re learning to observe, to pay attention to details that seemed irrelevant before. The more open you are to seeing beyond the surface, the more the world of The Witness reveals itself to you. And it’s not just about the puzzles themselves—it’s about how the game makes you realize that in life, too, we often only see what we’re willing to see.

Every area of the island is coherently themed around a specific idea. Each zone feels distinct, with its own set of rules, visual cues, and atmosphere, subtly guiding you to grasp the concept it’s trying to teach. Each area "is about something". The architecture, the unique artistic visuals and colors, and even the extremely well crafted sound design work together to gently nudge you towards understanding without ever spelling it out.

These areas aren’t just backdrops—they’re designed to suggest their secrets. As you explore, the way each space is crafted practically whispers clues to you, encouraging you to observe, experiment, and learn. The game operates on the principle that true understanding requires effort and introspection. If you rush through, you’ll miss the subtleties and nuances that make the experience so rich.

It’s this meticulous attention to detail that makes every part of the island feel alive and meaningful, pulling you into the game’s world and making each revelation feel earned.

And it never feels repetitive. Every puzzle introduces a fresh, new idea, challenging you in unique ways, and the game constantly forces you to think like a scientist. You’re not just guessing—you’re experimenting, forming hypotheses, testing them, and learning from each failure. Just when you think you’ve figured things out, it introduces a twist, or a partial carefully placed obfuscation, forcing you to adapt your thinking and test your hypothesis.

Puzzles don’t exist in isolation. Everything is connected to everything else. They build on one another, coming together in spectacular and often unimaginable ways. The process is methodical yet incredibly creative, as you're driven to break down problems, refine your approach, and discover the deeper logic behind each challenge. It’s like performing scientific experiments on your own perception. The further you go, the more you realize how the game’s mechanics compose a brilliant system that rewards careful observation and persistent curiosity. Each solution opens up new layers of understanding in ways that are mind-blowing.

In essence, The Witness teaches that meaningful insight is born from patience and curiosity, making every moment spent in its world incredibly valuable.

The Witness is a really unique game, but not something I would recommend to most people I know.

The game resembles old open-world puzzle games like Myst, where you learn rules to a puzzle in one place and apply them somewhere else in the world. In The Witness this is meant literally - The only progress you make is in your own understanding of the world and the puzzles. Theoretically, you could immediately solve every puzzle, but you probably lack the understanding to do so while at the beginning of the game and may need to return to some of them later, when you understand what e.g. blue and orange dots on the lines mean or what you are supposed to do when a red star is on the board. 

So for this whole game, you explore the island the game is set on, and slowly make small discoveries about the world around you. The areas are incredibly varied in how they look, how they play, how you progress, what kind of puzzles they include, and no matter where you go, it will help you in getting closer to completing the game. Sometimes, a solution to a puzzle is a bit tedious or just a bit confusing to figure out, but I was rarely really stuck in the game, and I never felt like the puzzles were too easy or unfairly hard.

However I think the pricing is a bit... much. It's very well-polished for an Indie game and a really nice experience, and the game is really wonderful to look at, but asking for 37€ for a game that is 8 years old and that you'll get 9-15 hours of gameplay out of is kind of a lot. I bought it on sale, where I think the price was more appropriate. 

The other thing is, that I think this is a game that is almost more interesting to play for game developers than it is for actual players. It's a wonderful game to analyse in terms of how it handles tutorials, progression, exploration, level design, and I was really fascinated by all of these aspects and could already write whole papers on it, but I'm not sure if I would have enjoyed the game on the same level if I wouldn't have been thinking about how clever the design of these aspects was all the time. But maybe I'm also just not really the target audience for a game like this.

So generally, I had a very fun time with the game, I don't think I would personally recommend it for the asking price, and you might need to be really into games like Myst or be a game designer to really get a nice experience out of The Witness.

Jesus H, this game.

BEFORE YOU BUY: If you are shade/color blind and/or deaf/don't have speakers, get a guide. Actually, it doesn't matter. Get a guide.

If the Talos Principle is the gateway drug to the hard stuff, this is the hard stuff. It's Myst's hardcore sibling from another marriage.

Aesthetically this game is amazing, and everything I want from a game like this. The open world alone is worth sinking time into this.

Philosophically? Long-winded. If the puzzles don't give you a headache, the philosophy behind this game will.

As for the puzzles, they are frustrating. They teach you the rules, and then throw those rules in your face, screaming "THOUGHT YOU WERE CLEVER WERE YOU??". Even with using a guide, I said to myself multiple times "Okay, that makes sense, but I would have NEVER figured that out on my own." If you completed this game without a guide, consider yourself a MENSA-certified NERD.

The ending is a slap to the face. Literally like "Lol, you did all this work? You cute little MENSA-Nerd." If you have the time/energy/sanity, go for the secret ending, because in that, guides MIGHT NOT HELP.

So yeah, buy it for the aestethics, but for the love of god, don't pretend like you're going to get enlightened and solve this like the Talos Principle. The game discourages that kind of optimism. Get a guide.

Very relaxing and unique puzzle game. The beautiful environment and serene soundscape create a hypnotic atmosphere for exploring and solving puzzles. The puzzles themselves are well designed and offer a great challenge. The design decision to make it where you have to explore the island to understand all of the puzzle mechanics makes for a very satisfying gameplay loop. You will finally find a tutorial for a mechanic and then remember all the places you previously saw that mechanic, excited to go finally solve those puzzles. The game's "story" is somewhat lacking, requiring an immense effort on the player to make it pretty far into the game and also decipher it from its clues just for a pretty underwhelming reveal. However, the story really doesn't matter all too much in this case. The main appeal, at least for me, was the puzzles and solving all their mechanics, and that part was satisfying enough that the lack of a satisfying story didn't bother me all that much.

No other game has made me feel as underwhelmed as The Witness.

Let's start with the puzzles. I loved them a lot and I wouldn't change a thing. The game does a great job teaching you its mechanics, not by explaining them to you, but by letting you experiment on less complex puzzles to rule out what works and what doesn't. It's excellent game design. My only complaint is a timed segment which is more dependent on luck than skill in my experience.

Graphics. You see the trailer. It's 50 hours of that hyper-saturated goodness in an environment so carefully crafted that no strand of grass is in the wrong place. Just make sure to turn on the crosshair, turn up the FOV and turn off V-Sync so you don't get motion sick.

Philosophy. A lot of people praise this game's existentialism, but it didn't really do it for me. The game takes an aggressively neutral stance which works to its detriment. It's like having a textbook read at you and they don't offer much if you have at least a basic knowledge of philosophy. The only thing that made me think was when they finally stopped quoting people and made a point about how atheism can only exist in contradiction to theism and has trouble standing on its own. I didn't agree with them, but it did make me think. Sadly, that was in an area that few players will ever access.

The mystery. It sucks. I can't adequately articulate how much it sucks. It is so underwhelming that every theory you have while playing the game will be better than what the "conclusion" is, if you can even call it that. To give you an idea, every once in a while I asked for guidance online so I knew I was heading in the right direction. On my last post I asked for hints once again and laid out my current theories and open leads, only to find out that my game had already come to its end. I had discovered everything. For context I have seen both endings of this game and both times my basic intuition as a writer and game designer was "Oh, that's just a fakeout ending" and both times the endings were REAL.

Now, I have to be honest with you. This game has a trick up its sleeve. Your experience with the game will heavily depend on when you discover this trick. If you find it late, you will be gifted a second game to play. If you find it early, you will spend the rest of your playthrough wondering if that was it or if there's something else. It's an odd choice from a game design perspective as people who enjoy puzzle games are more likely to think outside the box, but if you think outside the box too early you won't get the extra special experience that is meant to be a part of this game. Who was this made for?

In conclusion, I can't recommend The Witness in good faith. While the puzzles are good, the promise of a mystery and a subversive experience is never truly delivered on, and it's all wrapped up in a bow of contextless quotes and videos you can watch for free elsewhere. Go read Tao Te King instead.

I will try to be as spoiler free as possible in this review, however obviously I cannot be spoiler completely spoiler free.
After having heared a lot of good about this game I decided to try this. And I hope that if your ead it that you don't.

My issues:

1. The price: I am sorry. While I didn't 100% it, I finished the game in 13 hours. That means I finished all areas and anything else that I found, and while I did look out for secrets, I didn't go searc every corner over and over again and there is definitely some stuff I missed. I bought this game on sale for 10€ and don't really feel like I got my moneys worth, it does not have the same playtime or enjoyment as any game I have seen that cost 40€. Unless the stuff I missed can quadrouple my playtime while constantly being enjoyable.

2. Accessibility: This game is not accessibile for a lot of people. Are you colourblind or have some other visual impairment? Don't play it. Do you have any hearing impairments or something similar? Don't play it. In addition to having no accessibility settings, in an usual playthrough, most of these puzzles will only show up AFTER the 2 hour mark has long been crossed, meaning if a disabled person bought this game without knowing about these issues would not be able to refund it. There are subtitles but they don't help with the sound puzzles. Only with the videos.

3. The videos: There are secret puzzles that hide videos. Just videos, that are usually only a person talking into a camera about something related to the message of the game. Just a real person talking or walking. Nothing exciting or puzzling. Just boring. I managed to find all but one and they easily are combined longer than 1 hour. You might say "don't watch them", but a) they are a part of the game and I tried to experience as much as possible b) they are rewards for puzzles and the first few times I legit hoped something directly relevant to the game would happen and c) its just frustating that your reward for exploring is... this.

4. The slowness. This game is slow. A lot of my playtime was just spend with walking from area to area, from puzzle to puzzle. Eventually you unlock a fast travel method but a lot of time it feels like walking would just have been faster, as the fast travel is slow. I don't care if this is the vision or something, I don't mind games being slow at times but after 13 hours it gets annoying.

5. The puzzles. While the huge majority of puzzles are enjoyable and enganing, sometimes they were frustating. And honestly, I did look up a few puzzles. And while sometimes I thought "how the hell was I supposed to figure this out???" There was one area, where idk if its an impairment I have or if I am just a weirdo but I had to look up EVERY SINGLE PUZZLE. I  understood the patern, I honestly felt physically unable to figure out the solution by myself [spoiler](it was the jungle area btw)[/spoiler].

5. 1. In addition to that there is no clear approach to puzzles. For some you have to figure it out directly. For some you have to try for a long time. For some you have to solve other puzzles beforehand. Not just to understand the mechanics, but to be able to solve the puzzle sometimes you need to solve another one before (you can still try tho).

6. The about this game section is just untrue. There is no such story about you regaining your memories. And the game does not respect your time.

While I can't say I didn't enjoy this game, I cannot in good faith recommend this game.

Everyone says that this is such a genius puzzle game, the use of the environment, the logic, the scenery, and so many great things… I just didn’t like it. The game is based on several types of puzzles and most of them are really not fun (like the reflection ones, the sound ones, or the ones in the greenhouse). And for those that can be fun, they eventually become so convoluted that they are more annoying than fun, really.

Okay, so instead of complaining I will try to explain why this personally didn’t land. Everything is about panels that need a certain path to get solved, and sometimes when you think you understand a mechanic, the game just tricks you. A fundamental part of the learning process is understanding the bases to keep moving forward, but if you didn’t quite understand the basics, or if you forgot about them, The Witness will NOT remind you of them.

It’s good that games teach you mechanics indirectly and that players can learn by themselves, but I’m just saying that if those mechanics can be really confusing, the game should at least provide some guidance. It would have been so nice if after each area you could have kept track of the things you did and its variations, but no.

I'm really sad to give this game a negative review as I hoped to enjoy it a lot. Overall very beautiful but also very tiring and rather pointless game. There is a nice intoduction to solving puzzles, unfortunately it could be confusing at times. There was at least one type of puzzle where I solved a few easier ones, then got stucked only to find out that I misunderstood the concept of puzzle. I also found two genuine bugs in more complicated puzzles - I got it right (checked everything a few times) but it didn's pass as solved - apparently there was only one solution programmed while more possibilities were available. In a few locations puzzels didn't really get more difficoult or complex, only more annoying by distorting or obscuring screen. Also, some types of puzzle were solved by walking around to find one, correct spot to look from, which got tidius quickly. As for the environmental puzzles... where do I even begin... Way, way to many for me, although I appreciate the idea.

Exploration was fine but I was expecting a little bit more. Beautifull locations that suggest some kind of story behind them but never really tell or even hint the story - that was probably most disappointing to me. This game had great ideas but many of them felt underdeveloped or overly complex with no payoff. When I finished the game I was relieved that it's finally over. Maybe that game just wasn't for me.

The Witness is a puzzle game, in the purest form of the genre. Everything is a puzzle. Mazes are everywhere, to the point of leading the player to obsession... a consequence that I still believe to be the [i]true[/i] point of this game.

This game is all about puzzles, finding patterns and meanings, understanding without being told the rules... and obsession. An obsession that stems from the very concept of the game, fed by hours of peaceful thinking and untangling the rules of the puzzles. You already know it as this weird obsession every gamer has felt at least once in their life. This gripping obsession that leads the player to see the game outside of the game, be it in dreams or when awake. That very obsession that superimposes a videogame masterpiece to one's everyday life while the game is not completed.

At first, there are mazes to solve everywhere inside of the game. Until you discover that actually, there are also mazes everywhere outside of the game.

No introduction or instructions to play, self-discovery is at the core of the game.
Series of mazes with increasing difficulty, geographically arranged by categories. They look repetitive at first but you must make your strategies evolve. Some of them are seriously hard to solve because of the difficult access to must-have indications (for example, patterns in shady trees).
Some puzzles won't be pleasant to people affected by color blindness. Also, some require the understanding of primary colors (it could be deduced by playing with available filters).
Be prepared to help yourself with colored pencils and sheets of (5x5 mm) graphing paper for the toughest mazes.
A large, nicely colored, and impressive 3D environment, you can move on earth, under the earth, on the sea... but never fall :) you cannot die, you never need to save (automatic), thus drawback: no multiplayer course on a same computer.
Boss levels inside the mountain! :)
Additional challenge: find as many maze-like paths as possible in the scenery!

This game needs a flash warning. There are puzzles in the end-game area whose mechanics are based on bright, quickly flashing colors. Even for me, who doesn't have epilepsy or (usually) motion sickness issues, the puzzles in this area were headache inducing, and the spinning panels actually made me nauseous. These aren't skippable puzzles, either; they're in the final area of the main game, directly on the path to the ending. And there are puzzles in other areas that, while not as egregious, could be similarly problematic. It would cost nothing to at least display a text warning when booting up the game. I would otherwise recommend [i]The Witness[/i], but this is just too big of an issue for me.

The Witness is a great puzzle game set on a beautiful yet haunting island. The core gameplay consists of solving the line maze puzzles that you see in screenshots of the game, and that's it. The whole thing is line puzzles. It might not be for everyone, but these puzzles are really well made and placed throughout areas very thoughtfully. There are tons of different mechanics present to explore and master within these simple little puzzles and I personally never found them to get stale over the course of my playthrough. 
     It's important to note that the reward for solving most of the optional puzzles is simply the gratification of completing it. Beating the main game gives an achievement and an ending, and theres a little extra thing that players can do to get a second achievement, but that's about it. About half of the game is mandatory, and the rest is optional puzzles that give essentially no reward. It's a little odd, but it allows everyone to play until they've decided that they're done, and I think it was a good idea. This also means that there is very, very little story. There are environmental hints at some sort of a plot, but the actual concrete details are very few and hard to find. Overall, this is a good game for those who want a good, challenging puzzle experience.

Spoilers ahead

Pros: 
Fantastic visuals, minimalist art style but enough detail to immerse you. 
Diverse set of puzzles that build on unique mechanics that are fair most of the time and some leaving you kicking yourself once you get it. 
The puzzles overall really make you think and the game even pushes you to accept that you might not know how to do something, and in turn rewards you for exploring. All the main puzzles have a way of easing you into them, even if the gimmick isn't clear right away. Post game content that gives you more to do after beating the main puzzles is a nice touch. 

Cons:
Most puzzles are fine, but there are a few that just feel like a cheap gimmick and arent really ones that test your thinking. Also some mechanics that are very ambiguous and leave multiple valid interpretations based on how vaguely previous game mechanics were introduced. The whole mysteriousness of the game is part of the vibe, but limits a few puzzles from feeling fair to the player, especially the one at the bottom of the mountain. Its the only puzzle of its kind and there is no setup that helps you understand the unique mechanic to it. 

Story, I get some people might say its a deep philosophic wonder, but its really just some distantly relevant quotes to overcoming challenges or observing the world around you. The game had so many cool and unique locations and dropped several hints at lore, but then in a post game voice line they jokingly throw it out the window. They were so close to having something great and just didnt finish this aspect of the game 

Recap: 
Fantastic puzzle game with majority of puzzles being fair yet complex enough to make you think differently. Story is basically nonexistent, although there is some opportunity for lore if they make a sequel, and some of the recordings had some good outlooks that the player could use to approach the game or just life in general. Despite the nit picking I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzle games or likes a challenge. Its not an easy game but if you commit to not solving everything on the first go you will have a ton of fun no matter your experience with puzzle games. If its on sale 100% pick this up.

While Johnathan Blow is known for being pretentious, The Witness's calm environment free of hand holding allows you to explore the world in your own style and at your own pace, especially if that pace involves pausing to think every once in a while. I'd recommend The Witness for a slightly discounted price of $25 to $30.
Well well well...

I'm constantly going back and forth on this and I think I have to leave it as this. There are a lot of incredible things about the Witness, the art style is great, the puzzles take what you might think of as a pretty simple puzzle and continue expanding on it in such a way that it remains addictive. Typically the amount of "thinking outside the box" you have to do for these puzzles is long in an incredible way where even after you see and understand the mechanics it still takes you a while to figure out. There's so many cool secrets in the game that you could be exploring it for what may feel endlessly. 

The problem is that this is not always the case in the Witness. Being an open world puzzle game is an interesting concept and in some ways it's great but at the same time... It's not great when you're spending sometimes hours trying to find the where you can learn about this new mechanics to enter a new area that may or not not even use the mechanic you just used to enter. Obviously many would argue that the open-worldness aspect of the game is necessary because that difference in perspective is crucial for solving many of the puzzles, secrets puzzles and "base game" puzzles alike. But to be honest that doesn't really justify the issue imo. Many of the environmental puzzles are frankly infuriating because even when you know the mechanic, you have to spend all you're time looking for the "correct" solution instead of wracking in your brain how the line might work. Some great examples of this is the monastery where its incredibly simple, but because of what I mentioned earlier I spent way what time on this than I would have liked because I "wasn't seeing this the right way." It's incredibly alloying because in addition I could sometimes find another route where the line worked and I was following the rule, but again it wasn't the "correct" solution, but I feel that it should either be designed such that I wouldn't be able to find such a solution or it just doesn't exist at all. 

Another example of an not ideal environmental puzzle is the jungle. Maybe I'm just tone deaf, or maybe I don't appreciate sound messing with me in such a way where it doesn't feel like there's any rhyme or reason to it. Again, when I am solving a puzzle I want to consciously be wracking my brain trying to think of and testing the different possibilities until I find the correct one that works, not simply trying to have "better intuition" or something like that. 

One of the worst things about peoples response or defense of this is that "oh well you just didn't get it" or sometimes they'll go with the more informal "skill issue." But that is quite literally a terrible defense because its a infallible one. It's like if you say you don't like spinach and you're friend reply's "oh well you just haven't had the right spinach." Like that's such an annoying answer because sure, at the end of the day, that person is probably right because there's a great many different ways to cook different foods and different combinations or different breeds or whatever, but you wouldn't be able to try all of them and thus won't be able to disprove it. If you have reached your opinion based on a decent numbers of encounters in different contexts, than it fine to say that it's just not for you. Even if the Witness is a great game with fascinating mechanics and a deep message behind it, it is the responsibility of the creator to make that the case for the players and not act like its the players fault if they don't enjoy it.

But like I said earlier, the Witness has many things great about it. Most of the within grid puzzles are a blast and some of the environmental puzzles are straightforward that you still have the joy of being able to think about it without having to struggle with whether or not you're looking at it right. Two great examples of this are the orchard and the keep, where it becomes very clear how it works and you can enjoy the environment without having to look at every nook and cranny. 

Overall, there are a lot of great things about the Witness and many things I didn't cover (Lets just ignore the audio files since this is a puzzle game at the end of the day). But it ended up being negative for me because I feel like what I perceived as poorly designed puzzles ended up severely subtracting from the game as a whole, and having to explore with no explicit direction was sometimes fun but could also be infuriating. Sometimes less is more after all. At the end of the day, the Witness doesn't really have an explicit requirement to it so you can just play it at your own pace and have fun with it. But I wouldn't recommend it if you're a bit more of a completionist like myself at times because it can make you severely question if its worth the effort in trying to complete it such that you might just brute force it or even worse look up the solution if it feels inane. It's not the kind of puzzle game that I like but I do still enjoy many of the types of puzzles the game had to offer, regardless of if you want to buy it though I don't think It's worth 40$. I would heavily recommend waiting till its on sale like at the time of this review if you want to play it.
A masterpiece.

Honestly, this game just wasn't for me. I know plenty of gamers whose opinion I respect have really loved this game, and at first I liked it too--mysterious abandoned island, beautiful graphics, and plenty of puzzles, what's not to like? However, after the first 300 puzzles or so (not an exaggeration by the way, there is a reported 650+ total puzzles in the game) the bloom was definitely off the rose. I don't play puzzle games just for the intrinsic enjoyment of doing puzzles; I need story, mystery, the human element. And those things simply never materialized in The Witness. I liked the idea of gradually learning how to solve completely non-verbal puzzles. And I can appreciate the theme that slowly (agonizingly slowly) emerges as the player progresses: that true spiritual growth can be encouraged by pondering unanswerable questions. Cool coo coo coo cool. Just not something I am personally interested in spending my leisure time on! 

Updated to add: I was looking around to see if there was a more complete explanation for the point of this game, just because I was interested in what other people thought. The Google AI summary was quite interesting: it said that the player character was actually an android and the purpose of the island was to teach it logic and to be more human-like! I had not seen this idea anywhere else, nor did that make sense to me based on the other playthroughs I watched. And for an AI to suggest this storyline...just seemed interesting to me. Has anyone else run across this explanation??

I really wanted to like this game, but it just doesn't function well as a video game. It's not enough to just have cool, innovative ideas in the puzzle designs, many of which are genuinely incredibly fun to solve; you have to put them together without over-indulging in meaningless repetition. It also doesn't help that much of the communication of these ideas is too abstract and not intuitive. I really enjoyed some of the areas, but it just became too much busywork by the end, without any ultimately meaningful payoff (at least for me). I suppose the real Witness was the friends/puzzles we made along the way?

The Witness has some high highs and low lows, but overall it's a very unique experience worth a shot if it seems at all interesting to you. (It's also the second game to make me start seeing line puzzles where there are none in real life, shoutouts to TUNIC.) It's very pretty (despite some noticeable pop-in) with minimal but immersive sound design that helps the environment feel more immersive, and it helps the puzzles feel more integrated with the world you're in.

The puzzles are great. I love them. They often do a lot with a little, able to convey complex problems in few enough moving parts that you can usually keep track of them. It's also very cool discovering new concepts and realizing "Oh, I can apply it to this other thing I saw earlier." In its best moments, The Witness makes each locked door a mystery waiting to be solved. Some of the mechanics are immensely creative and feel new and exciting years after the game first came out, though there are also some areas or concepts that I'm more iffy on. Significant mechanical spoilers: [spoiler]I loved the hedge maze and color puzzles, reverse-engineering the colors in the elevator is one of the coolest if most time-consuming puzzles in the game for me. The sound ones are a bit too vibe-based, which is very frustrating, especially when the gap between the sound replaying is on the longer side. Also, the light reflection ones felt a bit too much like guesswork, and were less engaging than the similar environmental obstruction or shadow-based puzzles.[/spoiler]

There are a fair amount of minor annoyances. Semi-frequently, you need to wait a while for an animation to finish to progress, and they are almost always incredibly slow. Some of them do have a reason to be slow, but it's still frustrating to wait 30 seconds for bridges to form/move/rotate/etc, for a door or gate to open, for an elevator to rise or fall, and so on, especially when it's the 10th time you've had to do so. Still, this didn't break the pace badly enough to sour the experience too much, at least for me.

[b]Finally, It's worth noting that there are some accessibility concerns that crop up a decent length into your playthrough.[/b] Minor mechanical spoilers: [spoiler]There are large stretches of gameplay focused on color and pitch with no colorblindness or deafness/tone-deafness accessibility options. The pitch-focused ones sometimes include background noise or sounds that are very quick with long pauses, so if you are hard of hearing or have trouble parsing important sounds from background noise, you may struggle. Also, near the end, there are puzzles with rapid motion, repetitive flashing lights, and steadily changing colors. Finally, not as major as the other ones, but if you have trouble visualizing things and/or have an iffy working memory like I do, you'll absolutely want a second monitor or pencil and paper.[/spoiler] I get why it would be difficult if not impossible to remedy this without significantly changing the gameplay, but it still leaves a bad taste in my mouth since there's no warning for mechanics that can require some players to look up a guide to keep playing, or worst-case-scenario can render the game inaccessible to people who are already many hours into the game.

The Witness is a game I'll be thinking about for a while. It isn't very often that a puzzle game (or any game) captures me like it did, and the ones that do (Outer Wilds and TUNIC come to mind) I hold in very high regard.

The open world hints at a story that just isn't there. This makes the unusual inclusion of audio/video logs all the more conspicuous. The media selected is quite good, but it seems in absence of The Witness really having anything to say itself. Some are favorites of mine, like The Secret of Psalm 46 from Brian Moriarty, the creator of one of my favorite games Loom (although having players [spoiler]sit and watch someone elses video/audio for an entire hour[/spoiler] should be a game design crime). To me including a clip from a Tarkovsky movie came across more like an effort to artificially elevate The Witness, than something that lends to a subtle cohesive narrative or theme. That is to say it feels shoehorned in. The fun aspects to some of the gameplay were also never good enough to counterbalance this feeling while playing. Additionally, [spoiler]the obvious grand "A Ha" moment that I am sure many got when they realized puzzles were hidden all around the environment, was completely lost on me because at the beginning of the game I happened to notice what looked like a line puzzle made out of a river and figured that would be something that happens later. I wasn't looking for something like that to spoil that moment for me, but it just happened unfortunately, and did have an effect on my enjoyment of the game[/spoiler].

An astonishingly elaborate packaging of what is essentially just a series of line drawing puzzles. The puzzles themselves are challenging and have a diverse set of mechanics. They are set (mostly) on panels in a beautifully rendered, colorful and serene environment. Without the open-world packaging this would be a puzzle game not worth mentioning. However, the player is free to walk around and explore as she sees fit. While this gives a feeling of exploration and adds to the bewilderment that you do not receive any introduction, this is also the games great shortcoming: it lacks a meaningful sense of direction for the player. Puzzles can be intimidating if you happen on the more sophisticated first and did not find the ones which introduce a particular mechanic before them. I love puzzle games. Portal 1 and 2 and many of their mods. Talos Principle, etc.
I gave this one three hours and then uninstalled it.

I initially thought it would be subversive in some way, but it really just creates it's own genre out of the most boring parts of every game it draws from. Somehow the objectively worst game I have ever played.

Seriously- if you want philosophical quotes from famous people, play getting over it. If you want subversive puzzles, play Baba is You. If you want to explore a beautiful world, go outside. If you want to learn useless information, go to school. All of these offer more purposeful experiences than The Witness, which has you walking around a hodgepodge world, pulling out your puzzle device to open up doors and connect wires; though, you really aren't connecting the wires or opening the doors, you are just doing puzzles.

The puzzles follow a formula of "impossible to understand until you find the tutorial." after said tutorial, the puzzles become solvable. You then go to the next area and repeat. You are also not guaranteed to find the tutorial before you encounter the related puzzle. I guess this makes it a metroidvania, but only the backtracking parts.

At times, I felt that I wasn't really moving or interacting with a world. You can not jump, you cannot climb. This game almost feels like a two-dimensional drawing with significant parallax, since the most you can do is change your position- often through a significant amount of puzzles.

There is also really no threat that I encountered within my playtime, just walking.

The world is also supplemented by esoteric philosophical tapes littering the ground. These tapes don't add all that much to the story, and make you question why exactly you are walking around in this world when the knowledge contained within is more tied to the world outside of the game.

TLDR: I didn't enjoy this game. Maybe I would have if I had not yet experienced similar twists, turns, formulas, and puzzles in other games. It really seems mundane to walk through a world that seems to want nothing more than to lob philosophy at you.

[h1]The Witness keeps you away from grass[/h1]

I spoiled The Witness. I blame myself for watching someone else play it instead of experiencing it first hand, and while it was an interesting journey along with one youtuber, I certainly have failed my own enjoyment of discovery in this game. What can I say? I didn't even know what the game was. The Witness holds a lot of surprises. It is the game best played completely blind. Here I present my thoughts, but remember that my opinion might be shaped by someone else years ago. My criticism isn't "pure" and "proper".

When it comes to puzzles (the main attraction) the game falls flat in some areas. While most of the problems cleverly designed to involve player's surroundings, there are just so much of them that later puzzles reliant on it become trivial. At other times - rarely - I brute-forced some pannels because although some of them involved using environment, I still couldn't understand what the game wanted from me. Even after watching guides.
The final area has interesting ideas such as projecting a trail from a line you would have to draw on a pannel yourself, or integrating one puzzle as a part of the other. But it is the same place where instead of presenting even more unique tasks, the challenge is to just see the puzzle itself. It spins, it blinks, it changes colors... They are not hard to solve, just hard to comprehend because of visual effects.
Some concepts are overused in the game and become easy while others are so obscure you have to think even more out of the box to get to the solution. Tasks rarely fall inbetween. Probably The Witness wanted to make player go further an beyond thoughts they acclimate to over the course of playing, but I believe it would only work if the game had more of such demanding examples. Some panels could be taking you hours at a time to solve. It's a real pleasure if you do it them yourself, of course.

[spoiler]The ending is truly unsatisfying. But unlike some people, I think it is a good thing for The Witness. It is a game about perspective in more than one way: it is about people trying to make sense of the world around them. If you listened to enough voice-journals, you know it.
The Witness comments on it with environmental puzzles too. Walk around a flowerfield and at some point you might see the same symbol you draw on puzzle pannels. See a stain at the top of the chimney? If you walk far enough and find some pole, it might turn into another symbol. And the game is full of stuff like that. Just as the world around us. Or, we think it is. People try to solve the world around them - find the sourse of some phenomenon, give it meaning and etc. We are very good at connections and see them everywhere. And many think that it is because we see them, it is there. And for some reason too.
Now, imagine we got all the answers right. "*This* is how the Universe works, *this* is why it's happening and *this* is what it's for". Do you expect a cookie for that? When the game ends so ubruptly, erasing everything that you have done, not giving you any reward, isn't it the point of our efforts to study anything? As I see it, the game encourages you to look outside at your own life and find different perspectives on questiones you're bothered with.

And this is where The Witness contradicts itself in a way. If you striving for 100% completion, good luck. Literally, good luck. Some of the challenges The Witness presents in terms of these environmental puzzles (where you have to find this symbol in nature around you) are buried behind layers of 3D environment. There's just so many of them, that you might spend weeks trying to seach every inch of an island. It's rich with details. Too rich. And as much it is good for two separate people have two separate experiences with the game, it also means that the game never wants to be solved and plays against the player at times. Do you know that there is one puzzle that requires you to wait almost an hour to complete it because its beginning connects to the end with an object that moves along the screen veeeeeryyyy sloooowlyyyy? AND - get this - it's one of the films you might find in a game (You also don't know how long the film will take you to watch beforehand). So, if you find it, you probably will watch it first and MAYBE notice that there's a part of a puzzle. Then you will start searching for places where this part might fit and then you will have to watch this film AGAIN to finish the puzzle. This is terrible. [/spoiler]

For a game that inspires curiosity, The Witness' secrets are so unbelievably time consuming, that it undermines the whole message of the game. At the same time its implementation makes perfect sense. Just hearing what different people have to say on topics of religion, culture, art and science makes you reflect on world around you. Maybe, The Witness is not the game that asks to be completed in any way, just as you can't complete life. Maybe you really just need to close it and go outside.

I recommend playing The WItness. I don't recommend finishing it.

So right off the bat, my no recommendation isn't exactly true. Just to get this out of the way, here's my positives. if you are the kind of player who loves puzzles and working them out, and I mean LOVE puzzles, this game is for you. Granted, the entire game is line puzzles, but there is enough variety that you can keep your brain working harder and harder as the game goes on. Additionally, if you love beautiful and colorful environments, you'll also love this game. With that out of the way, here's why I wouldn't really recommend this for the average player. This game has a lot of line puzzles, and I mean A LOT. If you don't thing you can play through about 10 hours or so of just line puzzles with some variation here and there, you probably shouldn't pick this one up unless its on sale. Granted, if you're here looking at a puzzle game then you're probably all on board for that! What's really my turn off is spoilers though: [spoiler] To start out with positive spoilers, I absolutely LOVE the obelisk puzzles! I accidently discovered one of the lines in the world while exploring the town, and i fell in love with it. I think I spent more of my down time looking for lines around the world than anything. I don't know why, but this alone was what kept me playing through to the end despite my struggles. On with the negatives though,  a lot of the endgame areas are absolutely BRUTAL with gimmicks that will probably take you an hour just to understand and then make you sit on a single puzzle for another hour. Specifically, there is a block gimmick where you are shown specific Tetris-like blocks and you must fill in the puzzle accordingly. This is tough on its own, but when it is combined with some of the game's even more tricky gimmicks it gets to the point where you cannot complete the game unless you are a line puzzle god I personally had to look up some solutions around the end of the game due to the nature of these puzzles just frying my brain. As you can tell by my play time, I absolutely breezed through the beginning areas by my own without problem, but the endgame areas such as the Mountain and Quarry are just insane. Additionally, there is a completely optional challenge run which is absolutely insane with the timing. I have only seen a few legitimate runs through it, others use game pause shenanigans to stop the in-game timer so they can solve each puzzle. It is optional though so I can't really knock the game too hard for that. [/spoiler]

The experience of finding solutions in this game feels more like inspiration than conscious reasoining. The solutions just appear to you when they feel like it. The first puzzle in each area serves as a brilliant tutorial for the mechanic being introduced in the area. Sometimes it takes awhile to see the solutions and it'll be a little frustrating sometimes but trust me, keep exploring until you find a puzzle that makes sense, and soon you will be off on a mind-bending journey of discovery, perspective, and skilled observation. This game will make you look at it like you've never looked at anything before. And then, if you do the mechanical transferrence thing where you start to think of what if you could apply video game mechanics to other games, or real life, and this game will make you look at the world more carefully and maybe even see things you hadn't before.

Every replay of this game leaves me feeling more and more empty.
And yet I can't stop.

Everywhere I go, I see line puzzles. Each thing, each person that happen to exist within my gaze are nothing more than an unsolvable puzzle. Maybe the angle is wrong, maybe I have to move something around?

The clouds are full of puzzles. The cracks in the sidewalk must connect to a circle somewhere. 
I look into my child's eye. I must click the circle. The puzzle must be solved.

As a professional witness myself, I can say that this game is an apt depiction of what it's like to have eyes. 
As a bonus, the game also allows you to have ears. 

I go on a walk to try to take my mind off of things. A leaf falls from a tree and lands in the lake, resting calmly on the surface of the water. There is still work to be done here. 

I hear birds chirping around me, dogs barking. The gravel shifts beneath my feet with each step. 
Maybe if I time it right, I can get a puzzle with that kid's ball he's kicking around. 

Hopscotch. Tic-tac-toe. Drawings on the sidewalk of unknowable creatures. I see a circle.
I water my plants. An unripe tomato on a vine. The way the sun lines with with the top of the trellis.
My eyes burn. Maybe this new dot in my vision is part of a secret puzzle.

I can't listen to classical music anymore. Travelling is hard. The world beneath a plane is just more puzzles.
If I go to a hotel, I'll just wake up again. I need to solve the puzzles first. I can't take the elevator either yet.
It's easier to just stay home instead. Maybe I should replay The Witness again.

Let me start by saying that I'm a big puzzle connoisseur. I've played many puzzle games in the past and that is almost exclusively what I have been playing recently. I was very excited about The Witness because it had great reviews and people saying that they wish they could erase their memories to play it all over again. When I jumped into the game I was greeted with the first simple puzzles that are about drawing lines on a grid. That 'grid drawing' concept follows you around throughout the whole game and seemed extremely easy to follow at first but becomes more and more complex with new rules being added as you go.

Right after leaving the starting area, you are thrown into an open world environment that is actively working against you (at least that's how it felt to me). There are no markers indicating where you should go or what you should do next or how to continue and/or what the goal of the game actually is. You are completely on your own. As I mentioned before, the grid drawing becomes more complex as you continue but since there are no guidelines telling you where to go, it is easy to end up in an area with crazy puzzles and rules that you haven't even learned the basics for yet. Even if you manage to find the 'tutorial' puzzles, there are no directions as to how you can solve them. For example, the grid can contain a symbol that indicates that you must ignore/break another rule within the same puzzle. If you know the game, this might sound easy to you but if you have no idea what it means and you're completely new, this sort of 'tutorial' is not helpful at all and is quite frustrating to deal with (if you're lucky enough to find the 'tutorial' puzzle in the first place).

I am not the type to look up answers to games either because I want to find the solution myself but did find myself having to look up the rules to certain puzzles simply because I didn't understand what was required of me. 

The most frustrating thing that made me decide not to continue with the game was when I worked my way through a castle with 4 hedge mazes. Up until that point, every single puzzle was based off visual clues. You had to see in order to decide how a puzzle was to be solved. The third maze had audio clues that would tell you where to go. I usually listen to my music while playing solo puzzle games or have my headphones off so I was stuck at this puzzle for 40-50 minutes before I gave up and decided to find a guide, JUST to realize that I had to hear my way through the maze. Eventually I felt more frustration than satisfaction so I have decided to quit altogether. 

I don't like giving negative reviews and do was to end by saying that everyone should make up their own mind. Most people seem to like this game which I completely respect and understand. For the puzzles that I understood, I really enjoyed myself and loved the difficulty progression. For the puzzles that didn't make sense to me, I hated just how stuck I felt without knowing where I might be able to find the answer. 

All in all, while I didn't like 'The Witness' myself, I do recommend trying it out and experiencing it for yourself.

I dislike this game.

[h3]In short:[/h3]
At first I was charmed by the environment and the puzzles. Then I realized that this game tries really hard to be something intellectual and philosophical, something that gives no reason to anything existing in this world. "Think about it yourself", or something like that. Usually games reward exploration and progression with lore and discoveries. Not in this one. The ending sucked too.

[hr][/hr]

[h3]Long rant:[/h3]

[u]The puzzles:[/u]
The puzzles seemed quite cool at the start. A very unique concept which builds on itself in new and original ways. At the start, the way the puzzles are introduced is quite simple and they get a little more complicated as it goes on, which made sense.
However, there is no textual explanation, so when you try a puzzle and accidentally get it correct, you will never know why. Building upon that to more complicated puzzles then becomes impossible if you don't understand the logic.
The good thing is the feedback when you get a puzzle wrong. This makes it easier to find the fault in your solution and adjust it accordingly. For me personally, this never worked with the [spoiler]Tetris puzzles[/spoiler]. I really thought I would have part of the puzzle correct, only for it to blink red and confuse me to no end. I ended up googling this specific puzzle type because I just couldn't be bothered anymore.
Also, I hated the [spoiler]sound puzzles[/spoiler]. It tries to overwhelm you just by adding chaos (which is lame btw), which it very much did for me, to the point where there was no logical explanation which [spoiler]sound[/spoiler] I needed to be working with. Stupid.

[u]The environment:[/u]
This is what initially drew me in about this game. The world is interesting, incredibly beautiful and fun to discover. There are "secrets" everywhere. The sound effects are soothing and really draw you into the world. I found it fun to run around and discover places I hadn't been to. The colors were stunning and it's interesting trying to discover some sort of story about all of it.

[u]The lore?[/u]
At first I was intrigued by the environment, why it was shaped this way, what it was trying to tell me. Soon I realized that it was a very disappointing story, [spoiler]tangled in philosophy.[/spoiler] I can think of something myself or fill in the gaps, in which case it could be anything, which I just don't like. Especially the ending makes it ten times worse, if not a hundred times. [spoiler] It uses the same thing a lot of tv shows and stories use that I just don't like; "it was all a dream/fake lol. this was all for nothing"[/spoiler]

[u]In the end...[/u]
This game just feels like it could've been so much more, but, I don't know, because it wanted to be unique or different, it has chosen a very specific route and approach that is just not for everyone. [spoiler] I really feel like I wasted a lot of time just watching some guy getting his candle blown out. Like, what?[/spoiler] Maybe there is something very profound about it that I just didn't get. Maybe this just isn't my kind of game. I just got frustrated with it and wanted it to end asap.

There are some really cool mechanics in here and some interesting environmental clues to a story, it's just, not enough. The frustration with stupid puzzles and lack of guidance and lore is just overwhelming for me to recommend it to anyone. I do not recommend it. It feels like a frustrating waste of time.

I enjoy puzzles and problem solving.  

I love the beautiful art and pristine, vibrant aesthetics.

I do not enjoy THESE types of puzzles, which are mostly simple variations of connect-the-dot, combined together to solve larger puzzles, but requiring a lot of wandering around to figure out which ones need to be done in order or together. 

The puzzles are a weird juxtaposition against the beautiful scenery, where you're solving what look like 8-bit puzzle games connected by power/network cables, and that really takes away from the atmosphere IMO.  Combine that with a lack of any context/story to provide mystery or impetus to move forward, and I just couldn't immerse myself.  

TLDR:

I just don't "get it".

I wish I could recommend this game as it's beautiful and has some interesting puzzles, but I really can't and am frustrated with the game more than anything else.

In the beginning, all is well. Very straight forward puzzles, a logical game flow and the experience is great. But a few hours in, the fact that it's an open world starts working against you. You will encounter puzzles to which you probably haven't been introduced yet before and have no real means of solving or understanding the rules without finding the tutorial puzzles of that type first. And even if you do find the correct starting point for a certain type of puzzle, once you think you understand the rules, the rules are sometimes changed halfway through with barely any indication that they did. So everything you thought you knew can be thrown out of the window and you're beginning from scratch again.

If you don't mind sitting on the same puzzle for a long time trying to figure it out, this game might be for you. I am not that person. I am a casual gamer. I don't have the patience to spend an hour per puzzle and then probably end up either brute-forcing my way to finding the logic or playing the game alongside YouTube tutorials. And that just sucks the fun out of it completely if you are not a hardcore puzzler and more of casual player. 

Really wish there were any optional hints/explanation in the game to ease you into the puzzles or give you a nudge if you're stuck. I am just not that hardcore of a puzzle gamer to want to invest a lot of time in individual puzzles and it just got increasingly frustrating more than anything else if I couldn't understand the logic behind a puzzle. I might still complete the game for the sake of seeing where the story is going, but it will probably be through walkthrough videos more than anything, which is a shame.

The one downfall of this game is that it expects it's players to be just as pretentious as the creator. You must assume everything has a purpose, everything is designed, and if you are stuck, its intentional.
This game is challenging, but not just in the conventional puzzle sense. The witness does not necessarily put the tools you need to solve the puzzles in your hands. Instead, you must learn what the tools are, and how they are intended to be used. In my opinion, that is the genius of this game. However, this can create a disconnect between the player and the puzzles as, at some points, if you are not confident with the tools, it can feel like trying to fit a square peg into round hole. That being said, while I may have encountered said challenge, I did not see it to be a barrier to my enjoyment of the game; not at all.

The witness, in a way, could be considered a game of trust. This goes back to that pretentiousness I mentioned at the beginning; when I played this game, I refused to attribute my lack of understanding to the games lack of guidance. I believe this is because whatever teaching the game did felt like a mere courtesy. Near the beginning of the game, you are introduced to a puzzle that uses multiple mechanics you have not been introduced to yet. Most players assume this puzzle is intended to be skipped, and while this may be practically true, I argue that intention need not be considered here. That is because if you would like to sit around for 30 minutes or more and brute force this puzzle, you can. 
I believe this shows the nature of The Witness; not just a game with challenges to overcome, but a game that is conceptually, from the ground up and in it's entirety, a challenge within of itself. This makes more sense when considering that there are puzzles in this game that you can not be expected to solve without the assistance of pen and paper, and others that just seem without regard for the player. And that's why I love this game. It REFUSES to meet you where you are at, yet is never ONCE intentionally vague (I'm looking at you, Destiny 2). As a completionist, the puzzles made me feel clever, but the game made me feel like a champion.

The Witness is undoubtedly one of the finest puzzle games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. From the very first moments, as you step onto the mysterious and beautifully crafted island, the game captivates with its stunning aesthetics and meticulously designed structure. Every corner of the island hides unique puzzles that demand not only logical thinking but also keen observation and patience.

One of the greatest strengths of The Witness is the freedom it offers in exploration. You are not led by the hand – instead, you independently uncover the rules governing the game world and seek out solutions. Each puzzle presents a genuine challenge, providing immense satisfaction upon finding the correct answer.

The game is not just a test of intelligence but also a philosophical journey. Subtle hints and hidden narrative elements prompt reflection on perception, knowledge, and consciousness. The Witness is not just a game; it is an experience that lingers in the memory long after the final puzzle is solved.

Jonathan Blow and his team have crafted a masterpiece that stands out among other puzzle games. I highly recommend this game to anyone seeking a truly challenging and intellectually stimulating experience. The Witness is a true gem in the world of video games.

Okay. Now, allow me to review one of the best puzzle game I ever played which stands side by side with Portal 2. In fact, you know what? It is the best game I ever played. Now onto the game. The Witness started with a very basic introduction to the format of the puzzle which is to connect a dot to the other dot across a line. That's it. The concept is very easy to grasp especially for puzzle lovers. But then as you progress through the game, it started introducing new mechanics within the 'connect the dot' gameplay, which then it started to hit you: this game is not as easy as it does several minutes ago. But, the pure genius behind The Witness is that it educates us on the puzzle solution without using any single word or narrative. It lets our brain works on itself and by the time we figured it all out, we started to realize that our brain has been subconciously rewired by it. We leveled up not by EXP point or gold, but by our own understanding of the game. The currency of the game is knowledge. Truly one of the best cerebral journey in gaming ever. And discovering how all the puzzles are interconnected with each other within the small island it's located in is such an amazing revelation, and it shows how much love the developer puts during the creation of it. Don't get me started on the environmental puzzles. Holy cow, if that ain't one of the most unique and magical puzzles gameplay ever existed, I don't even know what is. A pure, authentic puzzle lovers would never miss out on this game. And if you know some puzzle lovers who still haven't discovered it, let them know. Because they are in for a wild ride. And let them be the witness. (no pun intended)

10/10 will keep searching for the environmental puzzles in my own hometown (if you know what I mean)

A very simplistic yet kind of addicting puzzle game. Mechanics are simple, if you see a circle followed by a line, you just drag your cursor along the line to its end. As you go along the game, the puzzles go from simple mazes to adding more and more elements one after the other and then combining them all, making the ending sections very challenging.
Added to the “main areas” are a lot of environmental puzzles where areas in the environment line up in a way that creates a new maze you have to solve. In total there are 523 normal and 135 environmental puzzles, so this game will take you quite a while to actually beat everything. But if you’re not into having a completed save file, you can also just stick to the main areas and see the ending without having to go out of your way to look for all the collectibles.
There are also a whole lot of audio logs scattered around the world which are beautifully narrated, but I just didn’t have the drive to look for and listen to all of them, but there seems to be some bigger meaning and philosophy hidden throughout the entire thing.
If I had to give one big critique, it’s this game’s non-linearity. Yes, it makes exploring the island a whole lot more fun, you’re basically given complete access after beating the Entry Area, but you’ll more often then not stumble into a puzzle you just won’t be able to solve at that stage. The easier areas are close to the starting point but even then, there are no worded explanations to how puzzle elements work and on some you’re stuck with trial and error until something works and then you have to go back to figure out why. It kind of drove the fun out of things for me, which is why I stuck to spoiler free walkthroughs that guided me through all the areas in increasing difficulty which I think is the way to go.
Overall, if you’ve got a thing for maze puzzles and a couple dozen hours to spare then this is a definite recommendation.

[u]Achievements[/u]
There are only 2 achievements in the entire game, and both are relatively straightforward. The first one just requires you to beat the game by finishing all the main areas and the ending section. The second one is a bit trickier. After beating the game for the first time you unlock The Challenge which is basically a timed gauntlet of multiple randomly generated puzzles using all the elements used throughout the game. This can be quite tough, and it personally took me about 2 hours until I finally beat it even though I was only off by a couple of seconds. Beating this does feel very satisfying tho. So, even if you’re not the best at the maze puzzles, it’s not a hard 100%

Pros:

Beautiful, eerie, atmospheric, engaging -- its sunny, inspiring world is a joy to linger in, even if you don't like the (sometimes obnoxiously hard and a bit monotonic) drill of puzzles. There's no rush, no stress, you can't die, and AFAIK you can't really paint yourself into a corner either.

It also has remarkably polished game physics, which you won't notice due to the minimalist controls (you can basically just walk), but no news is good news here: it's not your average glitchy custom 3D engine from the low-poly era.

Cons:

- A bit sluggish: my 2-core i5 notebook almost chokes on it with all the gfx set to lowest. Fortunately, it still looks gorgeous, due to its lush, vivid, colorful design.

- The game was meant to be 100% explored and 0% explained (with no auxiliary or meta narrative, no tutorials, no hints etc.), but this means that e.g. the effect, or even the very purpose of, some puzzles (esp. those optional yellow/orange ones scattered all across the map) are really just frustrating to figure out, rather than mysterious and exciting.

- [!!! SPOILER !!!] Many stunning, intriguing creative elements of the world serve no purpose whatsoever, they are mere embellishments (even otherwise interactive objects like the audio tapes and secret puzzles -- which are just weirdly off-topic and tedious spiritual/philosophical monologues). They do reinforce the unique vibe, but still: what a sorely missed opportunity!

Do you like puzzles? Do you like dozens of interesting and intersecting mechanics for what seem like simple puzzles? Do you like being haunted by the voices of philosophers who pontificate on the nature of life and reality while you solve puzzles? Did I mention puzzles?

A highly engrossing game, with beautiful graphics and game design and nice puzzles, ranging from fairly easy to very complicated. It is clear that a lot of love and attention to detail went into making this. Highly recommended if you like puzzle solving games/

Review Summary: Overall it is a good game and is worthwhile if you're really interested in obtuse puzzles, simple open world exploration, and philosophy, but if not I can't really recommend it. Don't expect a story or in game rewards outside of a sense of achievement. It has a serious issue with causing motion sickness even if you don't normally experience it with games. Also, be careful if you are epileptic, some portions will likely cause problems for you.

-------------------

I like the game, the visuals are overall great, and can be great if you're interested in it, but there are some severe issues. It isn't a bad game, but don't go in expecting it to be a cake walk, and don't go in expecting great rewards for completing stuff outside of a sense of achievement. Also, don't go in expecting a story, the closest thing to that in the game are the various audio recordings of philosophical or poetic quotes and the very light environmental storytelling, with it being more of an experience based game than a story one.

One big thing that I should mention is that if you are hard of hearing or deaf, there is an entire section that will likely be pretty much impossible to get through without a walk through, and if you are epileptic there are certain parts which will be pretty dangerous for you, particularly in the final portion of the game.

Its a decently interesting world to explore, with each area being visually unique with a ton of puzzles, though these puzzles can get extremely infuriating at points due to them being needlessly obtuse or being based around some function that is poorly taught to the player. 

The biggest issue is that it seems like it was designed to cause you to experience motion sickness. I've never experienced that issue with any game before. 2 of the 3 main causes can be fixed, the FOV and the lack of reticle, yet the motion blur is still pretty nauseating. Also, there are some portions such as the boat as well as some puzzles in the final area which really cause this issue to get a lot worse when doing them. Again, I have never before experienced motion sickness from a game before this, and it got pretty bad at points even after fixing the two issues I mentioned.
Witness'd

Full disclosure: I didn't finish the game. I wanted to like The Witness when I started, but I can't recommend it. 

In my mind, the only thing going for it is the visuals. It's stylized and gorgeous. 

If there's a narrative, I have no idea what it is. I found a few audio logs on the ground that had random quotes from historical figures. Maybe it's building to some grand philosophical point? I'm sure it's loaded with environmental storytelling. 10 hours in though, I had no idea where I was there or why I should care. Unlike games like Portal or the Talos Principle, there was just zero intrigue. It didn't feel like the game *wanted* me to care.

The gameplay is a slog. The core mechanic puzzle mechanic is staring at a board and trying to draw connections between points. Along the way, various rules are introduced to make this more complicated. Again, I only made it 10 hrs in. Maybe the variety improves (many other reviews are closer to 50 hrs). But so far, this is the only mechanic. The rules they introduce to complicate this mechanic aren't interesting. They are either obvious, or obscure to the point where you succeed by pure trial and error. You sometimes get feedback about which rules were violated when you fail a puzzle, but rarely *how* the rule was violated. Communication of the the "how I failed" part is pretty critical to learning. But even when the rules make sense and you feel accomplished for learning/using them, they get monotonous quickly.

The environmental visuals also factor into the puzzles. I like this idea, since it breaks up the monotony of staring at a grid. These sometimes feel great. Other times, they are punishingly obscure. Once you learn what an environment cue means, the game degrades into the modern equivalent of pixel hunting. You need to run around and find the very specific spot/angle you need to to solve the puzzle from. Even though they are interesting at times, they often lead to even more monotony.

 Some puzzles have the infuriating property of deactivating when you fail to solve them. This isn't a "branching path" kind of thing. When a puzzle deactivates, you just need to go back and re-solve the previous puzzle. Your solution is still shown on the previous puzzle. So, you just redraw the lines and go back to the puzzle you were actually trying to solve. It does nothing but waste your time. Some puzzles do this, others don't. It's a minor issue, but a baffling game design decision. It adds nothing but (are you excited for the word of the day yet ?) just even more monotony. 

Skill issue? Maybe. Maybe these puzzles aren't for me. But if I wanted to stare at grid for hours, I could buy a Sudoku book and go to the park. I could do that for a lot less than the outrageous $40 dollars they're still (in 2024) charge for this game. The book might not have a payoff at the end, but I know it won't try to serve me some "deep and profound" pseudo-philosophical point from a random dev who made a poorly-designed puzzle game

This is a video game. If you treat it as such - as a hugely involving series of thoughtfully constructed puzzles that can only be solved by immersing yourself in a virtual world - then you'll have a ton of fun. If you treat it as a commentary on games themselves, as a novel, as a metaphysical statement, or as a sort of interactive film, you may consider yourself educated, but you won't have much fun.

Don't let anyone push you away from or pull you into this game because it's supposedly "smarter" than the average. You complete ridiculously rewarding spatial reasoning puzzles - basically, figuring out "where do I draw the line" - that were clearly created with care and insight, and every so often you encounter some philosophical musings. No more complicated than that - nor does it need to be. Have fun!
