So I think this might be the most hours I've put in to something that I really ended up just hating.
But I think that may have been the point of the game.

Hear me out.
You know how Andy Kaufman wanted to put static into a TV broadcast cause he thought it would be funny to screw with the audience? I think this is a video game of that.
I'm embarrassed it took me so long to catch on, but it boils the frog slowly and lulls you into thinking it's being clever.
It didn't realise this was the case until I found myself "solving" a "puzzle" by literally standing locked in place, listening to an annoyingly pretentious narrator talking about how he used to work at radio shack and realising I would have to stand there for about an hour of him doing this until the moment the "puzzle's" solution became valid.
At that moment I was like "Oh... I'm the butt of the joke. I'm being f***ed with," and I stopped the puzzle, closed the game, and realised I'd been the butt of the joke for over 50 hours.

I don't know if I should be mad at the game for messing with me or if I should respect it for doing such a good job. Either way, I feel stupid for letting myself be duped. Kind of that feeling you get when you're stuck on a puzzle for a long time and then notice something super obvious that makes it trivial, but on a huge scale.

Anyway, I wouldn't recommend playing this game. Zero stars, or maybe five stars.

[i]The Witness[/i] is a fantastic game; I would really have no qualms about ending the review there. It uses a beautiful mesh of realism and painterly impressionism to make a beautiful world whose sense of exploration and wonder is perfectly in line with the great litany of things to be found, from a great many little secret and clever detail which reward the careful eye, to the hundreds of line puzzles throughout. 

Despite the quantity of the puzzles throughout, almost each and every one of them serves some purpose. From teaching you a mechanical consequence to simply opening a door, each puzzle's completion is its own reward, bringing you step by step closer to enlightenment.
l
I'm being vague on purpose because as a puzzle game - a [u]very, very good[/u] puzzle game -  [i]The Witness[/i]' every moment is that of beautiful, resonant revelation between utterly brain-bending trials. A lesser game would provide hints, background music, anything to latch onto, but [i]The Witness[/i] leaves you completely and utterly to your own devices and is such very much susceptible to being spoiled and very much is best experienced as blind as can be. I'm going to talk about a few significant spoilers, which I'll black out for the sake of the prospective [i]Witness[/i] player. Enjoy!

However, it's not perfect; I have a few gripes, really the tiniest of nitpicks on what was otherwise an amazing game I could happily recommend to any puzzle fan.

[olist]
[*]When you have a puzzle selected, there's often something dinging. Either the beginning circle or the endpoints of the puzzle - which the game elegantly and wordlessly teaches the importance of to the player - are constantly blinking, with a visual and auditory cue. For a game that relishes in giving you the time and mental space to think things out, a tiny mistake like this really feels like a bullet.

[*]Some puzzles, upon failure, deactivate. This makes it so you have to go back and re-enter the solution (which is typically pretty easy to remember but [i]does[/i] disappear as you re-interact with a given puzzle panel) to the previous panel in a sequence - a feature which is never telegraphed to the player (though even if it was it would be just as unpleasant). [i]The Witness[/i] as a game, other than this one quirk, can really pride itself on its terseness of concept so again it is a shame to see something like this bubble up through. Solving a puzzle in this game is a communication of understanding, having to repeat it again mindlessly in some arbitrary rite of passage to retry the current puzzle is, even if a very short inconvenience when it does happen, a baffling blunder from a game like this.

[*]There shouldn't be a sprint button. The obvious response is [i]"Well, why don't you just not sprint?[/i] but at the end of the day the purpose of a system is what it does; and a sprint, naturally, encourages sprinting. At least to me, something like that communicates a lack of trust in the game environment to a) be beautiful and b) communicate priorities and paths to the player. 

The obvious exception to this is [spoiler]the challenge (which is fantastic by the way; I'm not sure I've ever truly comprehended the heart-stopping terror of [i]In the Hall of the Mountain King[/i] until I played this game), to the point that I'm convinced that a sprint was added with the express purpose of being used in the challenge, just kind of being this odd vestigial growth for the rest of the game during which you, very notably, never need to and shouldn't move fast. Especially for noticing the puzzles hidden in the map; the mix of boredom and wonder of an aimless walk throughout the island is very sufficient fuel to find a very large chunk of these.[/spoiler]

Especially given the extra shortcuts and movement options the game grants you pretty early on and only expands on as you progress, having a sprint on top of that just feels overkill to me.

[*][spoiler]Obtaining the secret ending, the one with the hotel and the credits and the real-life video, is a bit odd. I'm going to have to talk a lot more about the game a bit more holistically to describe what I mean.[/spoiler]

[spoiler][i]The Witness[/i], to me, feels like an allegory for the Buddhist concept of enlightenment. As the game approaches its end and you enter the mountain which has been ominously looming over the island and attracting the lights of lasers, you begin to get the sense that this is all a test of sorts. A few nuggets that hint toward this appear throughout the island; recurring symbols, sketches of buildings and puzzles, but here it goes mask-off. Various security monitors show parts of the island, and malfunctioning and rejected puzzles are strewn about the various laboratory-like rooms of the mountain. And yet even these lead you deeper and deeper down the mountain, culminating in an elevator chamber which flies you to the beginning of the game, losing all your control as all your puzzles become undone and culminating in the game itself closing. When you re-open the game you are as you would be if you had never played the game at all, at the start of the very first hallway with no progress in the island to speak of.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]This to me feels like a death and rebirth of the player character. Though the puzzles are in the same deactivated state as they were when you first downloaded the game, your knowledge and intuition of the game persists; if you started from scratch you would absolutely finish far quicker than your first attempt. However, the secret ending is not about progressing; rather it is about finding an environmental puzzle using the sun - the most significant circle in the game, one which looms over you for the entire time - thus activating a hotel lounge, which a straight walk forward through brings you to the secret ending. In this secret ending a human wakes up from some kind of virtual simulation and walks around the real studio in which [i]The Witness[/i] was developed, utterly transfixed on patterns of lines and circles. This feeling was completely and utterly relatable, that tiny worm that [i]The Witness[/i] grows in your brain for seeing circles connected to lines very well might be the game's most profound export.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]However, the secret ending does not follow this exact sequence.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]What I believe is the intended route to the secret ending revolves around a room, hidden behind activating all 11 lasers (of which only 7 of one's own choice are required to beat the game) and the optional challenge (which, amidst all this negative babble, I feel inclined to mention again is AMAZING). In this room is a puzzle solution which, when put into a certain panel in the starting section, re-seals the door making the sun puzzle, previously blocked off by forward progression, once again possible. I realize this is the tiniest of nitpicks, but the whole beauty of the secret ending, to me, [i]is[/i] that voluntary relinquishing of all puzzle progress, [i]is[/i] that metaphorical acceptance of one's own death to reach enlightenment! Being able to get this ending while having all your pretty puzzle panels lit up, while still indulging oneself in the [i]samsara[/i] of the game world, feels so thematically incoherent to me! Of course, this is the most minute of nitpicks, but finding flaws in a game as pleasant and absorbing in this is like finding needles in a haystack, exclusively by having them prick your fingers.[/spoiler]
[/olist]

If you read through all that, thank you! I have not tried to articulate my thoughts about [i]The Witness[/i] very much at all, so actually putting the experience of this game that has utterly entranced me is always nice - like a release valve in my brain. I do want to revisit it someday, but for now I think I've earned a break.

If you just scrolled to the bottom and haven't played it, go away!! Play [i]The Witness[/i]!!

I'm not going to give a game that I found really fun a pass on completely skipping accessibility options.

The review if this game had accessibility options:

I love the puzzles, the rule discovery and the world. The interaction between the constantly evolving grid rules and the environment is amazing, the two end areas were a ton of fun (besides the dumb flashing color screens). I can't describe how high the highs of this game are. The challenge was one of the most fun things in a puzzle game I've played.

Like all puzzle games, it has stinkers. Puzzles that either suck, or just didn't click with me. Color theory land sucks (how does magenta + magenta = white?). The ship vault was one of the most overdesigned puzzles I've ever seen, and ridiculous logical leaps have to be made. The way to access the entire secret area is just cruel, especially considering how obvious it is that the area exists, and considering how [spoiler]you can't know that some environmental puzzles and the 4th paper are there[/spoiler].

I don't agree with the people that say this game has too many puzzles, that the grid puzzles all feel the same and get old, that it's just trying to waste your time, or that it's pretentious (I don't even understand what half the crap means and I don't care). But, I will respect that games don't click with everybody, players can miss one thing and be confused the whole time, sometimes players have less patience or less experience with certain types of games.

I almost completely enjoyed my time with this game, and even that GDC talk made me smile (and the you know what with it - i hated its existence, but it's kinda funny i guess).

The reason for the negative review:

But again, I will not respect a game that does not make itself accessible to as many players as it can. Colorblind options and options for those that are deaf or hard of hearing (or just not making puzzles based on those things)? An epilepsy warning? Controller support? Audio options? I don't understand how this was published without these things.

i first played this game when i was 16 and, despite having loved puzzle games ever since i could remember, this game made me fall in love with these games in a whole new way. this game is the ultimate show-don't-tell masterpiece, and the marrying of simplicity with complexity is done in such a beautiful way that it makes Myst look like a baby's binky.

what is really incredible about this game is how the environment and the individual "puzzle games" are combined and played with in really thoughtful and mind-bending ways. nothing feels like a gimmick; everything feels inventive and creative to the point that every single challenge gives you an incredible feeling when you find the solution.

however, it is really, really difficult. i pride myself on never, ever looking up a guide/walkthrough to playing any puzzle game that i start. for this game, i hope you're ready to test your patience-- i stopped playing about halfway through and i didn't pick up this game again until 6 years later, when i was 22, stopping again about 3/4 of the way through.

now, at 24, i am just about to complete the (base) game, save for all of the environmental puzzles (which i'm still about 1/2 through). these puzzles are probably the most awe inspiring part of the game-- they mirror the mini puzzle games but in your visual perspective of the environment around you. some of them are straightforward, but almost all of them make you feel like you've discovered an impossibly hidden treasure when you find and solve them. i'm looking forward to finding them all, maybe by the time i'm 30.

but really, take your time with this game, and i promise it'll be an unforgettable experience. 

also, there are some interesting philosophical ramblings and a sort-of story/narrative that you discover in a non-linear way as you solve the puzzles. i like how open-ended it is, but i definitely think the Talos Principle is the best philosophical puzzle game of all time.

Some clever ideas, but too much of it is tedious and annoying. I like games like Portal that have a linear progression. The player is given a simple goal and the puzzles get progressively harder. It has tutorials in the beginning that familiarize you with the mechanics. You're never lost or wondering what exactly you're supposed to do even as the levels get more tricky. 

The Witness, on the other hand, just throws you in and expects you to figure everything out on your own. Some people might appreciate that it doesn't hold your hand, but I found that to be a source of major frustration.

The game has a relatively big open world and doesn't give you any pointers or instructions. The first dozen puzzles are easy to figure out, but later on they get more complicated and it becomes a chore just to figure out what you're supposed to do. You have the option to skip puzzles and find something else to do, but many of them have to be activated first by solving other puzzles. That means that there's a lot of running around aimlessly just trying to find active puzzles to solve. The open world is too big and doesn't give you much direction on where to find the more beginner friendly challenges, so you waste a lot of time running from place to place.

Some puzzles are more tedious than hard to figure out. They require memorization. For example, you have to walk through a maze and then draw the path you just walked. Stuff like that isn't hard or challenging. It's boring. When the best way to 'solve' a puzzle is to take out a piece of paper and draw a map or a pattern, that's a cheap puzzle that doesn't actually challenge you intellectually and just feels like a chore.

I like puzzle games. I like challenging games (for example, I've managed to get all the achievements in Sekiro, which I'm pretty proud of). But one thing that always annoys me is a lack of direction. I want to know what I'm supposed to be doing. I don't want to wander aimlessly or keep having to guess how the basic mechanics of a puzzle are supposed to work. Solving the puzzle itself is supposed to be the fun part. If I spend half of that time just trying to figure out the mechanics of the puzzle, that hurts the experience.

Here's the short answer. It a beautiful; mechanically rich puzzle game. Its puzzles are genuinely some of the best I've seen and they are truly unique. Highly recommend playing it, but only if you're fine with never solving all of its puzzles.

Now for the long answer...The whole game relies on exploration of a gorgeous and massive map with almost no defined direction. So you're free to go pretty much anywhere and solve each section of the world in the order you deem fit, which is great for when you eventually get stuck on a puzzle you don't know the rules to and can't progress in that particular area; but its also bad because you never know where you should go to learn rules to mechanics you've never seen.

This game creates a sort of game loop where you do a few puzzles, get stuck, go explore, solve some more puzzle somewhere else, and after hours of doing that, you find a tutorial for a mechanic you saw earlier; so now you have to go back and solve those puzzles, which lead to either more puzzles you don't know the rules to, or a dead end with a cryptic hint that you won't understand for a long...long time.

There are some puzzle that never give you tutorials, and you just have to infer to rules from the puzzle you get, which can be a little difficult. But in most cases, the puzzles are designed in a way where you CAN find the knowledge to solve them. I'm not sure if I'm particularly good at puzzling or if this type of puzzle is just something I'm good at, but I didn't need to look up solutions for the majority of the puzzles, I had solved around 500+ puzzles before I finally had to look up a solution to a puzzle which a lot of people said was one of the hardest to figure out. So take this paragraph with a pinch of salt if you're not a seasoned puzzle solver...in fact, I'd say that you REALLY shouldn't play this game unless you have played an extensive amount of puzzle games before it, because this will test your patience, this game will ask you to be good at visualizing multi-step processes in your head, making leaps of logic, MEMORIZING PATTERNS, constantly changing your perspective (literally and figuratively) and extrapolating information from small amount of hints.

Ok that paragraph went on a little long, but in short...if you want to solve this game without guides...it is going to be an arduous task. Now for a bit more spoiler-y stuff (I'll try to keep the spoilers to a minimum tho), so if you want to go in with no knowledge of the story and world-building aspects; don't read any further.

So the game has gotten some negative press for its story elements, and for a justified reason (not a good reason mind you, just justified). As you play the game, you will find these small audio players that you can interact with; which will start an audio log. These audio logs talk about philosophy and things that honestly feel very..."artsy" in nature. Ones I listened to a few of them, I stopped caring or paying any mind to them. None of the audio logs are needed to solve the puzzles and listening to them felt like the game creator was trying to be seen as "sophisticated" and as "an intellectual"; which honestly might be the point? not too sure?

Then there is the controversial ending of the game (major spoilers!). You've been solving hundreds of puzzles at this point, and you finally find your way to the top of the mountain, for what seems like the final puzzle. To your shock, when you solve those puzzles a door opens up and you head inside the mountain into a portal-esc interior. The puzzles only get harder and challenge you in new unconventional ways and you keep struggling your way down level after level of increasingly more challenging concepts. Then you finally get to the bottom; solve 8 of the hardest to visualize puzzles (their not really that hard but its like really hard to wrap your head around them visually) and then you're presented with an elevator. You take the elevator and it takes you on a long.....long....long ride through the entire map; showing all the puzzles turning off and resetting back to being unsolved...and at the end of the ride, you're at the beginning and the game closes, when you open it back up, you're at the start of the game. None of your efforts mattered, all the puzzles you solved meant nothing, the world you awed at for hours...meant nothing. There is no explanation for why you're here, why the people are turned to stone, why you're solving these puzzles...no explanation for anything. 

Now to a lot of people this might be a little upsetting, which I can sympathies with; but in all honestly I feel like it was very clear from the start that this game was all about solving puzzles...just because you want to solve some good puzzles. Because there is no achievements for solving puzzles, there is nothing that indicates the percentage of puzzles you've done; only a number of puzzles you've solved. There is nothing in the game that tells you "you've done it all, you can quit now" and when people talk about 100% this game, it is based on an agreed amount of puzzles shown in your puzzle count. which isn't 100% accurate (there is a section in the game where you solve a bunch of puzzles and they count as less than what you actually solve) and its not 100% confirmed to be the true number of puzzles in the game. Bottom line is that 100% this game was never the point of the game, the game never expects you to solve all the puzzles and IT WILL NOT REWARD YOU FOR DOING SO. 

So If you've gotten this far into my review, just know that its a great puzzle game...But for the love of god, stop playing it when you stop having fun solving the puzzles, you will gain nothing from solving any more than you want to solve...and also there is a puzzle that literally takes an hour of REAL TIME WAITING to solve...so there's that as well...

Get this game, solve like 450-500 puzzles and be done with it. The visceral feeling of solving a puzzle that has been stumping you for hours is a feeling that this game will keep giving you in spades, but its all its going to give you; nothing more, nothing less. If that sounds like a good time to you; if you enjoy purely mechanical, incredibly designed puzzles placed into a pretty scenery that means absolutely nothing outside of its mechanical purposes; you will love this game.

If you want a story; a purpose for solving puzzles, then you will come out of this disappointed and with a feeling like you've wasted your time.

In all seriousness, though, there are some standout moments where I genuinely thought "That's clever" but you return very quickly to the relative tedium of endless grid puzzles. I like puzzles, but wouldn't say I love them enough to do hour after hour, so naturally I accidentally discovered the "a-ha" moment everyone is talking about, nice and early, because such a beautiful environment begs exploring which seems at odds with what the game mostly involves.

There's clearly two games here; one is a puzzle-solving masterpiece, which is sadly sullied by a somewhat tedious, pretentious and disappointing exploration game, even if rendered beautifully.

Again, if you prize puzzles, buy it. It deserves the praise on that front. Otherwise, just watch some videos about it, get the gist, and you will basically have seen it all. Best of luck!

This game is like a cryptic crossword.  You need to know the rules of the clues, and you need to apply those rules to complete the puzzle.  If you're not in the same mind set as a cryptic crossword setter, you struggle intensely.   If you're familiar with the setter and the types of clues they use, then its a fun and enjoyable challenge.

Needless to say I do not share the same mindset as the puzzle creators.  

Could I have earned the intense satisfaction of figuring out the rules of the puzzles on my own like many other have?  Maybe...but I have limited time which is disappointing because I'm good at puzzles so this should have been my kind of thing.

I needed an easier on-ramp because the change in difficulty was far, far, too rapid. 

p.s. I also had a lot more success halfway through when I started screen shotting puzzles to figuring them out on MSpaint, rather than purely visualising in my mind.  I think the game might have been better by taking notes as well.


Edit:  I would also say some of the audio files made me cringe intensely.

This game is an inspiration to many, many other fantastic puzzle games. It's game design and concepts should be studied and emulated (mostly). The puzzles are interesting and fair (mostly), the environments are pretty. And it has one of the single, greatest AHA moments that truly changes how you see the game.

So why do I not recommend it. Because I truly feel like it doesn't respect you or your time, and that AHA moment quickly became the most tedious part of the game, which ruins it in hindsight. Look, you play a puzzle game for the puzzles, and that's what this is. Just puzzles. You learn the rules in different areas, exploring and backtracking as the only limit is your own knowledge. Truly, that's where the game shines, and that's what other developers should take from it (like Taiji.)

The problem is my expectations, where it felt like it was teasing more. A hidden story to unlock if you only solve just a few more puzzles. The areas were so interesting, so much environmental story telling, and yet, looking back, there was no story to tell. Audio logs drone on while you wait for baited breath to figure out why you were listening to it to begin with. And yet, in the end, *Spoilers* it's just a dream. 

The game wants you to think about Perspectives. And it does this well. But man, screw those audio logs. Screw the "puzzle" that had you actively wait (I mean, you can't do anything else) for an HOUR of tracing. Screw THAT audio puzzle (you know the one). Screw every slow moving boat, or bridge, or door, or elevator, or windmill that ate my life away 30 seconds at a time. Doors unlock to nowhere after long puzzle chains with no reward besides finishing the puzzles themselves. It just feels pretentious,  much like this review. Strip it all away and you've got a great puzzle game in a pretty environment. Just, don't focus on anything else.

The Witness is a game I find myself returning to and thinking about over and over again as the years go by. It's the kind of game anyone who wants to make games (particularly narrative and systems designers) should try out, to see what it looks like when a game does an extremely good job of communicating exclusively through mechanics.

Is it perfect? Nah. Some puzzles are a little too obtuse for their own good. (There's a section involving trees and shadows where it feels like the purpose of the game goes from "deduce the answer" to "psychically intuit the mechanic, which may violate previously established rules", which I didn't love.)

But the beauty and depth of what it achieves is just wonderful. The place my brain goes when playing this game is a place I wish more games would take me. A puzzle game where the puzzle is deductive reasoning happening inside your brain, rather than, say, turning a bunch of switches in a pump room or whatever nonsense.

I'm a story and experience driven player first and foremost. If the designers of this game and I were in a room discussing games, I think we would have radically different philosophies. But this game feels like the clearest possible articulation of that design-purist, mechanics-first approach. I love it BECAUSE it's so quietly insistent in its approach. It feels like having a conversation with a very zen teacher who is gentle in their methods, yet merciless in refusing to give you the answer and demanding you learn to be brilliant.

I think it's a game everyone should play at least once.

[h1] What you see is what you get. [/h1]

Every "puzzle" in this game revolves around the same concept, connecting lines in a way that follows the puzzles' very specific set of rules. Sure, some of the puzzles can be unique in how they're solved, but most of them utilize symbols in a way that requires you to learn what each of them means and how to solve around them. They're introduced little by little as you explore the island, sometimes throwing in other symbols or mechanics to spice things up. But inevitably, you'll come across a puzzle you can't solve yet because you don't know how a symbol works. So then, you'll explore the island a bit, until you come to a different set of puzzles to solve, until the cycle repeats. This is why I stopped playing, because of repetitive game-play that caused me to run around in circles wondering what I was supposed to do, not wanting to look at a guide.

[h2] TL;DR: The Game is good, if you have the patience to follow the game's logic. I didn't. [/h2]

This game is not for everyone.  If you don't like experimental weird shit games, don't get it.  

The Witness is hard to describe.  A large open world that you wander around in solving puzzles.  Why do you solve the puzzles?  Some times you can see that they lead to something, some times you do them because, well, this is a puzzle game and you found a puzzle.  The entire game is built upon a slowly increasing knowledge base, where you solve an extremely simple puzzle, then a slightly more complex one, until you learn the rules of that type of puzzle.  You might need to look at the puzzles from different angles, or listen carefully to sounds, but you can't even carry objects so don't worry about fetch quests.   Every puzzle in the game is totally self contained, once you understand the rules.  Like a Myst game, keeping a notebook is a must.  It has no characters in the traditional sense.  No big face slaps of "I AM TEACHING YOU PHILOSOPHY" like The Talos Principle. But it has strong theme, expression, and intent. 

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Dear god the motion sickness.  I don't get motion sickness from games, but hooooooly crap did I have to stop playing this multiple times because it made me sick.  This is especially true with some of the very late game puzzles.  The worst part of the game by far for me.

-Difficulty that can be frustrating.  Almost nothing in the game is difficult in the traditional sense.  What makes the game hard is figuring out the rules, and if you don't know a rule it becomes next to impossible.  Figuring out some of them can be a challenge.

-Nothing is explained in the traditional sense.  The reviews that say there are no tutorials are wrong; the entire game is a giant set of tutorials.  But you need to pay attention to every thing you do, in every puzzle, and what it means.  Woe to you if you didn't write down your discoveries. 

-It's slow.  Think Myst, if you played that back in the day.  Moving through spaces, exploring them, piecing together from the environment what you are supposed to even do there, if anything.  

[b]Pros:[/b]
-Do you like learning through doing, rather than having something explained to you?  That's the game.  That's literally the entire game.  And I mean it.  It is 30+ hours of tinkering and experimenting and [i]OH SHIT I GET IT![/i] moments where suddenly 3 of the puzzles you left behind, stuck, suddenly make sense and are child's play.  Along each of those you will discover something else and another puzzle you couldn't figure out just clicks into place.  Or maybe what you discover is a puzzle you didn't even realize was there, but you were staring at the whole time! [b]And you get lost in it.[/b]

-It's beautiful.  Incredible art direction with layers and layers and layers.

-It has a hard to quantify human "art feel".  The frustrations, and the journey.  The realizations about the game and about yourself.  It'll do things to you that suck, and it'll do things to you that are wonderful.  When I beat one of the endings I literally had to stand up and walk away from my computer. 


[b]A few ending notes[/b]
Looking up almost anything immediately breaks the game.  This can be extremely hard to deal with in a context where the answer to not understanding something is to just look it up.  A few times in the game I "solved" things a bit faster than the game intended and had to slog through a dozen puzzles of ramping difficulty.  If you just look up how a mechanic works, all you're doing is slogging through puzzles that take longer to walk between than to solve.  There are multiple endings, and at some point you will probably want to look up some of that because... Well, you probably will.  I can't tell you if that is the right or the wrong move.  It will make a radical impact on your entire game experience though, and I'm not sure which way is better. 

Do I recommend?  For me, yes.  I also know people that would hate it, and I totally understand why.

[h1]This game just devolved into rubbish as I played[/h1]

As a fan of The Talos Principle, I thought this game might be worth a shot, seeing as it looked like you needed to use your brain, and I enjoy a good puzzle.

Sadly, the game seems hurried, unfinished, and - stupidly - unbeatable.

The core game seems fine on the surface. Beautiful colours, a nice range of varied scenery, a variety of puzzles for you to figure out. Now this is where my internal alarm went off, but I ignored it. No tutorial at all can be refreshing, and a welcome breath of fresh air compared to so many games out there that take the concept too far, but in this instance, it would have been nice to have something. I wonder how many other people had to look up the triangles rule...

Later, I noticed other things. Some puzzles relied on an audio cue to let you know how to solve them. Unfortunately, the trigger for these is too broad - so when you have 4 puzzles side-by-side, all the 4 individual audio cues play at once. It's a right mess of tangled frustration.

And the game really likes to smash you over the head with the frustration hammer. When you think you've finally got somewhere, getting into the challenge area, you'll be happy to know there is a veritable GAUNTLET of randomised puzzles you have to solve in the tiniest amount of time. It works by starting some music, and if you aren't done before it finishes, the whole lot resets. This is fine, I have no problem with this, but here's the kicker - puzzles that are meant to be solvable often load up as impossible puzzles! So you waste time, fail, retry, fail, retry, fail retry fail failtry... you get the picture. And 99% of the time it isn't your fault. 

Now, it's true, there is a section in that timed bit that DOES have impossible puzzles. But 1 out of 3 should be solvable, followed by another 1 out of 3 should be solvable. What I'm talking about are the rest of the timed puzzles, before you even get up to that. In between laughing so hard I'm in hysterics, and gasping for oxygen, and wiping my eyes clear of laughter tears, I have to say you can't even look up a guide to help you, as it is randomised. So you're stuck with unbeatable puzzles. 


Sure, they've tried to pretty it up with audio files and videos that make you question reality, or try to read your future in a bowl of alphabet soup, but the reality is the game is broken, so collecting the audio files seems kinda redundant.

If you want a puzzle game that you can actually finish, I recommend Talos Principle. Until this game gets a patch to fix the random fail element I'm not touching it with a ten-foot barge pole.

The game is fantastic. Pretty visuals, clever puzzles. 
Right from the beginning you can basically explore freely. Each area can be solved. Just do what you can, you can always come back to things later. Look at things from multiple angles. Most puzzles (except for some easter eggs) are very fair.

It's like playing a voxel-realised CYAN Worlds game, only because it's voxels instead of pixels, it's all 3D-modelled and bright and relaxing. The puzzles are both as intuitive and as occasionally frustrating as you might expect, and it goes in WAY DEEP on the sliding maze puzzle locks, but it's also a real walk-around-and-click-on-everything-you-can sojourns, so get your comfy hiking shoes on, first.

Absolute masterpiece.

The way that the very simple puzzles are slowly built up into something mind-twistingly complex is done in such a masterful way. And once you discover the [spoiler] puzzles hidden in the environment itself [/spoiler] it will totally blow your mind on yet another level! The art style is simple, yet beautifully done, with each "zone" having a distinct look and feel.

In a genre containing many excellent peers (The Talos Principle, Anti-Chamber, The Swapper - to name a few), The Witness somehow stands out head and shoulders above them.

[h1] The game is in the wrong category. Over half of is not a puzzle game. [/h1]

Let's see the type of fake puzzles you will find in this game:

1. [b]Draw a line.[/b] Trace the line you see. This isn't a puzzle. This is the only mechanic in 3/14 areas. (not counting the tutorial)

2. [b]Perspective.[/b] Generally the same thing as above, but you just need to walk around to find the perspective. This is the only mechanic in 5/14 areas.

3. [b]Screenshot puzzles.[/b] Usually scattered around the island, but mainly used in the end area of the game. Might be connected to actual puzzles, but you have to solve them in photo editing software, because the puzzles are disconnected between multiple areas or are otherwise a pain to look at.

4. [b]Arbitrary developer decision puzzle[/b]. The sound puzzles uses [i]"small = low pitch"[/i] but [i]"up = high pitch"[/i], and one of the tree puzzles uses [i]"forward = down"[/i]. Figuring out how the mindset of the developer affects these things is not a puzzle. 

These 4 types of areas consist of 10/15 areas without any actual puzzles. That's two thirds of the game.

[h1]  What about the other areas? Are the puzzles in them good? [/h1]

[b]Yea.[/b] 

But you're paying for 10 areas filled with no puzzles. Okay that's kind of unfair, the castle and the endgame both have a few actual puzzles, so you could count the final score as 8/15 areas. But that's still over half of the game.

So yeah, Want to buy this game? Wait for at least 50% sale.

This is probably my favorite game of all time.

Note that time spent is not accurate. (I own and have played it on numerous platforms.)

Maybe this was made with autistic people in mind and/or the lead developer is autistic—the game's world is full of special shapes and there's even an optional in-game mechanic of tracing them. While spotting patterns in the environment isn't something I normally ever do myself, I had fun looking for them in this game. Never played a game with such a mechanic before.

The puzzles are appropriately challenging. Unlike Baba Is You, which is very much a brain-melting puzzle game (that's not really a complaint though), I barely had to look anything up in The Witness.

This game is amazing, and quite the experience. The first thing I wanted to do after I beat it was play it again. It can be frustrating at times but it's all worth it for what I can only describe as a spiritual experience. Easily my favorite game of all time and definitely one I'd recommend playing, but only if you like puzzles or thinking, otherwise you may have a really bad time with things.

Previous puzzles were easily understandable, for example, [spoiler]separation of colors, or the reflection of the sun on the screens, or rocks in the background indicating a solution[/spoiler].

The straw that broke the camel's back were two puzzles right next to each other at the very edge of the area.
[spoiler]The puzzle in the left has squares with figures in black and white. These figures do not interact like other b/w figures, since they have different shapes. Since separation isn't the answer this time, what is the answer? It turns out, you have to separate each type by two, so now the colors can blend, but they have to be two of each color for it to work. 
The puzzle in the right is one seen before in the same area, which I already had problems with before. Previously, you are supposed to form a specific shape based on the tiny shapes inside, but it wasn't necessary to form the shape around where the tiny one was. That's something already not very intuitive (I feel like you can tell because you wouldn't understand the previous sentence without playing the game), but with the brand new puzzle, one of the tiny shapes has a 22 degree angle. What does this mean? It means that the slightly modified shape can be rotated.[/spoiler]

To summarize, when a puzzle game stumps me, I should think "wow, I am very dumb" if I have a moment of weakness and check a Walk-through, not "I was never going to figure that one out." And this problem only appears when a new mechanic is introduced, with the puzzle that's supposed to be easy to understand in order to increase the difficulty for that mechanic. 

I don't think it's a "gitgud" issue, because I've played plenty of puzzle games and enjoyed them.
Manifold Garden was instantly more understandable despite it having an out-of-the-box idea and conveying less information due to its minimalist art-style.
I had the same problem of misunderstandings with Superliminal, but it didn't happen in every single puzzle in one area.

If you get easily frustrated with puzzle games, this is definitely not the game for you.

On the one hand, the puzzles are clever, the setting is gorgeous and a delight to explore, and there's a Cool Thing the game does that is unique and magical when you stumble across it. 

On the other, the game is pretentious in the worst ways. It makes a huge deal out of the idea that "different perspectives can let you perceive the world in new ways," and in terms of the Cool Thing, it works well in that respect. But for a game littered with audio logs, both, it sure does focus almost exclusively on white western perspectives. The audio logs have no real context; you might as well just play any other puzzle game while having an Inspirational Quotes website open in a browser.

There are multiple videos to unlock of various lectures, and wow, it's all white people sharing western perspectives. There was nothing in this game that made me feel challenged or like I had a new way of seeing the world. Want to hear about Buddhism from an actual Buddhist? Too bad. What you get instead is a white lady's take on a white man's take on Buddhism. Want to hear about Zen? Okay, here are two quotes, one from a white British guy, and the other from... the same white British guy. How about an interesting indigenous take? Nope! Here's some more high school level Western philosophy instead! Cool. It sucks. 

It feels like Jonathan Blow had the opportunity to elevate some actual unique perspectives on the world, but went with the safest, most boring options possible. A tip of the hat to the most mainstream Eastern philosophies, with absolutely no effort to bring in anything actually different. What an absolute waste of an opportunity.

Great puzzles, beautiful setting. Shame the rest of the game is as shallow as can possibly be. I wish Jonathan Blow was as curious as he is clever.

Oh man, I loved this game. I have to write this positive review because I don't understand the hate towards this game that I see everywhere.

The Witness is an open-world puzzle game.

Before playing the game, I think it's crucial to understand the puzzle-solving system: In this game, there are no hints, no clues, and obviously, no explanations about the puzzles you need to solve. To help players understand the different puzzle rules, the game offers 'tutorial' areas, introducing rules gradually so players can learn step by step. What makes the game interesting is that you might encounter a theoretically solvable area, but it becomes impossible without having been previously through these 'tutorial' zones. This creates a desire to keep going, a curiosity to learn all the rules to complete and solve the toughest puzzles. Many players disliked this game for these reasons: limited explanations and an increasing difficulty curve of the puzzles. It's not recommended to play this game if you're not a puzzle game enthusiast.

[u]SPOILER:[/u]
The game becomes more intriguing with its visual and audio aspects. The graphics are beautiful but almost too perfect. The sound is minimal, consisting of just footsteps and puzzle success or failure sounds, making the game feel cold and empty. To balance this, while exploring the island, you can find many graphical Easter eggs and audio logs from philosophers and scientists, promising an intriguing story. However, when you put it all together, you may end up with nothing. 
Some find it confusing, considering it a mishmash of pseudo-profound nonsense. 

I won't claim to have understood every nuance of the game, but by listening to audio logs and watching mini-films in the game, I think that people who complain for the reasons i said earlier totally missed out on one of the conclusions of the game: Life/this game should be a zen experience where you find contentment in simple things, like visuals, landscapes, and yourself. On the other hand, the game presents us with scientists encouraging us to understand the world around us, to seek explanations, to ask for help in understanding a bit more about what surrounds us every day. This can even be translated into the game by seeking solutions to solve puzzles that seem too difficult and impossible. The game point out that no one holds the universal truth of life and, consequently, of the game. It's all about finding a balance between an approach to life indulging in zenitude and the desire to seek explanations.

Yea... Actually, they were right. It's a mishmash of pseudo-profound nonsense, [u] just like life. [/u]

The puzzles start out fine, if frequently tedious (and the walking even more so). And I could have looked past some of the puzzles being more trial-and-error in your own position than any actual puzzle. But as someone who is red-green colorblind, hitting puzzles that are actually impossible to do because the colors are indistinguishable, with no color blind option, is frustrating. Even more frustrating is that the dev is explicitly uninterested in implementing any level of accessibility options, even for basic puzzles where something as simple as including a pattern, or adding an option to change the color schema would work just as well. And it sounds like that extends to other disabilities as well - there are auditory puzzles which have no accessibility options or aides available for users who have hearing problems. 

Even before running into these issues, this wasn't a game that was engaging - the amount of time spent slowly walking around the map and "solving" a basic puzzle a dozen times made it hard to be the only thing to focus on for me and more of something to do while watching YouTube - and it's certainly not worth $40.

I've been playing this game since 2016 – yes, I'm one of those who have played this game for the longest time – and only now have I decided to finally finish it (of course, there were long periods when I just put this game aside).

I like the visuals and the puzzles. However, in my view, the environmental puzzles are the weakest part of this game. They don't require logic; instead, they demand a keen eye and pixel hunting, which quickly becomes tedious. In my opinion, the author is a very talented person, but he failed to realize the difference between SOLVING and SEARCHING. Searching and pixel hunting quickly become boring and tiring. I'm a big fan of puzzle games, but there's a limit to how much time I'm willing to invest in a game. The Witness requires an excessive amount of meticulous exploring and peering into the landscape if you aim to complete it 100%.

So, here's my advice for all newcomers to the game: try the minimal walkthrough on your own (you can finish the game without completing all puzzles), and resort to guides if you aim to finish it 100%. This approach will unveil some interesting endings and game content. Trust me – it doesn't make sense to finish it 100% on your own because it will take an enormous amount of time on average. Plus, you will clearly see (if you follow the guides on environmental puzzles) how much time a puzzle would have taken you if you attempted it on your own.

To sum it up – overall, I like this game; perhaps only Myst surpasses it. But what I don't appreciate is that it becomes tedious at some point, and we, as human beings, just don't like to hit our head against the wall without making any progress. Being unable to solve a puzzle doesn't make you stupid; spending hours and days trying to solve a puzzle that you cannot solve does.

The Witness is one of the weirder puzzle games I've played. Because the core mechanic is solving 2D mazes on screens, many of the puzzles don't seem to warrant the overarching 3D world they exist in, feeling as if they'd be more at home in a normal puzzle game. Specifically, the majority of the non-environmental puzzles didn't feel like anything special, as all I was tasked with doing was coming up with a solution for the maze I was presented with.

Where the game does shine, is with the environmental puzzles. To avoid spoilers for anyone who has yet to play the game, environmental puzzles require the use of information not directly present on the 2D maze screen to solve the maze, and it is these puzzles which justify the game's first-person perspective within a 3D world.

Unfortunately, not all environmental puzzles are good. Specifically, I found the jungle audio puzzles to be miserable, having given me a literal headache when solving (from the audio, not the puzzle difficulty). Additionally, I found the shipwreck puzzle to be uniquely awful in a way that would be damning for the game as a whole, if it were not an optional side puzzle (though I wish the game made that clearer to the player, so they would wisely be able to avoid it).

Regarding story, I can't say I had any idea what was meant to be going on, nor did I understand the ending. The audio logs and video clips inserted in the game seemed out-of-place, but they could easily be skipped if you weren't interested in them. Unfortunately, if you don't care for the video clips, there is no reward for completing many optional side puzzles (including the aforementioned shipwreck puzzle).

Still, I found the game quite fun overall--at least, as far as completing the main game and the 'challenge'. Beyond that point, there still remained quite a few bonus or secret puzzles, but I was struck with a lack of motivation as for why I'd choose to hunt them down. The game doesn't really reward you at all for completing puzzles (beyond unlocking more puzzles), so any enjoyment here will come from intrinsic motivation in accordance with the satisfaction of solving intriguing puzzles, and once it wears out, your time with the Witness has come to a close.

The world they built was interesting and it's a cool idea, but the puzzles continue to just be gruesome. Not even that they're super difficult, it's just that they aren't fun to solve. I love puzzle games, but the solve needs to be satisfying. I tried to like it, but couldn't.  If you look at the trailer and think the game looks cool but I'm not sure about just moving lines on a grid, trust your gut. No part of this is fun.
Dont read spoilers, (its probably too late, but dont!)

"I make my games intentionally less fun than they could be as to not distract from what they are about.", paraphrasing the lead creator Jonathan Blow.
That is like baking oatmeal cookies. We could have made tasty and healthy cookies, but we really didn't want you to miss the fact that they are healthy, so who cares if it feels like chewing sand sometimes? This game is definitely healthy and more impressively, intentionally so. 

The main mechanic in this game is choosing which line to retrace in the little mazes and you navigate a 3D environment to go from puzzle to puzzle. Now I was worried to fall of some narrower spaces while walking until I realized you can't, as the game in the most abstract, is like it is in it's most concrete, even while walking you retrace one of many lines in a maze.

That self-reflecting is present at each layer, in the small the medium the big, even on an emotional layer. I am not here to judge whether or not The Witness should be called a piece of art, but it definitely is an art piece. It wants to be, and proves it is, at least to those, to whom the twist in the game mechanics reveals itself.

Speaking about that twist, you either fall into one of 3 categories:
A.)You intuitively understand
B.)It reveals itself to you
C.)You miss it

Interestingly, if you fall in category A or C, you are left with [u]just[/u] a puzzle game, or so I thought. For me it was looking at THE tree, that helped me reconnect to my childhood. If you miss it, but you like puzzle games, I am sure this still is relaxing to you and you can finish the game without ever understanding what it is about.

About the puzzles and their difficulty: The game does not talk. If it could, it would repeatedly utter: "Pay attention! Do you understand?". The first time playing I got stuck here and there. Let's say you have 5 puzzles in a row. I expected them to get more difficult, so when I was stuck on puzzle 4 I went somewhere else in the world. Now I see that the puzzles don't get more difficult, they repeat "Pay attention! Do you understand?". There is a reason why puzzles 1,2 and 3 were 1,2 and 3.

You ought to pay attention, until you understand.

Like Kentucky Route Zero did, I think The Witness accomplishes what very few games have done over the past years, at least for me: transcend what is considered a canonical adventure and reinvent narration and engagement. 

This is just a puzzle game. However, how puzzles are solved and how you approach to its logics are things that are deeply connected to your personal experiences and perception. In synthesis, it is just a game about connecting lines. But the never ending shades of puzzle designs that intertwine between these simple starting and ending points are so well constructed and so exhaustive that they will make you feel like some sort of human algorithm trying to solve problems over and over again. A machine, or something along those lines.

I think that if you want the definitive puzzle experience, something to push you out of your comfort zone, something that lets you rethink the way you approach obstacles, you will love The Witness. I don't really want to say more about it, other than the fact that it really is the game of life. Literally.

The only real side effect is that you will eventually go insane and will start seeing patterns everywhere. Nothing's perfect, I guess.

I know a decent amount of people will really like this game, but I can't stand it.  It mostly comes down to the fact that I don't like line puzzles, and this is nothing but that.  I'm fine with them for a little bit, but by the time I solve one area's puzzles, I'm so done.  I don't feel excited when I solve one, I'm just relieved that it's over, but then I remember there's just more line puzzles and I get frustrated.

It makes me wonder how much is just on my preferences, and how much is on the game.  Is it my fault for getting bored after the 20th line puzzle?  Should the game use more than 1 type of puzzle (it has many approaches to line puzzles, but they're still ultimately line puzzles)?  The answer may differ from person to person, but personally think the game could do more to stay interesting.

This is the first game I have actively deleted from my steam library.

I would recommend the game The Looker though.

I've never come so close to ripping hairs out and uninstalling a puzzle game for becoming so frustrating, and there's no way I could have completed this game without the help of guides. I'm not a violent person but I've got a knuckle sandwich for whoever designed the moving puzzles in the mountain. Nonetheless I got satisfaction from the different biomes and figuring out some things on my own. Beautiful artwork and atmosphere.

Positive: 
- Very peaceful and imaginative open world with beautiful Colors.  
- Interesting puzzles in a wide range of difficulty.  
- Controls are simple.  
- AutoSaves are often and work well. 
- Playing time is much longer than expected. 
- Memorable in many ways.  

 
Negative: 
- Lack of instructions. Clues and lessons are presented but you are completely on your own with no real sense of direction. 
- The game often breaks its own rules. It presents you with a formula but may not always work the way it’s presented. 
- There is no difficulty settings. 
- Sometimes the only way to solve a puzzle is through guessing which is not based on rules or logic.  
- Sometimes you must solve a previous puzzle again because you made an error on the current one. 
- Some puzzles have very low visibility.  
- Spinning and flashing can be an issue for some. *Only on the final stage of the game. 
- Once you end the game you lose all end progress. You must go back to the previous save before the final stage. 

 
Conclusion: 

The Witness opens on a vibrant and wonderful island full of bold color and intriguing scenery. It really provides inspiration to explore. It felt so laid back and peaceful and despite not having music the sound effects were sufficient to create a pleasing atmosphere.  

My hopes and dreams of completing this game were rudely interrupted when I came to the realization that the execution of the games design is a little chaotic.  

Some solutions are not based on logic or rules but chance alone. Low visibility was also a major factor in a few of the puzzles *not sure it’s just me. It honestly felt like you needed the eyes of a hawk and wit of Master Splinter to advance. I commend those that finished the game with no help.  

If only they could have perhaps had a plot or better sense of direction. Perhaps a difficulty setting to match one's ability or mood. 

Overall, The Witness provides brilliant concepts and detail which evoke mystery, thought and ultimately reward. The puzzles were not the star of the show, but the fashion in which they were presented. Marvellous A+ 

 

RECOMMENDED   8/10

The Good: the music in this game is indescribably epic. 

The Bad: only people with IQ higher than 369 are able to hear it. 


But seriously -- the game was a letdown. Many of the puzzles are satisfying, but the later ones are punishingly difficult. On the one hand, it's true, the difficulty can correlate to the player's intelligence / observation skill, so that's fair. On the other hand, many of the puzzles' intended solutions are actually, objectively ambiguous, like [spoiler]tracing the columns in the distance on the transparent panels[/spoiler], or [spoiler]following some of the audio tones[/spoiler]. Even after I went online for some of the solutions, I still couldn't back-trace the logic of the alleged solutions and how one would arrive at them, which says that the puzzles are structured poorly. If the challenge of the game comes from poor game design, that's a big strike against the game. 

In the course of exploring the island, the player will find audio recordings reading random, apparently unrelated to anything, quotes. Some of these are short and saccharine, while others drone on and on. This reminds me of a very similar game ("The Talos Principle") which I would describe as a clone of this one (or the other way around, I'm not sure which was more original). But while the wannabe-big-brain quotes and notes in "The Talos Principle" had some bearing on the setting and exposition in that game, the quotes in "The Witness" don't really relate to or explain anything. It's like someone checked out "Ye Olde Booke Of Smarte Quotes" from the local library and blindly picked a dozen of them to be shoehorned into the game for no reason. 

The "secret video codes" which you find show people talking about such inane, sophistic, pseudo-philosophical nonsense that, after finding and watching one, I couldn't be compelled to watch the rest. Since your character can't leave the room where the video projector is to explore other things, this is basically an exercise in wasting time to watch pop-scientists smell their own farts. 

I honestly do like the visuals in the game, however. The colors and shading are very well done, and the sea / waves move realistically. There is some nice exploration to be had, which is satisfying when the puzzles make sense and "click". The way the game starts "live", bringing the player right into the game without any introduction or main menu even... I think that's pretty immersive and original. This mechanic works great for a game of this genre. 

Overall, I think the game is not very well made. Regarding the price -- $40 is beaucoup money for a game which, let's face it, few people will be able to beat without eventually searching online for solutions. So if one solves the puzzles he can, and looks up solutions to the rest, he'll get, maybe, six hours of gameplay for $40 (and not all of them will be pleasant hours, with several hours spent in frustration). This isn't worth the money, and is not the best use of time, in my view.

If there's one word I would use to describe The Witness, it would be "pretentious".

Coming from someone who's well-versed in games similar to it, be it puzzles or walking or atmospheric, this is clearly the worst option you could pick up. You've got Portal 1+2, two incredible games that introduce puzzles at a gradual pace with a great atmosphere and story. You've got The Talos Principle 1+2, two of my favorite games, especially with the DLC and its grandiose tone and setting. Then you've got The Witness. It has none of that.

The community has several puzzle types that have been bruteforced because they are [i] literally impossible to solve using context clues. [/i] There are puzzles in this game that break the conventional rules and understanding of what you've learned. And you can go to them all out of order. You can literally go to the most difficult portion of the map, instantly, and find yourself struggling to understand anything about what's happening beyond "oh, there's lines".

The ONE cool moment in this game was finding out about the hidden game mechanic that lets you draw lines across the actual environment. And while that's neat, there is no incentive or reasoning to do this and find the perfect angle or solution to a random puzzle.

Believe me, I enjoy games with AND without a point or clear direction. But this game almost revels in its mediocrity. It throws concepts and ideas at you and doesn't care if they are meaningful, they are just *there*. That, and the secret ending is pretty fucking bad.

Fuck you, Jonathan Blow.

For games that I think show the potential of that, I'd rather recommend titles such as Anodyne 2 and The Magic Circle, both of which feature well written original narratives rather than outsourcing their artistry to quotations of supposedly important words uttered by equally important people. This is the video game equivalent of spending a weekend without the internet.
You have an intricately sculpted island full of puzzles, you have your two legs, that's it.
No fast travel. No minimap. You're forced to navigate by memory and take in the gorgeous scenery.

Having completed this game without external help, I can confidently say that every puzzle is entirely solveable if you're willing take your time and listen for what the game is trying to tell you. Puzzles teach you their rules without as much as a single word being spoken, meaning it's your own responsibility to figure out and formalise the patterns.
Something you learn right out of the starting area is that you WILL come across puzzles that are out of your grasp, that have rules you simply have not learned yet. The lesson here is that making a mental note and coming back later with a new perspective is part of the game.
There are a few puzzles (two specifically) so obtuse, they had me trying for up to an hour only to give up, which at the time felt frustrating, but only because I failed to implement what the game had taught me:
When at a loss, leave and come back later!

The Witness is not a game that entertains you, nor is it a puzzle to be solved. The Witness is an experience made by passionate people, and if you want to hear what they have to share, you have to play by their rules. In practice, that means patience. A lot of it. Sometimes, getting a puzzle wrong means having to solve the previous one again, telling you "hey, you're not meant to blindly guess, you're meant to think this through". Taking notes is sometimes practically required, which to me only adds to the immersion.

Another beautiful aspect is how the game has no unlocks or progression outside of your knowledge. Every puzzle can be solved from the very start, given you understand their rules. This makes spoilers a serious hindrance to the spirit of the game, and only your first playthrough will capture the magic of discovery. The silver lining is that speedruns of the game are wild to watch.

I had a blast. If what I'm describing sounds in any way appealing to you, I strongly suggest you give the game a go.

Then when you feel like you have beaten the game, but you have an achievement remaining, you haven't. Then the difficulty really ramps up for the last (optional) challenges.

There are 2 types of puzzle games.

One type is, you know the rules and you are just trying to solve the puzzle at hand. Sudoku, Wordle, Crossword are non video game examples. Most of the "puzzle" games are quite like that. Rules are simple and provided to you by like reading or tutorials. Tbh, that's kinda boring. Yea, I get it, do I really have to spend 15 minutes executing it?

The other type is, you don't know the rules and you are thrown into the game. The game is now like a fantastic universe that you don't know how it works, and through logic, awareness, perception and deduction; you figure it out. Then, solving the puzzle at hand takes a few seconds. That feeling makes you feel smart, it's extremely entertaining. Examples include: Antichamber, Myst, Riven.

This game is, well, both of them, but the best parts are made of the second part, because it is not just limited to "puzzles", but they somehow interract with other things in a smart way. Now, you are not just solving a puzzle, you are experiencing what universe you are in. That feeling when you realize what things are, is great.

The Witness is a game I have really mixed feelings about.

[h3] The good [/h3]
What first grabbed my attention and was ultimately one of the reasons I bought this game was how beautiful it looked. The island - extremely diverse and meticulously designed, with its vibrant colour palette and low-poly (?) art style - is truly stunning and a joy to wander about.

There's many types of puzzles, most of which follow the same formula, i.e. require you to draw a correct pattern on a grid board, but due to the level of complexity they reach later on the gameplay never quite gets boring or tedious. They are challenging but (mostly) logical. There are some exceptions to that, probably the most ridiculous one being the [spoiler] sound puzzle which tests whether or not you're tone-deaf and how clearly you can hear when someone repeatedly bangs pots and pans right next to you [/spoiler]. Sometimes a task would be artificially made more difficult than it really was, e.g. a background/squares in a colour-based puzzle would repeatedly flash and change colours, subjecting the player to epilepsy.

There's no actual story but when you explore the island, you stumble upon physical signs signifying some mystery surrounding it. Scattered all over the map there are also audio logs containing quotes from significant historical figures. All that makes you think there's more to this game than meets the eye...

[h3] The bad [/h3]
...but apparently there's not. Or maybe there is. The thing is, whatever Jon Blow wanted to convey is so muddled and vague that he may as well have sticked to puzzles. What we got here is a ubiquitous sense of some big secret and a bunch of disjointed hints that ultimately lead nowhere. 

The quotes he had decided to use - quotes from great thinkers, mind you, such as Einstein, Tagore or Feynman - are devoid of all the wisdom I'm pretty sure they have in context because... they're stripped of one. They don't gain new meaning (unlike in a game like Talos Principle where different ideas are put in a proper framework) and instead come off as a non-sensical, pretentious, unbearable and laughable babble. This effect is further amplified by the stereotypically philosophical tone they're delivered in. Don't even get me started on [spoiler] the secret videos that are more of the same but longer. [/spoiler]

[h3] The conclusion [/h3]
It seems to me that Blow (just like with Braid) wanted to keep things as unclear as possible and to me, whatever his true intent was, that's just a sign of incompetence.

Overall, it's a decent game. Usually, that wouldn't be a sufficient reason for me to recommend it but despite its severe shortcomings in some areas, it excels in others and that's why I think it deserves to be experienced first-hand.

Video games have a unique artistic potential. For music, for plays, for books, they have typically been seen as extensions of the other. "All art aspires to the condition of music" because music was seen as the most experiential of the forms, unperturbed by the various structures and limitations placed on theatre and literature. Film, arguably, held the position upon it's realisation to challenge music. Where music was pure audio - and open to experimentation with the lack of a defined structure outside of time - film could occupy the same unstructured space in both audio AND visual.

The 20th century saw many revolutions in film. We went from live orchestra accompaniment to the evolution of the talkie. From the musicals of the immediate talkie era to surrealism of Fellini, Tarkovsky, right through to present day Lynch. True experimentation with the audio visual medium that arguably continues. Animation could be seen as a route to unlocking it, the merging of it with live action giving further potential. Some might argue the opposite, but the argument exists both ways and that is the point.

We pay extra to see live orchestra accompaniments now. To relive those early revolutionary days of film. Maybe that is the sign of some kind of limit being approached.

Video games are the great new medium of the 21st century. We are, in the 2010s and 2020s, in a similar manner to film in the 1910s and 1920s. Great works that stand the test of time are barely now being created. They are incredible compared to Pong and Tetris yes, but they are still starting points for games as art. Something like Baldurs Gate could be seen as something like Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans. But this is in the sense of narrative, scope, in becoming to film what film became to theatre. For gaming to become what film is to film, we have to go more foundationally.

Games are not experiential like film and music. Games are experience itself. They are fictional, yes, but so too is the daily experience of you and me. When you use your computer, you are using rocks with lightning passing through it. What makes it a computer is your experience of it. It only exists in your head, and the head of those who agree with you. The words on this screen become words only through your experience, otherwise it is light and plastic. Light and plastic, too, are simply arbitary groupings of real phenomena that help us further describe the world. What you go through in life is not reality itself but reality through a lense of fiction. With art, we create further fictions. With gaming, we can create the true experience of existing through them.

The Witness strips gaming down to this core fundamental. A simple circle and line, oft repeating, in various forms and puzzles. It is no mistake that it begins with simple puzzles on a screen - and make no mistake, this is not where the challenges end.

That is what The Witness is about. Not Tao Buddhism or anything like that, at it's core it is about the fundamental potential of video games as an art form - and it is it's own best example.

Yes, the art style is great. Yes, the atmosphere is brilliant. Yes, the challenges themselves - as they must - are fantastically inventive. But this is not what The Witness brings to the table that is new. Plenty of games challenge the greatest works of film, theatre, literature, music, and art itself in these aspects. The Witness attempts to warp your perception of reality itself in a simple manner, committed to with astonishing deliberateness, and in doing so unlock your view of gaming's potential to do just the same. If all experience is fiction, then the fictions you experience in gaming have the unique potential to carry through with you even after you stop playing.

In this, gaming can truly be life changing.

I do not know if video games will ever reach this potential. If they do, The Witness will be looked back on as the pioneer that started it all.

[b]If you're only here for the puzzles, you'll have a good time, since there's not much else to talk about with this game.[/b]

   {+}: [i]The aforementioned puzzles are well-designed and surprisingly varied for what appears to be a simple core concept. You learn the rules on the go, with the game letting you figure things out puzzle by puzzle in a way that I found highly enjoyable and engaging.[/i]
   {0}: [i]The overall look of the game is simple but functional, with some colorful areas.[/i]
   {-}: [i]The game seemingly teases a narrative that never actually materializes. This however, will also depend on your own expectations. If you come into the game with the understanding that there's no MYSTery to uncover, you probably won't have similar hangups to mine.[/i]

Overall, there are hundreds of puzzles with varying logics behind them that are worth experiencing if that's your focus. Despite my criticism about the lack of a narrative, I also still found it fun to meet the game where it is when it comes to additional content you can find while exploring. And it ends up having a small fun meta aspect that was fun to discover. Also, there's a boat you can ride in! How fun!

Oh, and don't worry. You don't need the extra achievement to get to the end. :D

I love Myst and Riven and all the Cyan World games. That love brought me to The Witness. 

At first, I was a little bored by the repetitive dot-to-line puzzles. I figured out a lot of them on my own, but I have been known to use a walk-through when I get too frustrated. The puzzles became tedious - I'm looking your way, tree-house - which cause me to abandon the game completely for almost a year. 

I will say that I DID thoroughly enjoy the shadow, reflection, and more interactive puzzles like changing water levels to reveal or hide puzzle pieces or walkways rising out of the marsh. The thrill of getting a puzzle right (like unlocking the double doors in the mountain) was exciting. The boat was pretty neat, as well, but  really only useful to get to the tree-house, unless you count the useless environmental puzzles.

Speaking of environmental puzzles, I didn't even realize they existed until I had unlocked most of my lasers. (I used a walk-through to get the tree-house finished and discovered how MANY puzzles were in this game - environmental, audio logs, discarded triangle puzzles, briefcases/the theater, and "the challenge.") 

SO I tried completing the game to 100%. I went back to each area for the "entry/town/glass factory obelisk" and the "symmetry island/windmill/solar temple obelisk" environmental puzzles, completing the discarded panels and audio logs along the way. Eventually I was like, "why am I doing this?" The extraneous puzzles have ZERO POINT to them, but to light things up in the lake. 

The story line is just "meh." The only audio log that I cared to listen to was the one on top of the mountain, where she describes the world around you being created to represent the world we, the players, know and love. The world and visuals are this games only saving grace. 

Overall, I think this game is worth it if it's on sale and you have a few weekends trapped in your house. It's interesting, and can be cool getting the lasers unlocked, but everything else about the game is repetitive, tedious, and pointless. The story line is convoluted. The main selling point of this game is the cool world the graphic designers created and, like, 20% of the puzzles.

It was really a great atmospheric game that felt lonely. You were doing the task of puzzles in the left out island and the reward upon your curiosity was nice. Didn't able to finish some puzzles because it was hard but nevertheless great game.

This is a wonderful puzzle game, and I am only about 1/5 way through it. The puzzles are really engaging and clever, and it's a fun island to walk around and observe! 
Don't be misled by your first impression of the puzzles in this game! Suffice to say, they are *not* merely self-contained maze-like puzzles, there is much more to it than that as you progress through the game. 

The one tip that I could find useful when starting this game is to explore the world and its puzzles *slowly*. Since it's an open-world game, it is very easy to rush through the map and find a very difficult puzzle that you haven't built up the skills for yet. To really enjoy the game go slowly and methodically over each area and tackle the easier groups of puzzles first, then after some time, try to go back to some of the isolated puzzles or puzzle-groups that you found difficult - they may not be so inscrutable after the experience you gained from solving puzzles in other areas.

I've been waiting to grab this game on sale and... the disappointment is immeasurable.

As others have said, there are interesting concepts with the puzzles both on board and environmental. You can see the care that has been put into crafting the different rules that you'll find across multiple locations/boards and how they interact together in more difficult scenarios. The island is beautiful with a screenshot worthy moment around every corner, but also feels too large to navigate quickly--[spoiler] even after you discover the boat[/spoiler]--when you want to revisit an area or explore.

However, the greatest problem for me is the core game play loop. After several hours, I just cannot bring myself to do the next puzzle. Not so much out of frustration, which I feel is a warranted complaint for some, but sheer indifference. I just don't get much of, if any, catharsis or excitement from solving what equates to a mobile game puzzle. Not to say there aren't some cool moments, there are (and they're almost exclusively the environmental puzzles), but why is the bulk of the game so bland?

Personally, this plays like a mobile puzzler with a nicely built world around it that has nothing truly interesting to say [spoiler](even with its notions of interpreting reality)[/spoiler] or challenge you with. The most perplexing thing about this game is its price tag, and the 85% rating it has at the time of review. Beyond explanation for me.

Edit: Its on the app store for 10 bucks, just buy it there
