There is a considerable amount of misunderstanding surrounding the description of this game. Many people see the grid puzzles on panels and assume that this is the essence of the gameplay. In this review, I aim to illuminate parts of the nature of the game, providing you with a clearer understanding before diving into it. There are no spoilers about the story.

Before delving into the review, it's worth briefly mentioning games such as The Talos Principle or Portal. These games follow a linear structure with intricate puzzles that are largely self-contained. Players can solve one puzzle today and return ten days later to tackle another, making the gameplay quite straightforward. The quality of these games predominantly hinges on the complexity and ingenuity of the puzzles. 

On the other hand, The Witness is clearly inspired by the Myst series and takes a quite unconventional approach that we aren't really used to. The journey starts with the character who has 'amnesia' and needs to explore an island to figure out what is going on.

[b]- Part 1: Intro -[/b]

The island is divided into multiple regions, each featuring a set of challenges grouped around a common theme. If the player encounters difficulty with a particular set, they have the flexibility to bypass it and explore other parts of the island. This design creates a highly non-linear experience and balances exploration with puzzle solving by allowing players to gradually expand their knowledge of the world and return to previously unsolved challenges. Importantly, players are not penalized for being unable to complete a puzzle; progress can still be made, and the game can be successfully completed even with many of them left unsolved.

Now, not all puzzles are easy to identify. The most common ones are found on panels of various forms within specific regions, typically grouped together and must be completed in a sequential order, with the complexity of the puzzles gradually increasing. Trial and error is employed for the simple challenges and logic is applied for the more complicated ones. This process aids the player in making sense of their rules. However, in some cases, the solution does not depend solely on the information presented on the panel, but on the environment as well. 

On the opposite end, there are also numerous hidden challenges that are not presented in the standard panel form and require from the player to interact with the environment in some way, offering a welcome break from the panel puzzle-solving monotony.

The game's story unfolds through scattered audio logs across the island. Instead of straightforwardly conveying the narrative to players, these logs are deliberately enigmatic, presenting the story as quotes from influential thinkers. The player will also come across a theater and watch video clips.

As we can see, The Witness isn't just a sequence of puzzles; rather, it features multiple layers of puzzles, suggesting a more complex and intricate structure to the gameplay.

[b]- Part 2: Bird's eye view -[/b]

So what type of game is The Witness? While solving the panel puzzles may seem pretty straightforward, discovering requires the player to slow down and be very observant of the surroundings. The audio logs are scattered randomly, and so are some panels. Many puzzles are hidden in plain sight, and there are also hidden rooms with extra puzzles. The more you play, the more you'll come across things that you missed because you weren't paying enough attention. Rest assured, there's a lot to discover, more than you could ever imagine. If you are stuck or frustrated, you are encouraged to take a break—perhaps move on to another area, or simply pause for a moment to enjoy the serene landscape. Its phenomenal attention to detail makes it feel like a piece of art; in a sense, it is. Ultimately, it is a game that constantly reminds us that we should live in the moment. It's peaceful, relaxing, meditative, and challenging at the same time. It's one of those experiences where the process of solving puzzles and uncovering the island's secrets is as rewarding as reaching the end.

The Witness also explores the process of learning. The game throws players into an adventure with no explicit instructions, setting the tone for a self-guided experience. Most regions introduce an independent and simple core concept. Upon completing one area, players are confident that they understand how to apply the rules learned to another one. Yet, as the game progresses, these concepts seamlessly merge, requiring application of knowledge across different areas.

This mirrors the learning process, akin to assembling smaller building blocks. The game's quality lies in refreshing the joy of learning, reminding players that learning is about discovery and understanding, a sentiment often overlooked in contemporary education. Consequently, it makes for an excellent choice for children.

[b]- Part 3: Outro -[/b]

Now, as with most titles, this one too has its shortcomings. Solving those panel puzzles can and will get tedious at some point. The reason for this is twofold: first, there are too many of them, and second, these puzzles aren't as sophisticated as the complex ones you'll encounter in games like The Talos Principle or Portal. Consequently, solving them doesn't feel very satisfying, although this is probably subjective. In a sense, the game distributes its difficulty across the entire island. Lastly, some puzzles can be a bit trickier or challenging, almost reaching the point of being unfair. Even if you know the rules, you may find yourself unable to solve them. All this reminds us of the challenges inherent in learning something new; the smaller building blocks are often boring and may be the source of frustration.

Having said all that, The Witness stands out as one of the few games I've played that didn't leave me feeling intellectually inadequate. This isn't by accident; it's by design. The introduction of panel puzzle mechanics, through solving puzzles of increasing difficulty, essentially serves as a tutorial. However, it never really feels like a traditional one. As a result, the primary challenge in most situations lies not in the complexity of the tasks but in the player's understanding of the rules and, consequently, the world around them. Also, unlike traditional adventure games like Myst, there's no need for "pixel hunting", as it's always evident what you can click on.

It's important to emphasize that this game isn't for everyone. If you approach it solely as a race to solve puzzles on panels and rush towards the end, chances are it won't resonate with you. However, if you're the type of player who relishes taking their time, finding joy in games rich with exploration, and appreciating them as an art form, then The Witness might be the perfect fit for you. That's the reason the game doesn't place stringent demands. On one hand, it presents a world, encouraging exploration and the discovery of numerous elements. On the other hand, players are at liberty to finish the game without necessarily uncovering many of its intricacies. However, by doing so, you'll likely miss out on understanding why you are on this island in the first place.

Therefore, my suggestion is to take it slow and uncover as much as you can. As you delve deeper, your knowledge will likely grow, leading to a clearer and more coherent grasp of the narrative. In the end, while understanding the story should be relatively straightforward, discerning the deeper meaning(s) of the game is not entirely obvious :)

Good luck!

Pareidolia is the tendency for perception to impose a meaningful interpretation on a nebulous stimulus, usually visual, so that one sees an object, pattern, or meaning where there is none. It is a type of apophenia.

Common examples are perceived images of animals, faces, or objects in cloud formations, seeing faces in inanimate objects, or lunar pareidolia like the Man in the Moon or the Moon rabbit. The concept of pareidolia may extend to include hidden messages in recorded music played in reverse or at higher- or lower-than-normal speeds, and hearing voices (mainly indistinct) or music in random noise, such as that produced by air conditioners or fans.

Best game ever

Though filled to the brim with a peaceful atmosphere, be warned: this game's puzzles are so addicting and complex you'll never see the world in the same way you did before playing.

Some puzzle mechanics resonate better than others, though. They can be total headscratchers, and they'll definitely make you take out the old pen and paper to note things down. It's one of those games, and it's really beautiful for that.

It's also beautiful for its aesthetics. One could probably take a picture of any one of the game's environments and use it as a wallpaper. It's quite relaxing, too.

It's also nice how the game doesn't force you to do the puzzle sections in any set order. You can go for any areas in any order you like, though you will have to eventually do them all if you actually want to finish the game.

All in all, it's quite the masterpiece, and everyone should enjoy it. I'm not too sure about the steep price tag, though. I'd wait for a sale.

这个游戏的主题就是一笔画线，主要有三个玩法：1. 通过简单题目找规律，推理猜测出规则；2. 利用学会的规则，按要求解密；3. 环境和谜题相结合。
对于猜测玩法，游戏是开放世界，鼓励暂时想不出的情况下先去别的地方，说不定再回来时就有顿悟的时刻，所以不太会有挫败感；游戏的机制也很丰富，让人感慨一个简单的划线能玩出这么多花样。
对于解密玩法，游戏中不乏精彩的解密；而且同一个规则下，不同的谜题都或多或少有不同的特点，而非规则的简单应用，不会有枯燥感。
游戏中解密与环境的结合是最让人惊叹的部分，既有通过环境提示来解密，也有通过解密来影响改变环境，还有利用视觉寻找环境中的谜题，不少地方令人拍案叫绝，震撼不已。

The Witness has great graphics.  I liked freely wandering the island solving some of the easier puzzles in the beginning.  After the Pink Trees, the game became nearly impossible to complete without a walkthrough. I spent more time being frustrated than enjoying a puzzle game.  I could never access the Treehouse because my boat did not have the activation slide on the right and no where in the discussions was this topic even addressed. very good but be open minded

I just finished 100%ing this game, so now is the best time to put my thoughts about it on paper.

This is one of the best puzzle games that I have ever played, it has one fundamental idea, builds on it throughout the entire game, and has a final challenge that introduces some very hard puzzles that are one of a kind. It makes you learn by doing, and once it finishes building that basis it reinforces it through harder and harder puzzles, questions that are very interesting to answer, and it truly makes you proficient. The witness, to quote electron delta's review of this game, asks you to "Stop looking, start seeing." It does a good job at it making you able to see a solution very quickly.

However, this is also one of the worst puzzle games I have played. Some of the puzzle types require you to sit in just the right location at just the right time, others are one-offs that require thinking in an entirely different way for a challenge puzzle. The game promotes not needing all of the lasers to enjoy the game, but requires all [spoiler]eleven of them to access the challenge area[/spoiler]. The game's downsides are not enough to hurt the positives it does.

[h3]From here on out, there will be spoilers. Read at your own risk[/h3]

[spoiler]There is one more horrible thing this game does, the environmental puzzles. The moment when you first see them, high atop the mountain looking down at the river, the panel next to it. The environmental puzzles add such a good dimension to the game. However going for all 135 of them is not a fun experience, some of them you need to align the clouds just right to see the line in the negative space, others you do the same but with trees, the red and purple flowers in front of the castle form puzzles, they are truly everywhere. This hunt was a truly maddening experience, the obelisks help but it has a lot of "right place, right time, eyes on a swivel for anything remotely resembling a circle." And all of this is without touching on the environmental puzzle that takes 57 minutes to complete. And while you wait for the full moon to cross over that theatre screen and become eclipsed, you hear a GDC talk about easter eggs and about looking too deeply into things, all this is while you are solving an easter egg itself! The environmental puzzles are the best part of this game and the one I would most like to remove.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]The Challenge, the record player, and the puzzles needed to unlock it are the truest final boss to this game. The cavern is filled with new puzzle types and ones that use mechanics in new and interesting ways, it makes you truly think again about everything you've learned so far. And the challenge? It forces you to solve puzzles sight unseen, with around 7 minutes to solve around 20 puzzles. Using an early pathfinding puzzle with two hexagon dots to define the maze you traverse later on it s very good decision. The puzzle panels which ask you to spot the fake reinforces the "start seeing" mentality. Your rewards for completing this is the solution to truly leave this place. What does that "3-2-1" mean? Why does it undo my progress? And then hopefully you see it, you are able to touch the sun and unlock the final ending.[/spoiler]

All in all, The Witness is a beautiful puzzle game that tests the player's skills and patience. You can stop whenever you want, and the game is perfectly okay with that.

[h1]-THE WITNESS-
[b]HONEST REVIEW[/b][/h1]

♌ The Witness is a puzzle game with the principle of "Start from the circle, reach to the end". The game reveals its difference with a maximum of 10 different mechanics that it can build on this foundation.

❌Although having so many mechanics sounds like a good thing, the game does not try to teach you these mechanics at all, and although you do not question this at first (5 hours), as the game progresses, you start playing a game where you do not know what you are doing and why. In easy puzzles intended to teach mechanics, you try to find a solution entirely through trial and error and create a rule in your own mind. However, while your rule is valid in simple puzzles, it does not work in complex puzzles. Because you have no idea whether your rule is correct or not.

❓Since our game takes place in an open world full of puzzles, you can start from any biome you want. Each biome has its own unique mechanics, but in the later puzzles of some biomes, you have to leave the biome when different mechanics are included in the puzzles. Since the game does not hold the player's hand at all, you do not know which biome to start from and where to learn which mechanics.

❌Since the basis of the game is based on a very simple logic, the puzzles start to repeat themselves. Although the game tries to keep itself fresh with various mechanics, since the developer wants to fill every part of the game with puzzles, when you encounter these mechanics both in their own biomes and in different biomes, it is inevitable for them to become repetitive and instead of giving you the feeling of solving a puzzle, it gives you the feeling of doing the same thing in a different way. And after a while the it feels suck.

⭐[b]A good puzzle game should open the player's mind and push him to think differently with every new puzzle it presents to the player. This game loves to be repetitive.[/b]


✅ Let's talk about what the game did best for me and gave me a reason to finish the game:
[b]"Environmental Puzzles"[/b]
Environmental puzzles are puzzles that use the basic logic of the game not only in the puzzles but in the entire open world. As I said, "The developer wanted to fill every part of the game with puzzles", that's exactly it. So any circle shape you see in the world can be the starting point of a puzzle for you. Although these puzzles are much simpler than the mechanical puzzles that the game tries to make, they are the only type of puzzles that make the player think.

✅ In order to find the puzzles in the environment, you may sometimes have to change the perspective, sometimes your angle, sometimes your location. Sometimes seek it from reflections, sometimes its light plays, and sometimes the environment, and these push the player to think differently and expand his view. Environmental puzzles are mind-expanding and well-thought-out puzzles.

❌ If you are a player like me who wants to experience everything in games, you can follow these puzzles on obelisks and find out what you missed on the internet. Even though I did most of them, there were some that I missed, but the solutions to the puzzles I missed were so absurd that I can say that this mechanic has been screwed. It is impossible not to be surprised by the minds of those who think about the puzzle and find the solution after reaching the solution.

📟 You may not know that there is a story in the game, because discovering this story is completely left to you, just like discovering the mechanics. However, the story it is trying to tell is quite empty and unnecessary.

⏭ To summarize, the game is a game that asks you to solve puzzles by putting different mechanics on the same basis. Although it is a very catchy game with its environmental puzzles, the fact that it does not hold the player's hand and constantly falls into repetition undermines these beautiful aspects of the game.

⭐ As someone who solved 520 of the 523 puzzles and 130 of the 135 environmental puzzles in the game, and who learned the mechanics completely while finishing the "Challange Room", I can say that this game is overrated, it is not a good puzzle game, and on an island filled to the brim with puzzles, the same mechanics are bored. .
❗ [b]"Too many cooks spoil the soup"[/b] ❗

👍[b][i]Don't forget to check out the game "The Looker" inspired by The Witness but much better designed![/i][/b]

[spoiler][h3][b][u]ENDING[/u]: Man! Stop touching every circle you see![/b][/h3][/spoiler]

I want to preface this: this is not a game for everyone. Please take some time and watch a video of what this game is like to play. I absolutely loved this game. To me, it is fun and entertaining. I enjoyed being able to progressively solve puzzles and use collective knowledge to solve more difficult puzzles. The hidden media within the game is cryptic, but also intriguing. For those wondering if you should get this game, answer these questions: do you like puzzles of any type? This game has puzzles that get very difficult, across a host of different media. Do you have a short attention span? Do you like sitting in silence? Can you handle listening to the same sounds repeatedly? This game has no soundtrack and often there is little sound other than the puzzles you are working on and the ambient sound of your environment. Can you handle disappointment? If your answers to this are yes, then play the game. You'll like it.

The Witness is one of the best puzzle games I have ever played. The way teaches you its mechanics without one word, the way the environment plays in finding the puzzle's solution and the environmental puzzles themselves, the level design, the art, it's all masterfully done. There's many satisfying moments where you'll get stumped by a puzzle for some time, to finally it clicking and you finding the solution. The weakest part is really the 'story', but at least it's optional.

Absolutely mind blowing puzzles and the MOST creative use of environment (for puzzles) I've ever seen. Deeply thought-provoking commentary and rhetoric on science vs. creation, which leave the player starstruck at the extreme display of intelligent pondering.

The world is beautiful; there is really nothing else to be said. The puzzles are hard and surprisingly varied for all following the same line following pattern. Everything is non-linear, but some of the rules for the puzzles are introduced in one area and expanded on in later areas. This forces you to do certain parts in order, but also teaches you that if you can't solve one thing, move on and come back later once you've discovered more. The "story" and ending (there are 2) can leave a lot of questions, but the fact that they are thought provoking in and of themselves is another notch in the game's belt.

"You wake up, alone, on a strange island full of puzzles that will challenge and surprise you."

Generally true. The puzzles can get challenging. There's a variety of mechanics, both inside and outside the in-game screens.

"You don't remember who you are, and you don't remember how you got here, but there's one thing you can do: explore the island in hope of discovering clues, regaining your memory, and somehow finding your way home."

The impllication that you'll regain lost memories is inaccurate, as far as I can tell. But sure.

"The Witness is a single-player game in an open world with dozens of locations to explore and over 500 puzzles."

This is true. (I wasn't keeping count, but it sounds right.)

"This game respects you as an intelligent player and it treats your time as precious."

That last part about time... is NOT true at all. You can reach the end of the game in a timely manner, but some non-mandatory puzzles require lining up things that move at an extremely slow speed, to say the least.

"There's no filler; each of those puzzles brings its own new idea into the mix. So, this is a game full of ideas."

...I guess? I feel like the optional room full of long videos could be argued to be filler. The puzzles are pretty great, though.

Not for anyone, but if you love it, you REALLY love it. If you like out-of-the-box thinking, visual puzzles, and looking through new perspectives, then you may love this game. This is a walking simulator-type game, so you walk around this beautiful island that is full of vibrant colors and unique sections that each hold a different "rule" added to the basic maze-grid puzzle you learn at the beginning. Each rule is denoted by different colors, symbols, or set-up (even sounds or shapes). However, this game does not TEACH you the rules, but guides you. There is a phrase within the education world: "Sage on the stage, guide on the side." While most games may "Sage on the Stage" and write the rules out for you, allowing you to try out different aspects of the rules before giving you a little chance to try what you've learned. Instead, this game is a "guide on the side" that allows you to find the rules by trying out different things on each puzzle with increasing difficulty. I would recommend all puzzle lovers to give this game a chance but use hints or solutions if the game begins to get frustrating so that you don't lose the love for the puzzle (just try solving it yourself first). Also, if you are struggling with an area or haven't found the "rule" yet, go to an area and come back. You will most likely visit every area a couple different times before attempting the END ZONE (More if you try to completion it -- which I am attempting). Good luck, and think outside the box, fellow puzzlers. : )

Welcome to The Witness, a mind-boggling puzzle adventure that's as perplexing as a riddle wrapped in an enigma, with a dash of M.C. Escher's surrealism thrown in for good measure. Developed by Jonathan Blow, this game takes you on a serene and thought-provoking journey through a mysterious island filled with puzzles that are as challenging as trying to eat soup with a fork. So, sharpen your wits, adjust your thinking cap, and let's dive into the captivating world of The Witness.

An Island of Enigmas:
The Witness presents you with an open-world island that's as vast and diverse as the Amazon rainforest. Each area is meticulously designed, like a mesmerizing painting that comes to life. From lush forests to haunting desert ruins, the island offers a picturesque backdrop for your cerebral expedition.

The landscapes are more than just eye candy; they often hold clues and hints to solve the puzzles, like a cryptic treasure map leading to untold secrets. The attention to detail is as meticulous as a watchmaker crafting a fine timepiece.

Puzzles Galore:
Ah, the puzzles – the heart and soul of The Witness. Prepare to immerse yourself in a collection of mazes and panels that challenge your logic, observation, and patience. Solving each puzzle feels as satisfying as finally getting that last piece of a jigsaw puzzle to fit perfectly.

The game doesn't hold your hand, but rather lets you discover the rules of each puzzle type through experimentation and observation. It's like being a detective, piecing together clues to uncover the mysteries hidden within.

A Feast for the Eyes and Ears:
The Witness is a visual and auditory treat, like indulging in a five-star meal for the senses. The minimalist art style is as elegant as a symphony, with every line and shape serving a purpose. It's a masterclass in how simplicity can be strikingly beautiful.

The ambient soundtrack adds another layer of immersion, whisking you away on an introspective journey as you unravel the island's secrets. It's like a gentle lullaby that soothes your mind even as you wrestle with mind-bending puzzles.

No Hand-Holding Allowed:
In The Witness, you are the master of your own destiny, like a cowboy riding through the untamed wild west. The game refuses to hold your hand or offer any hints, leaving you to rely on your instincts and intellect.

The lack of hand-holding might be frustrating at times, like trying to find your way in a dark room without a flashlight. However, it's this sense of discovery and accomplishment that makes solving each puzzle all the more rewarding.

Secrets and Layers:
The Witness is more than just a collection of puzzles; it's a game of layers and hidden meanings. The island is filled with cryptic symbols and secrets, like an ancient code waiting to be deciphered.

Exploring the depths of the island and uncovering its hidden secrets is like peeling back the layers of an onion. You'll find yourself pondering the game's deeper themes long after you've completed the last puzzle.

There's More to See Than Meets the Eye:
Now, here's the twist that makes The Witness even more intriguing. As you explore the island and solve its puzzles, you'll start to realize that there's more to the story than meets the eye.

The Witness is not just about solving puzzles; it's about self-discovery and the journey of the mind. It's like a philosophical exploration of the human experience, leaving you with a sense of wonder and introspection.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, The Witness is a breathtaking and thought-provoking journey that challenges your mind and captivates your senses. With its stunning visuals, brain-bending puzzles, and hidden layers of meaning, it's a game that's as unforgettable as a star-filled night sky.

So, if you're ready to embark on an intellectual adventure, explore the mysteries of a mysterious island, and unravel the secrets of your own mind, The Witness beckons you to delve into its enigmatic world. Remember, in the world of puzzles and enigmas, the journey is as important as the destination.

Happy puzzling!

This is a qualified recommendation, but as Steam doesn't let you pick anything but "yes or no", I had to quantise in some direction. 
If you like puzzles - and can put up with J Blow being his usual pretentious self when you get bits that aren't puzzles - then you might like The Witness, since it is all puzzles all the way down. 
There's some kind of theme about perspectives being important, but you need to hunt down a lot of optional bits that I frankly didn't care about to uncover anything resembling a plot - mainly because it's not important, what's important is the puzzles (and the construction of the world to act as a training system for puzzles).
The Witness also is shockingly lacking in accessibility features - some sets of puzzles are impossible if you have imperfect vision in various ways (or issues with sound in some cases), for example. So, go in knowing that.

However, the game does get all the mileage it can out of a relatively simple basis for solution representation, and (for the most part) I did enjoy it. (Even if several hours of my playtime are in attempts at a certain optional challenge, which I kept *just* failing at the last, and which is almost certainly antithetical in its design to the rest of the game.)

Like many, I REALLY went back and forth on whether or not to recommend this game.

I love puzzles of all kinds. Before you consider purchasing this, do some self reflection and be sure you also LOVE puzzles. I mean L-O-V-E. If you do not, then I would not recommend.

If you do LOVE puzzles, here is an idea of what you will probably need to complete this game -- at least I did:
   - The ability to hear well and distinguish different pitches and sounds
   - The ability to see and differentiate all colors on the human spectrum (do not buy if you are colorblind)
   - Notebook and pen (graph paper works best)
   - Windows snipping tool
   - Photo editor and/or MS Paint - you need to be able crop, rotate, and invert screen shots, as well as paste images together.
   - A guide for hints if you get stuck (I like the IGN guide)

What put me on the fence about this recommendation is that, after using the above tools several times, solving some of these puzzles felt like work, and not fun. Sure, it's satisfying when you do eventually solve them, but it can be exhausting. Also, don't expect much of a reward after solving them. You don't really get anything except the ability to move onto the next puzzle in the series. This process is pretty uncharacteristic in today's gaming climate. It was fine for me, but just be sure to know what you're getting yourself into.

The world is beautiful, but don't expect to do much except walk around and solve puzzles. This is what the game designer intended, and this is what they delivered.

Recommended if you LOVE puzzles. Literally "LOVE." Otherwise, expect to refund.

Throughout the game you anticipate having fun or discover hidden alien plot, or even play horror game in disguise. At least witness something. But there's nothing. There's only this fake plastic island.

Yeah, cool environmental stuff, perspective views. First couple times when you discover them. But waiting for the windmill to turn? Cloud to move? Full hour moon story at the end? An unforgivable waste of time.

The first time I finished The Witness was over six years ago on mobile. I only went through what I needed to complete the game at that time and didn't go around finding more afterwards. The second time was two years ago on PC where I combed through every area, [spoiler]solved most perspective puzzles, found the secret ending, and found every vault including the challenge.[/spoiler] And now as of a few weeks ago, I've played through the game a third time and more or less 100% it. Despite what many people are saying about it, The Witness continues to be my favorite puzzle game ever made.

The thing that many people overlook is what The Witness does NOT have. There is no start screen. There is no music. There is no HUD. There is no map[spoiler] (besides the boat and in the lake)[/spoiler]. There is no companion to interrupt you and say "Ohhhh it seems that you are having trouble there. Would you like a hint shit for brains." There is only you and the island. The only bit of gaminess stapled on are the settings and quit button. It doesn't have anything else because it doesn't [i]need[/i] anything else.

I have also heard of complaints that because there is no hand holding that the mechanics can't be taught well enough. That has to do with the capability of the player to learn from previously completed puzzles and adapt their understanding of the mechanics accordingly. If you think that a puzzle should be solved from what you understand and yet your solution is wrong, then the problem lies with you and not the puzzle itself. If you are stuck, go to a different part of the island and come back later. If you still can't solve it, just look at a guild.

There is also this large sentiment even from fans of the game that Jonathan Blow is pretentious because of the [spoiler]audio logs and movie clips[/spoiler] found in the game. Much like the puzzle mechanics, these are put in to change one's perspective. About who we are. About how to find truth. Different people will resonate with each one differently, but to discredit them as just pretentious is a bit of a disservice.

There is much more I want to talk about like the design of the puzzles itself and the various scenes of perspective and the ending itself which is also unfairly hated, but I'll just leave it as that. For what could easily have been a simple puzzle game neatly sectioned into levels and with no added complexity, Johnathan Blow went much more than an extra mile to make what I can now call my favorite puzzle game.

[spoiler]Fuck the red ship door though. I don't know how anyone can defend that.[/spoiler]

When it comes to this game, it is hard for me to put my opinions into words. There are definitely many pros as well as cons, so I'm gonna try to lay it all out and I'll leave it up to you as to whether or not its worth your time:

Pros:

The game itself is slow and calculating to the point where it teaches you the mechanics of the puzzle systems piece by piece, slowly building upon whatever you've previously learned and expanding it to vast proportions. 

If you ever find yourself unsure of how to proceed because it seems the game just hasn't provided you with enough information to solve the puzzles, there is a chance the solution to the puzzles can actually be found in the environment around you. Some puzzles require you to adjust the camera angle just right so you can see the solutions illuminated in the sun's light, while other puzzles may require you to raise or lower the room's overall water levels so you could see the solutions in the water's reflection.

There is zero background music, giving you the player a vast natural ambiance to help you focus with zero distractions. 

The game is long, and brilliant. If you've got nothing but time on you're hands and wish for something that would serve as a simple distraction, this game would be the best damn thing for you. It is so easy to loose yourself in this game, forget the world around you and immerse yourself in the shear intricacies of life within this game. 

Cons:

This game is super intricate with it's environmental hints and clues to solving the puzzles, so intricate in fact that anybody who isn't excessively observant enough may find themselves in a situation where they may begin to feel inadequacy towards their own capabilities. 

The game-play is long and slow, so much so that if you're a gamer like me who plays games with the intent to record and upload for the amusement of an audience, I can not recommend this game for you. It's too long, too quiet for audience interest, and while it may seem like the game has some intriguing lore or story of some sort, it's never properly explained and leaves the players feeling cheated in some way. Like you've arrived at the scene of some great apocalyptic disaster, and there's nothing and nobody left to explain to you or help you understand what happened. 

So, all in all it is a good game. Not exactly the best, and definitely something to avoid like the plague if your just looking for content, however as a simple time waster I honestly couldn't recommend it enough.

This game was remarkably beautiful and I cannot fathom how much work must have gone into fine tuning the position of every branch and every lightsource to create the puzzles in this game. I also can't even begin to imagine how you would tackle the task of programming this. From a technical point of view and in terms of craftsmanship, this game is a masterpiece.

However, it's not really fun to play. I wouldn't call this bad, if there was a way to rate in stars I would give it a more nuanced rating. But ultimately, I wouldn't recommend this when you are looking for a puzzle game. The game mainly features two types of puzzles. On the one hand you find grids and have to draw a continuous line on those, following rules like passing through certain points or seperating coloured blocks with those lines. Those puzzles feel similar to for example sudoko: most of them are singular puzzles that could very well appear in a puzzle book that you might take on a train ride. Those aren't bad, but also not so outstanding that I would recommend the game just for those. The main selling point of the game is the second type of puzzle. Here to you have to draw lines, but you won't see rules on the grid but rather the environment will give you clues, for example in shadows or tree branches. Those are what make the game unique, but in my opinion also what made it boring and tidious. The biggest part of the game was spamming wasd and spinning my mouse in search for any kind of clue anywhere. I can imagine that some people want this, but for me it felt mostly like a drag.

Not everyone's cup of tea, but it was definitely mine. It was so fun to explore the island (which was way better looking than it needed to be), figure out how the puzzles work, and solve them. The puzzles are not easy though, so only play this game if you're willing to really think. Also has optional content beyond just beating the game, but stopping right after beating the main game is perfectly satisfying as well.

It's a decent puzzle game, but there's no point to any of it. It's about everything and nothing at the same time. Try it if you like connecting dots.

I don't know if I can accurately put in to words the way that I feel about The Witness. 

I can recognize that it is absolutely not for everyone with its gameplay consisting of variations of the same puzzle over and over. The reward is more line puzzles. The atmosphere is kind and calm, yet oddly empty. It's not unnerving, but there's definitely a feeling in your lower gut walking around this seemingly formerly populated island.

It's not for everyone. But it is for me. The puzzles never felt unfair or too crazy to grasp. The slow burn of the way the game wordlessly teaches you the rules makes me feel smart as much as I feel dumb. The game starts off neat enough, I was going through this word somewhat aimlessly, solving random panels I came across hoping to find a goal to work toward. And I did eventually find it. Seeing the first laser come out and point toward the mountain was the first time the game hooked me. 

The game hooked me about 4 different times. Each time, my opinion of the game grew more favorable. 

I don't want to get into spoilers because if you allow yourself to be along for the ride and give the puzzles your all, there are some moments in here that will absolutely floor you like they did me. Truly, if you like puzzle games and you're even a little interested, do it. Play The Witness as blind as possible.

I love The Witness. The witness is the best puzzle game I've ever found, and though I had to wait until it went on sale, it was definitely worth the wait. This game gave me weeks of puzzle solving fun before I finally solved it, and sometimes I sat on a specific puzzle for days on end (most recently for about a month on the same silly puzzle), though there is always a solution; it's never out of bad design that I get stuck. This struggle is integral to what I consider to be a good puzzle game.

This game was a magical experience. The best single player game I have ever played. It has challenging and thought provoking puzzles mixed with an enchanting, mysterious, beautiful atmosphere. It feels as though each small detail is considered and tweaked to provide a deeply unique and intriguing experience. The technical aspects of the game are near perfect, and the creativity and gameplay is incredible. It leaves a lot of questions to be answered on your own or left unanswered. As you play you feel the immense amount of effort and care put into the game. I recommend to play it and do all the puzzles legit if you can.

The Witness is a nearly perfect environmental puzzle game for the first 15 or so hours. It's puzzles are very well designed, there are a truly shocking number of secrets to find around the world, and the environment is genuinely visually stunning. The game is far from perfect however. Over the span of a single hour, The Witness went from my all time favorite puzzle game ever, to something I genuinely couldn't imagine picking up again. It's end-game puzzles are either extremely obtuse, pointlessly frustrating, or both.

My advice to those considering buying The Witness are:

1) Don't try to 100% the game. Hell, don't even try for 90%. Get as far as you can while still having fun. The moment you stop having fun is when you should put the game down, because it'll genuinely drive you insane.
2) If you get stuck on a difficult puzzle, don't hesitate to look up a hint or solution. Chances are the game didn't communicate what you need to do in order to properly solve it, and there's no sense in ruining good experiences with nearly impossible puzzles.
3) If you come across a puzzle with symbols you don't recognize, that's the game telling you to go somewhere else. While the game is technically "open world", it tries to lock some sections behind difficult and unfamiliar puzzles.
4) The Witness has no accessibility options, so if you have a sensory impairment (specifically hearing, sight, or color blindness), many puzzles (including some needed to progress through the game) will be entirely impossible to solve without help.

If I could just forget the entire last section of The Witness, I would, and this would still be my favorite puzzle game ever. But I can't, so all I can do is recommend others not make the same mistake as me. Don't try to 100% the game. If you can buy it on sale, do it, and only play for as long as you can handle. Leave the game there, and remember the good parts.

My interpretation of the game is that [spoiler] the entire game is a metaphor for the process of learning. From the very start, you are put into the game with no knowledge like a baby. It's nuts that something this big has such game design. Every single thing about this game is that way for a carefully considered reason, and the synthesis between ideas and mechanics as you progress is without equal. You're doomed if you don't think outside the box here. This on its own would easily make The Witness a remarkable outing, but there's also the peaceful and reflection presentation of the game world, and the puzzles themselves will have you feeling like some sort of bumbling neanderthal, but they're never unfair, which makes that eventual "a-ha" moment hit so much harder than any "just good" puzzler. There's no narrative to speak of in this game, but I think it can still teach us much about patience and perception.

When I played the original Hotline Miami I was happy to finish each level and felt a level of success, I was eager to replay and better myself, but for the sequel I just wanted to move on and every level felt like a chore. This game makes me feel the same was as HM2 but dialed up to 100 times. It's not unusual to finish a level (or find a solution online) and shout out loud "WHAT? WHY?".

I don't recommend this game to anyone that wants to finish it. It's obtuse, obscure, irritating, annoying, and the developer more than likely intended it to be all of those things. I can appreciate Jonathan Blow but I don't enjoy his game.

There is no way to check your progress, there are no sound options, hints and success conditions for each puzzle (even during that puzzle type introduction) are incongruous. The developer does not want you to succeed, which makes it feel in some way pretentious.

I will still chip away at this while I'm doing something else so that it doesn't annoy me as much, but who knows if I will ever finish it. I can't check my progress, and I'll only live another 40 years so it's extremely unlikely.

[u]The Witness[/u] is set in a gorgeous world with a very accessible user interface. The puzzles are all the same variety: start at a circle, follow a line. The game adds complexity in each new area you access in a very reasonable way.  Unfortunately, sometimes the "tutorial" puzzle screens are locked behind a puzzle that requires you to intuit information you don't have yet. You have to brute-force guess FAR more often than is forgivable for a professionally-crafted, playtested full-release game. Expect to consult a hint-guide or walkthrough.

The people I know who love this game delight in the environment and the simplicity of the puzzle structure. I agree that these things are delightful! The biggest struggle I have is this game's relationship to its own narrative. The Steam blurb says [i]"You don't remember who you are, and you don't remember how you got here, but there's one thing you can do: explore the island in hope of discovering clues, regaining your memory, and somehow finding your way home."[/i]  THIS DESCRIPTION IS A PATENT MISREPRESENTATION OF THIS GAME. There are vanishingly few clues (seriously: like 50-something voice-recordings and six videos) and they do not form much of a cohesive narrative at all. Past the First Ending (there are at least two), there are more "clues" that suggest something bigger than just "walk around and have a pleasant time in this beautiful world solving a puzzle maze now and again" HOWEVER the game never lines things up for you.

The recordings are all extremely pretentious quotes by Christian theologians from the Renaissance or a couple Chinese philosophers (vast minority), or a bunch of modern scientists. Honestly, the whole thing feels extremely White, Christian Atheist: "I reject the notion of God or destiny, because I can't know it, so nothing is worth anything."  Frankly, it's boring. And the "clues" the player DOES find indicate ||that a team of people went to an awful lot of trouble to manufacture this world|| so the narrative and the gameplay are at odds. If you want to send a message that "The present experience is all there is, so enjoy yourself!" then you need to make sure all of your game elements support that. If that ISN'T the message you're sending, then maybe quit saying it so often and make sure you ARE saying the thing you mean to say.

In my culture, I grew up with the notion that, on one hand, "The world was created for me," while on the other "I am but dust and ashes."  Two notes in my figurative pockets is a better exploration of philosophy than this entire game, which I took 61 hours to complete, hoping to find something of substance.  I even waited [b]literally 56 minutes[/b] through a whole video of ADHD rambling to solve an environmental puzzle.

Further: this game will be ENTIRELY INACCESSIBLE to people with visual acuity issues (particularly color-blindness) or are hard of hearing (one whole puzzle area requires hearing specific sounds through audio interference). There are no settings to accommodate for this.

But hey! The world is pretty and if you are just looking for someplace fun to run around and maybe solve a puzzle or two, this game is for you. If you're looking for depth of narrative or a game that respects your time as a player, [i]Caveat Emptor[/i].

The Witness is not a game for everyone. The game in itself isn't as much of a puzzle as it is a learning experience. That being said, I am enjoying every minute of it. 

Something to be noted about this game, is that there is a huge learning curve. There is no direction, no instructions, you are supposed to figure out everything yourself. And there will come multiple times throughout the game that you feel like you are stuck. I think a good portion of the bad reviews are because people just couldn't end up taking the time to figure out certain puzzles (which is understandable, but then again, read the first sentence of this review). I found myself leaving the game multiple times and then coming back to it just to find out how I was overlooking something very simple. If anyone can sit through this game in one sitting, they must be some super intelligent genius or something (if this is you props to you and stay far away from me). 

Jokes aside, I really enjoy the atmosphere of this game. It can come across as a little weird sometimes in the way it talks about intelligence and the mind, but if you can get past that I think you will find the game really immersive. I would also HEAVILY suggest not looking up any spoilers or any walkthroughs of the game as the adrenaline I got/am getting was from finishing puzzles and seeing where they led me. 

This game definitely takes time, and if you are not willing to put in hours upon hours of puzzle-solving, I would look somewhere else.

The game is probably fun for amazingly smart people. I'm only a little bit smart and that is clearly not enough for this game. But if I was smart enough, I doubt I would have liked the game. Because it lacks at two key aspects that make a game fun or interesting, namely (1) story and (2) gameplay. 

The story
The isn't a real story in this game. There are elements that hint towards a story, and there is a second ending that tries to give the impression of a story (the protagonist is a VR game tester), but a real story remains absent. People who like this game often give pretentious and modern artsy type of answers that the story is what you interpret it to be. To me this is just a cop out as you can say this literally about anything. 

Gameplay
Moreover, the absense of a story is also important for the gameplay. The game is very non-lineair, which many people would love, but without a story it gives you no purpose or goal to go anywhere. I'm sure there was an artsy idea behind it like 'people create their own purpose'  or perhaps one can do things in their own pace. But to me it made the game just feel a bit aimless and confusing. The confusing part is for instance, that because I saw a statue of a person early on, I though this would be interesting and I should go there. But sadly it was one of the hardest area's, and should have been reserved as a final area. After a while it became clear that if you stumble on an area that is too hard, you should just move to another area, but there are no clues to which one would be best. 

The game basically consists of a bunch of games where you need to draw a line through a maze. There are different rules, such as that it needs to contain a certain tetris like shape, or that stars of the same color should be combined, etc. But the basic gameplay is always the same. 

The rules are often introduced quite cleverly, with some 'training puzzles'. These are very easy mazes that have only a few possible outcomes, and thus it becomes quickly obvious what a certain rule is. Then usually there are a few more difficult mazes, which are fun, and then there are even more difficult mazes, which combines the new rule with rules from other mazes, and then there are more difficult mazes, and then again, and again and again. A good example was the game mechanic in the ruins part of the game. Here the correct path in the maze was visible in a certain angle (light was important here). So after discovering how to find the correct angles, the game gives you more mazes, but now you cannot find the angle without moving stuff, and then you get some more mazes where you have to move even more stuff, and then you get some more mazes where you need to move stuff not just once, but a bunch of times, and then you get a maze where you need to move stuff and look in the reflection of the water, and then you get a maze where you need to move stuff and look in the reflection of the water and move even more stuff again, and so on. 
In short, when you figure out a rule it’s fun, but it severely overstays its welcome and quickly becomes a chore. 

When combining many rules, it sometimes became too difficult to me. But I imagine that if you are color blind or even hard of hearing, it becomes impossible. Some puzzles use sound as a hint. And for many puzzles you need to see colors really well. 

Another design choice I didn't like was that the puzzles didn't only become hardly due to more logical rules, it often became harder because of dumb obstacles. For instance, a sound puzzle where the beeps would guide you through the maze, just had some telephone sounds to overrule the beeping sounds. Or sometimes you would have to look from a certain angle, and later in the game the puzzles would start moving around (very dizzying!). It didn't really make the puzzle more fun, or more intellectually stimulating, just more annoying. 

All in all, the game felt like a chore, and I couldn't wait for it to be over. Because I couldn't be bothered with some really hard puzzles, I did look up the solutions sometimes... So this means I did finish it, even though I didn’t like it... and I am not quite sure why. Perhaps because I did like the atmosphere and landscape of the island. But in all honesty, it felt more like an OCD thing. A pressing negative feeling that I just needed to have closure to this somehow very claustrophobic feeling game.

The game *attempts* to teach you the rules of the puzzles with a simple form of the puzzle, and as you complete gradually more and more complex puzzles you understand the rules and apply them to the new puzzles.
The problem comes into play when you learn a set of rules, but the set you learned was incorrect but applied perfectly to the previous puzzles. You (the dumbfuck) didn't understand the unwritten rules and are a fool for not understanding what the dev already knew when they made the new puzzle. I wouldn't be so harsh but this game costs real money. Money you had to earn by working. Money you could have spent on any other game, which is what I suggest you do with that money. Instead try Portal or Manifold Garden.

I'm so sorry but I just don't understand why everyone likes this game. I loved Jonathan Blow's talks on conferences and I love his philosophy, but this game.. It's just bad, sorry.

Navigating through the game is pretty much impossible, you never know whether you're supposed to be solving a puzzle or not which can get you stuck for hours if you think you're supposed to solve a puzzle when you're not, or even days if you thought you were not supposed to solve a puzzle when you were.
The puzzles themselves, the graphics and the whole atmosphere is really good, but it's not good enough to overlook the basic failings of this game.

The navigation in this game is so very tedious and unintuitive. One could either spend years looking through the terrain trying to find every hidden thing or one could try to follow a sort of natural path instead which would lead to not only missing majority of the puzzles but also eventually into a dead-end. Getting into one such dead end would require a lot of backtracking and remembering where things were, which would be nearly impossible since the journey would've taken a few days by then and this game doesn't have anything particularly memorable.

That's on top of the fact that there is no save feature, only load. And the autosave overwrites the current loaded one, making it impossible to backtrack without solving the same puzzles over and over and over and over. And what's even worse, the autosave frequently (always, in my experience) happens in the exact moment you fail some sort of a time-based challenge, of which there are way too many to keep backtracking every time.

The core design of this game is something I personally just genuinely despise. It's not just puzzles. You have spend hours on finding the puzzles, then you have to spend hours on checking whether the puzzle is solvable without external clues, then you have to spend hours finding the clues. They could be visual clues, auditory clues, spacial clues, luminal clues. And you never quite know whether you need them or not, so you pick up on patterns that aren't there, or miss other patterns entirely. Once you've gone through this process for one line of puzzles, all of the remaining puzzles in that line are dead simple and boring, with no real reward.

The whole experience feels like the game trying to convince you it's really clever while actually only obfuscating the simple, boring puzzles. Or alternatively, from what I know of Blow's approach to developing this game, it feels like he saw potential in the simple concept of line puzzles and attempted to extract the deeper meaning and the emergent complexity into a puzzle game but ended up forcing incompatible concepts onto it just to complete what has been started.

The kind of game that high intellectuals would enjoy after a long day of taping a banana to a wall and discussing the artistic meaning behind it. You get no hints, no clues or anything so you mess around until you resort to a guide, then you get to listen to some unrelated philosophy that the game considers "a story" I guess.

Simply put: nonsense puzzles that I have nowhere near enough patience for.

This game will challenge you intellectually because it never gives you any instructions. You just explore and find puzzles to solve. These puzzles start off simple enough to learn the rules and then get more complex. You're never told any of the rules, so you either need to figure it out for yourself through trial and error or look them up. I did a mix of both (and still haven't run into all of them, as of this review).

My experience so far has been alternating frustration and satisfaction. Overall, I'd say that I spend more time being frustrated with the puzzles than happy with the progress I've made. If I continue to play this game (and I'm pretty sure I will), it's not for the enjoyment of playing a game but to challenge myself. Based off of other reviews, I'm not expecting any big payoff at the end. Solving the puzzles is the whole point, so if you're the type of player that would look up solutions to progress, I'd say don't bother with this game.

Also, I agree with others who call the overall tone of this game pretentious. It's hard to put my finger on exactly why. Maybe it says more about me than the game itself. Edit: Just another hour in and after one less subtle recording found, I think I can better put my finger on what I don't like about the tone of this game. It's a religious game pretending to not be a religious game. There were other hints before, including the name itself, but it mostly just gave this sense of "I know the answers to all of your questions. Well, no, not those ones, but to all of the questions you should be asking instead of the ones you are."

In any case, if you're looking for something fun and/or easy, I'd suggest skipping this one. If you're looking for something to challenge your mind, then this might be it.

The non environmental puzzles take SIGNIFICANTLY more time akin to staring at a Sudoku puzzle trying to figure out the "one correct" solution rather than searching the beautiful surroundings for clues. If you are someone else who has played this game I am specifically lamenting the block puzzles being put seemingly everywhere after they are introduced and seem to be padding the game up until the end.

Opening the last area has one of the more cool environmental puzzles but this leads to a series of non environmental puzzles to beat the game that I can't bring myself to complete. They are the same puzzles you complete the entire game but with annoying "broken parts" just to slow you down entering in the solutions. If they had cut out a large portion of these non environmental puzzles imo this would be a 9/10 as the good parts of this game are great for what they are. Would compare it to a story game or tv show just having a little too much filler.

This is my first negative review on Steam and hopefully the only one I will ever do.
The Witness is honestly the single most insufferable and annoying puzzle game I have ever played. It’s bad enough that I think going back to the first Professor Layton and solving all those stupid-ass sliding puzzles all over again would be a better experience lmao.

I actually really enjoyed the first 60% or so of the game, but the other 40% completely soured the whole experience. It actually starts pretty fun, but the more I progressed, the less and less energy and motivation I had to keep going. The annoyance over some stupidly difficult and/or bullshit puzzles plus their general repetitiveness really starts to build up after a while. Oh, and speaking of horrible puzzles, thank you devs for putting a fucking puzzle with crazy flashing rainbow lights not soon after the ones that seems specifically designed to cause motion sickness, I greatly appreciated the headache 👍👍
There are also puzzles that are apparently literally unsolvable if you have color blindness or hearing impairments, which as we all know is always a very good sign of great game design lol
Anyway, after some point I started straight up looking up every solution because I couldn’t be bothered anymore. The sole thing keeping me going was some form of sunk cost fallacy. I kept hoping that the terrible parts were just temporary and that things would go back to being fun again, but they never did.

Oh and btw, did you know this game apparently has a story?? Well, I only do now because I googled it, since the game puts near zero effort into even implying it does. In fact, I bet most people only know there’s supposed to be a story here because the devs came out on interviews saying so. Allegedly, the idea that there’s narrative here is apparently “implied” via the use of ridiculously-hard-to-see cassette tapes scattered around the map, which are also so well hidden I believe most sane players upon finding them would think they are just neat completely optional collectibles/easter eggs at best. I think I found 2 or 3 of them in my entire playthrough by the way, and there are [spoiler]over 40[/spoiler], so I guess you really need to go out of your way to spot them, huh? lol
Again, I’m not sure how the players are supposed to figure out there is a story when the game literally doesn’t tell you anything of the sort (or anything at all for that matter) since the game appears to have an intense aversion to telling you stuff directly. I guess being terrified of words must really be part of the game’s minimalist philosophy lol

Honestly, the game as a whole just feels very pretentious and seems to think it’s smarter than it actually is (it really isn’t lmao). From the tapes that contain readings of stuff said by philosophers, scientists and whoever else, to the minimalist puzzle design that is apparently somehow meant to make you question your “ideas” and “interpretations of reality” or whatever, everything just screams “hey guys, look at how smart my game is :))))”. It’s just too much. Way too much lmao.

Well, I don’t know what else to say at this point. In short, it feels as if the game was so busy being focused on being “minimalist”, “philosophical” and “artsy” that at some point it completely forgot to actually be enjoyable. Maybe I’m looking at this through the wrong perspective (heh), but I’m also not willing to go back and experience anything from this game ever again, as I’d rather go play something that I feel actually respects my time and me as a player.

Just go play another puzzle game like The Talos Principle, it's a better use of your time and money. Or don’t, maybe you’ll like this shit lol. That insufferable last 40% sure wasn’t for me.

Definitely lives up to the hype. Game requires saintly patience, and makes my head hurt a lot, but it's so satisfying when you have those "AH HA!" moments. I don't think I'll be smart enough to complete the later portions on my own without hints though.

Don't waste your time.

[b]Cons:[/b]

The Witness is very... hollow. The world is shallow, you are weightless, and your actions mean little. Contrary to the store page summary, you do not 'regain your memory' or 'find your way home'. I don't think these are spoilers, because they are absent entirely - the subject of your memory or journey simply doesn't come up. Some Googling suggests that this is perhaps partly referenced in a secret post-game area, but: too bad! That's not the game! You have to put it in the main bit!

The story, if you can call it that, is sadly a pretentious bust. Recitals of abstracts from astronauts and 15th-century theologians do not a narrative make. Not even if they are (as one indeed is) 8 whole minutes long. The ending is a dire disappointment that made me wish I hadn't bothered persevering. I even unlocked the [i]secret[/i] ending, with its corresponding real-life video, but all that did was make it [i]more[/i] apparent in a truly toe-curling manner that the supposed intelligence is all affectation. Real 17-year-old film student stuff.

I could bear with the poseur philosophising (some of the quotes are nice!) and the abstraction and the quasi-mysticism if the game was itself fun to play. But it's not. Again, and in typing here I now realise this is the binding theme, The Witness is simply desperate to show you how clever it is. When it isn't. A recurring sin is that obfuscation is mistaken for acumen. The difficulty curve more generally is off-grade and poorly designed, with low levels of the satisfaction payoff that it should provide. The many layers of mechanics do not change that the core challenge is repetitive, and occasional dynamic features are clunky. 

If I had paid full price for this I would be really annoyed. Don't bother. For better servings on religion, philosophy, humanity, voice acting, story, and puzzles - get The Talos Principle instead.

I really liked this game, thought it was pretty rewarding and clever (meaning they don't rely on b*******) and didn't mind the lectures even though some of them are straight psychobabble. Then I wandered into a section where you have to listen to bird calls, apparently. I'm not super hard of hearing but I could not even hear a single one. Okay, maybe that's on me. Then you get to the end, and all of a sudden those clever puzzles get warped by bull****. I'm talking motion sickness inducing panels scrolling, flashing lights that made me wish I was colorblind, some real ****** game design. Ngl ruined the experience hardcore.

If you're gonna pull this crap at least do it in the first two hours of the game so I can return it unlike some of these masochists who're down to put up with the epilepsy.

The Witness is a hidden gem in puzzle games, beautifully designed in every aspect imaginable, but what surprised me is that it is - apart from the early game - exceptionally difficult! This game is hardcore when it comes to puzzling. It is so hard that I think accessibility is significantly reduced by it, since a difficult puzzle is not the same as, for instance, Dark Souls difficult. Games like that are beatable with devotion, dedication and persistence, but that will get you nowhere in The Witness. To beat this, you need the mental capacity. Or cheat and look up everything.

The Witness is on par with great puzzle games like Portal (2), Talos Principle, or Myst. Those are the memorable ones I've played (with more to come) but the Witness is without a doubt the hardest of these games. I was stuck on some puzzles for days. I was not able to complete this without the use of pen and paper, or screenshots where I could draw in, and it looks like I am not alone here. I am not sure if it a wise move to make a puzzle game this difficult. The end result is a game that I think most players will not be able to complete or enjoy because I believe intelligence is actually required for a player to finish and enjoy this. The game does not hold your hand, you are left with figuring out the rules through trial and error and although the game is clearly designed to be beatable, you do have to think outside the box multiple times. The difficulty should not be underestimated, even if you've completed multiple puzzle video games and do sudokus and crosswords in your spare time. The Witness is not for everyone.

I would only recommend this to players that fit the profile of high intelligence, strong analytical skills, can think outside the box and a 'bring it on' mentality. If you are *not* 'blessed' with high intelligence, or easily get frustrated when you don't understand what the game wants you to do, then stay clear. You will hate it and leave a bad review.
Visually this game looks amazing, the puzzles get progressively harder and the atmosphere is great. Very enjoyable, would play again

However, the game was not perfect. Getting to the end of the game, which can be done by following certain markers on the map, resets all progress the player has made. Additionally, the player is not required to complete the areas around the map before ending the game, which made for a disappointing end scene. Even still, a solid 9/10 game.

The Witness is a masterfully crafted puzzle game that delights and challenges players with its beautifully designed world and complex brainteasers. From the moment you set foot on the island, you're swept away by the stunning landscapes, the ambient sounds of nature, and the sense of mystery that permeates every corner of the environment.

The puzzles themselves are elegant and sophisticated, ranging from simple line drawings to multi-layered, multi-step problems that require careful observation and logical deduction. Each puzzle is like a mini-work of art, a perfect balance of form and function that will leave you feeling both accomplished and enlightened.

What sets The Witness apart from other puzzle games is the way it seamlessly integrates its challenges into the larger context of the island's lore and narrative. As you progress through the game, you'll uncover hidden secrets and subtle clues that shed light on the island's enigmatic past and present. The puzzles themselves become a key part of this narrative, serving as both a metaphor for the challenges we face in life and a means of exploring the deeper mysteries of existence.

The Witness is a game that rewards patience, persistence, and open-mindedness. It's not a game that you can rush through or beat by brute force. Instead, it requires careful observation, careful listening, and careful thought. But the rewards are well worth the effort: a deep sense of satisfaction, a heightened appreciation for the power of human intelligence, and a renewed sense of wonder and curiosity about the world around us.

In short, The Witness is a must-play game for anyone who loves puzzles, storytelling, or just beautiful, immersive game worlds. It's a triumph of game design and a testament to the boundless creativity of the human mind.

Well I have to say this game made me cry out of wonder and awe at the ending. I also found the movies you find in the game both touching and fascinating, as well as all the random audio logs scattered about from great thinkers to be worth pondering. One sequence in particular where you have to solve a series of puzzles under a time constraint and escalating classical music, was probably the most fun I've ever had in a puzzle game.

Its not quite like other puzzle games such as Myst or Quern where you have to use items and interact with the world, but nevertheless I found it quite absorbing to solve the dozens of variations on the same basic logic puzzle being put forward (essentially finding some way to get from the start to the end of the puzzle while fulfilling various conditions of increasing complexity). Some of the solutions and settings are really quite ingenious. But beyond that is the world itself...its like walking through an art painting. There are many points in the story where you just want to take a minute to enjoy the surroundings and the beauty of the world around you.

The developer of this game clearly put a lot of heart and soul into the game, and I really think that gamers who enjoyed Myst will find it to be a rewarding experience. I don't think you're meant to finish it in one sitting, but rather come back to it again and again. It is a wonderful bit of escapism to a pastel-coloured paradise world with clever puzzles and a mysterious story.

The island is uncanny and atmospheric, as long as you don't expect it to feel real or alive: it's not natural but a constructed space for you to ponder questions and mysteries. And yes, there is a touch of "All of this is deep, innit?" to The Witness, but if you can take this in your stride, The Witness's island is worth a visit.

There's barely any story or soundtrack, it's just puzzle after puzzle with a pretty interesting way of introducing the mechanics, where they don't tell you anything and instead make you explore to find more information on how to solve them. That's exactly what I was looking for and why I was so hooked on the game. If you like puzzles and want to challenge yourself I highly recommend it.

The island is neatly split into different areas, each with a different mechanic introduced to the player. This is my favorite part of the game, because of how you have access to most of them, and are free to leave a puzzle to come back when you feel like it. All of them are intuitive to certain extend, but most of the time will be spent figuring out what the game wants you to do. Clear some areas to progress and that's it. Also, some puzzles require you to tell colors apart or listen carefully to in-game sounds, which might worsen the experience to people with certain level of colorblindness or hearing problems.

A few spoilers ahead since the endgame and postgame are worth mentioning... The endgame part mixes some of the mechanics learned throughout the island, but makes it so the difficulty is mostly lost, and instead you have these simple puzzles that feel like they were made just to be as annoying as possible. Like making the interfaces move, or barely visible, or blink with bright colors, or spin around. Multiple times I had to step out and leave because of head pains. After that, if you decide to keep playing and go for 100%, the game wants you to clear all areas from before and play a boring version of Where's Waldo with dots and lines. There's not much to this part since most of the puzzles here consist of "stand in the right place". The timed challenge, on the other hand, was probably the part I enjoyed the most, challenging your memory and knowledge of the mechanics of the game while trying not to run out of time, makes me wish there was more of that.

In the end, this game will be stuck in my head for a while because of the experience, including the satisfactions and frustrations it gave me.

The game takes place on a beautiful, uninhabited island filled with puzzles and challenges for the player to solve. The Witness is a game that is not only entertaining, but thought-provoking and visually stunning.

The puzzles are simple in concept, but challenging in execution. The game uses a series of line puzzles, where the player must draw a line from one point to another while following certain rules. The puzzles start out relatively easy, but they gradually become more difficult as the player progresses through the game. Each section of the island is dedicated to a different type of puzzle, such as mazes or color puzzles, which keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting.

One of the most impressive aspects is the island itself. The game's environments are beautifully designed, with lush landscapes and stunning vistas. The game uses a vibrant color palette, which makes the island feel alive and full of energy. The sound design is also noteworthy, with a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that adds to the atmosphere of the game.

The Witness also has a strong narrative element. As the player solves puzzles and explores the island, they uncover audio recordings and environmental clues that slowly reveal the backstory of the island and its mysterious creator. The game's story is open to interpretation and invites players to come up with their own theories and ideas about what is really going on.

The Witness is an incredibly well-crafted game that is both challenging and thought-provoking. It is a game that rewards exploration and encourages players to think outside the box. The game's beautiful visuals and haunting soundtrack create a truly immersive experience. For fans of puzzle games, The Witness is a must-play title that will provide hours of entertainment and mental stimulation.

- Don't be afraid to move on if you're stuck. Some puzzles are basically impossible until you've done some simpler puzzles elsewhere that will clarify some rules, symbols, or other quirks. There are tons of puzzles, there's another one just around the corner if you're  struggling. 
- Don't be afraid to take screenshots or get out a piece of paper, some puzzles are tough to work out on the screen. 
- If you don't like logic puzzles then this is not for you, it's literally the entire game.Finally, although the landscape plays into some of the puzzles, there's no real story to speak of. If you're here, you're here for the puzzles.
