---{ A lesson in bad puzzle design }---

I have a few simple guiding heuristics on which I judge all puzzle games: 

[1] Puzzles should be self-contained and the knowledge required to solve the puzzle should be accessible and available when the puzzle is presented. If not, it had better be obvious that the player doesn't have the solution and will have to return in a metroid-vania fashion.

[2] Deceptive tricks and illusions are for magic shows and politics, they are not fun puzzle mechanics, and they are annoying as politicians and magicians.

[3] If you introduce a mechanic, the introduction of the mechanic should be obvious enough so that the player is given a fair chance to take the information in and use it for future puzzles.

[4] The meta-structure should be mostly linear, with little confusion as to where to find the next puzzle.

When this principle is not met, I lose patience, and I stop trusting the person (or team) who designed the puzzle because they've proven to me that they are willing to waste my time by sending me on a snipe hunt when all along I was never properly equipped to succeed.

Some games I feel live up to these principles well are "Baba is You", "Portal", "Human Resource Machine", and "Outer Wilds".

The Witness failed this test when I had to start wandering around the island to find out where the introductory puzzles to a new mechanic I needed were, at this point the game became obtuse and too much to track in my head without external notes and use of screenshots. It almost entirely lost me at that point, but I resolved to rely on those tools in an effort to see this game out. What eventually had me fed up with The Witness were a few points where the context of the environment pointed to an obvious solution, that was somehow not correct. Sometimes I would be left stumped, others I would brute force a solution I arrived at was not intuitive in the slightest. Another breaking point was a puzzle-set where the solutions require the player to listen for audible queues that were invisible otherwise (not intuitive, and the game did not introduce this concept in the slightest). Yet another offense was when the key to a puzzle was hidden in a corner while another key was adjacent to the puzzle and served as a red herring to mislead the player. These little tricks are not clever, deceit and lack of intuitive interaction are lazy design practices. 

I know this is a 7 year old game but it's one I don't recommend puzzle enthusiasts come back to unless you're okay relying on a guide to make up for the game's edgy desire to be mysterious and intransigent, or if you just like wasting hours upon hours guessing and checking which area you might need to be working toward next.

Good puzzle games make use of every aspect of their elements, the BEST puzzle games use everything outside of their elements too, to the point where you start seeing everything around you as a puzzle, even in real life. If you want to be a professional computer programmer, playing through [i]The Witness[/i] is honestly a better education than a 4-year Computer Science degree. And for 0.04% of the price.

And that's just the basic line-drawing mechanic. Once you start getting into the environmental puzzles, [i]The Witness[/i] transcends itself and becomes a spiritual experience. I swear I saw the face of God multiple times while playing.

This game is many things, but a game that everyone MUST experience it is not. This is not the Holy Grail of deep, philosophical puzzle games, although I can't blame the dev for trying to create something with depth. It is very pompous, bloated, and intellectual in a way that can only describe as "unnecessary." The droning audio logs become annoying, and the constant discovery of familiar shapes go from "wow" to "ok, fine" really quickly. To be fair, the dev really put a lot of effort into the puzzles, and they CAN be difficult since the game is constantly adding new rules to them and making them more complex. But they are all still the same puzzles you solve the same way. After sinking as much time as I have into playing this, I honestly don't feel like finishing. This game went from feeling like entertainment to a mundane task along the way.

I've had The Witness for a long time, and over the years I tried several times to play the game , and every time, I hated it.
One more attempt: still don't like it, but I decided to endure a little.
It grew on me and I reached the ending (which felt pointless), including the challenge area (I got fed up at that stage).

However, I still don't recommend it:
- It's just puzzles (2D puzzles in a 3D world): I don't see a storyline.
- There are 2 grand lines of puzzles, with multiple series in each, and for each series, you are somewhat guided by puzzles with evolving complexity.
	○ Logic puzzles: these are pretty good, interesting and satisfying to solve as you learn the logic.
	○ Puzzles based on your surroundings: I won't give more details about how they work as discovery is part of the game, but these are terrible. They are annoying, frustrating, and even when you solve them, there is no satisfaction, just a "oh, so that was it" feeling.
- Unfortunately, you need to work on both. You can focus more on one type, but you still need to solve some series in the other type to access the ending, and all of the series to reach the challenge area.
- The endgame phase adds some new mechanics (same logic): some are interesting, some are super-annoying.

Overall, although there were some satisfying aspects, the experience was seriously lacking.

It's called The Witness because everyone around you will be the witness of your slow descent into madness. Very good puzzle game that makes you look at things from a different perspective!

70% of it is perfect, which is why you're so invested and it hurts so much when it starts failing you.

Most of it is clever puzzles intuitively teaching you in a wonderfully realized world. It creates new ideas and builds endlessly upon them creating new ways to think and see and always in a way that if you get stuck it's on you, and if you only take the time and contemplate eventually realization will come like revelation.

Until . . .

Until the treetops, where so many get stuck on one of the toughest new concepts because the puzzle that actually introduces it, and the one that reinforces the idea are /after/ a large puzzle that uses it. Until the bamboo when the new concept flips off anyone with any form of hearing issue AND if you don't get it right the first time you're now penalized and forced to re-do the last puzzle (sometimes in a different part of  the maze) before you can try again (because, it not as if puzzles are about working out solutions...). Until you worked out the solution but you have to dance around finding the exact angle where the game isn't angry at the two pixels of overlap it put over the board. Until an endgame where the actual puzzle parts are barely a puzzle, it's fighting the interface or flashing lights or a timed memory test and all that build up of progressive puzzles has been completely abandoned for twitchy gimmicks.

Expect to be frustrated/locked out if you:
Can't do fast paced, twitch reactions
Have ANY form of colorblindness
Have any form of hearing issues
Have a reaction to flashing lights (doesn't need to be epilepsy; I don't, but I'm still writing this with a headache)


(Also, not major, but simple navigation is made onerous by not only a lack of jump button, but a proliferation of /ankle/ high walls)

Excellent game

It's one of those games you should and shouldn't play. I find this game similar essence of the Talos principle, the only difference is that Talos gives us a narrative, a reason to continue so we can understand more, and learn more. In the Witness you have actors reading quotes from famous philosophers and a very tiny narrative that is explained only at a secret ending. 

I have played the witness a total of 3 times
-first when it came out, played for 4 hours got bored and left. 
-Second time was 3-4 years later, I wanted to play, and enjoy the game. And for a time I did, but then I resorted to guides as I found some of the puzzles just annoyingly tedious and lacking fun. Finished the game with guides. And felt... meh. 
-Third time was this week, wanted to achieve 100% in the game. I came close until I returned to the tedious and annoying puzzles. And once again I resorted to guides as I found myself hitting a spiky brick wall that leads to an even spikier brick wall. So, I finished the game again feeling meh. Didn't even 100% the game. 

I love puzzles. One of my first games was Myst so I find them incredibly enjoyable. But The Witness lacks in engaging the player whilst also not caring about the player. You can spend two-hours on a single section of puzzles and feel as if you've just clocked out of a shift from an office job. Now that's not me saying I want confetti and someone petting my shoulder and whispering "good job".  Because I don't want that. I want to feel enjoyment and purpose in solving these puzzles. Which you do not get. 

What you do get is a false purpose, once you activate one of the lasers you feel a goal has been set by the game. The mountain. The final location. But that isn't true, you can go there from the start of the game. and enter after 7 lasers. Once you enter the mountain it feels like a test that makes sure you remember every rule so far, while twisting them to make them fresh again, It doesn't succeed in that, what it does is make them even more annoying.  So that's when I pulled the guide and rushed through the puzzles, couldn't be arsed anymore. Once I got to the elevator I just felt empty and tired. If this is by design, then good job, you have bored and annoyed me in my free time. 

This may come off as only a negative review, so let's jump to the positive things.
  -The game is utterly beautiful, every part of the island feels, looks, and sounds amazing. 
-Some parts of the island are fun, like the castle, and the desert.  And that's it for me. The rest felt just either too fast or too annoying.
-Hearing Ashley Johnson whispering philosophy in my ear makes my fucking day. This game unlocked a new kink for me. 

So back to our problem, The Witness fails in being... well... a game. It feels like more of an experience than actually playing a game. Every time I go back to it I feel as if I'm experiencing something. Not necessarily something good. The game's true story is that you are a developer testing the game (Super meta). The secret ending is you coming out of the machine fully insane and obsessed with the line puzzles. And that's it. The voice actors are also devs of the game, but that's technically not canon. If you go on youtube and hear all of the audio logs. You will find them commenting about the logs and the game.  Proving they are aware of the island and you. But because the narrative was scraped. We are left with an empty story and a pointless adventure. 

And so, the essence of Talos comes here.  A game that acts more like a game than an experience, Talos gives the player a goal and a mystery to solve. And they give you answers that fit. In the Witness, you can ask all you like but you won't get an answer. 

If you only want to solve line puzzles for hours and hours. Go ahead, play this. But if you are looking for something more than line puzzles and philosophy quotes. Go and play the Talos principle.

I am not sure how to feel about this game, not sure at all. Some parts are great, other parts are absolutely atrocious. Some parts were such a joy, some parts are downright painful. One part made me want to keep playing it forever, another part literally gave me a mental breakdown (or something close to it).

I am glad I have finished this game. Not only because I have completed a great challenge, but also because I don't have to suffer through this game anymore.

This game can feel so rewarding, yet also one of the most painful experiences I have had in recent years in gaming. (Do note I said it [i]feels[/i] rewarding, you gotta have an intrinsic joy for puzzles to keep that feeling though.)

Do [b]not[/b] play this game if you do not [i]really[/i] enjoy puzzles. This game is almost only puzzles. There is a bit of philosophy (which you will be too mentally engaged/fatigued to think about), but there is no story or music or lore or reward or anything. The only reward is more puzzles. You complete puzzles so you get to complete more puzzles so you can complete more puzzles. It is like a big Sudoku book, and once you complete one you get to complete 5 more. Each book twists the formula a bit, but by the end of the last Sudoku book you won't want to play Sudoku anymore. (Maybe this game is best experienced, where you complete one puzzle a day or only play when you have nothing else going on or only complete one section a week/month/year or something. I don't know...)

If you are someone who finds puzzles to be something that pads out a game, someone who sighs gently when they get stuck at a puzzle in a story game, or only played Portal 2 for the witty dialogue and story first and the puzzles second... then do not play this game.

If you do enjoy puzzles, then go ahead and play the game. At times you should have fun, but to limit suffering allow yourself to look up hints and guides and just understand you will never 100% this game on your own.

This is not the sort of game you complete without a guide or some hints, even without going for secrets you will certainly need help.

[spoiler]The Challenge looks actually interesting at first, but probably only because I like the music. Also I [b]love[/b] the environmental puzzles. I just think it is a bit naff that there seems to be no reward for finding them all.[/spoiler]

Overall... get it on sale if you are willing to play with hints or not complete the game.

As for those wondering I completed 90-95%+ puzzles without any sort of guides or hints. However, I really threw in the towel at the end. I also threw around a lot of swear words.

[spoiler]Also I activated all the lasers, which I don't think you needed to do to get the "Endgame" ending... so yeah.[/spoiler]
I have Witnessed.

I love games where one can wander around a lushly illustrated landscape at one's leisure, solving puzzles and discovering what happened long ago. If you like Myst or Journey, this is probably right up your alley. Although the puzzles in The Witness are superficially similar, the designers have come up with so many variations and dimensions that one is never bored (sometimes frustrated, but never bored!); attention to detail and lateral thinking are rewarded. The (mostly) nonverbal nature of the game also appeals to me. The island itself is varied enough that, even with my GPU-less off-the-shelf graphics, the visuals are endlessly fascinating. I especially like how every area of the island has multiple layers; as one plays and learns more, one can revisit a place and solve the puzzles needed to delve further.

The same style of puzzle, is used over and over again, and its just not fun.  Only positive I can think of - was I refunded it.  I was originally going to liken this game to a Sudoku puzzle book, but those are actually quite enjoyable to complete.  Witness ends up feeling like a chore instead of a game.

Go Download "The Looker" instead, its a FREE parody of this game, and its actually much more enjoyable to play, and kinda funny too.

I think The Witness is a work of genius.

As often noted, it's not for everyone.  In particular:

1.  The tone deaf and colorblind.  If either of these describes you, there will be a few parts of this game that are basically impossible without a guide.

2.  Those with low IQ.  This issue shouldn't be overblown--the greatest challenges in the game have little to do with IQ and a great deal to do with stretching your mind a bit and seeing things in a different way.  Nevertheless, some aspects of the game feel a little bit like the kinds of puzzles you might see on an IQ exam.

Most importantly, though...

3.  People in a hurry.  This is the big one.  The game expects you to take a leisurely approach:  put down your copy of Marcel Proust, sip a glass of wine, stroke your chin a bit, and enjoy slowly turning around the puzzles thrown at you.  You *will* get stumped on occasion.  And if you're eager to make quick progress every time you sit down to this game, you will probably be frustrated.

*  *  *

Just as an aside...the various messages have a similar arc to them.  I'm not sure if I'm altogether on board with that arc.  Should you ever stumble across a shipwreck...[spoiler]check out that audio file, but then be sure at some point to check out [url=https://www.gutenberg.org/files/26659/26659-h/26659-h.htm#P1] the historical response to it, from William James. [/url][/spoiler]

There's not much to say about The Witness that hasn't already been said, but regardless of that, it's a brilliant puzzle game, and definitely one of the best puzzlers I've played period. It's relentlessly cohesive and precise in a way rarely seen in games. The whole thing has an air of silent confidence, as if it knows it needs nothing more than what it presents to you to hold your attention, and it absolutely held mine. It builds and layers its concepts and rules in a way that were very engaging to play through and discover. The beautiful serene environments and quiet ambiance helped facilitate a focused flow of thought from puzzle to puzzle. It kicked my ass plenty of times, but I always came back. Even while away I'd find myself ruminating on possible solutions of whatever specific puzzle I was stuck on. If you like puzzle games, good games, or even just challenges, I'd highly recommend you play The Witness. Genuinely outstanding.

One of the best puzzle games.

A true open world divided in several areas.
The puzzles are just panels on which you have to draw the correct line. They are generally hard and the solutions often come with pure observation of your surroundings and not just thinking. They are very varied and you'll never get bored of them.
No tutorial, the game makes you understand its mechanics through increasingly difficult puzzles in each zone and that's a good thing.

The visuals of the island are outstanding but as far as the story is concerned, there is none. Solving all the areas will unlock the final ones but you'll never get any context about the island, the statues or anything. There are just useless pretentious audio recordings hidden and that's all. They went for the funny true ending instead of creating a story so don't expect anything on this side.

There are also environmental puzzles. I suggest looking for them with a friend because there are lots of them, the island is rather big and they are sometimes well hidden.

Puzzles are easy, and on top of that it is incredibly slow paced. Walking around and doing tasks just feels boring and tedious due to how unnecessarily time wasting it is, overall makes it an unfun experience.

I found this game unfun. Each time I launched it, I couldn't stand it for more than 30 minutes. After a few tries, I gave it up. It's not that I couldn't solve puzzles. They just didn't feel elegant enough for me. Even when I solved them, I wasn't inspired by them. I found them dull.

The Witness is exactly the game that gives the feeling of what it is like to uncover an understanding of something. It is messy, full of clever insight, unexpected turns, deadends, and I wouldn't have it any other way. I might say that this game is best to reflect how learning works. It is one that even the very mention of an idea could count as a spoiler because of how that often hints at some kind of solution. So any description of what the game is 'like' may probe your thought and for that reason I feel like one should go in blind. But I'll give some more description, just be warned.

A puzzle game is, by definition, a game about a player faced with an interactive thing with some goal. The thing is, most puzzle games trace one level after another. You often feel like you are pounding your brain against a wall until you get it.

This leads to one major issue: a puzzle game is usually seen to test the mind. But the mind doesn't learn this way. By doing this rote style, it has one fatal, fatal flaw. When you are learning something by going over it again and again-you get more and more hard-wired to a certain way of old thinking that makes it more and more impossible to understand new things. The hard-wiring limits how you can expand off of. You can only learn when presented a variety of different, natural contexts.

The creator has a physics major and that shows-this isn't because of supreme intellect or fiendishly complicated mechanics. But because they show an understanding of how learning of deep subjects takes place, and that is by far a deeper insight of this game-learning how learning and understanding works. I have self-studied mathematics and physics for a while, preparing for college and what I noticed is the feeling of discovery here is very reminiscent of the experience
of realizing something in math. This of course is applicable to anything you learn, a point emphasized throughout.

This game therefore takes a brilliant new approach-present a series of puzzles on an island in different sections with no pretension on what they 'should' know at a certain point. At first, you will come across a bunch of symbols and not know at all what they meme, it will incite a bit of wonder-especially due to the fresh environments and puzzle types around each corner. But you'll come across some path that, by the puzzles, work you through how one works and figure out a rule if you get through them. The rule won't ever be stated but you may think to figure something out and it may be subject to change. In this way, it is a metroidvania of ideas and knowledge.

The game is largely conceptual, it doesn't necessarily have a singularly tied 'rule', although the manners of the puzzle still tend to center on core ideas. Sometimes a puzzle is a bit more cryptic and not 'by the rules' you've think you've figured out by then. The game however gradually opens up you to more possibilities revolving around this 'rule' and this itself will set you in a mindset to open up. Because of its central focus around 'ideas', what often happens is you are wandering around and something completely unrelated probes an idea to try this out. It was itself not at all in the same problem category as what you were, yet it encouraged it.

This is exactly how learning works. This game actually promotes a sense of curiosity, wonder, frustration, and insight that feels so natural with how it really should work.

Sprinkled in between all that discovery though is what feels at core a deductive puzzle game, which helps test your abilities in that in a variety of ways, but there may be points where a singular puzzle you know the rule to but can't solve on its own merit may be a bit frustrating.

The world hints at something deeper although lore wise, despite an interesting aura of crypticism and philosophical themes, I don't think it goes much. There is however a later half I haven't really finished up but... oh I don't want to spoil.

As a final note, this is one of the games that made me really think about what games could be and one where I felt like it could truly be artistic, a power I didn't see before. It is one I was smiling so much at afterwards because of just... how cool it was.

This game is not for everyone by any means. I don't mean that in some sort of "you must be a super smart" way but more in the way that you need the patience of a saint and a serious drive to find rules and patterns where there seemingly aren't any. I played this game to varying degrees of "completion" over a long period of time, and I highly recommend taking breaks so as to not burn yourself out in this regard. 

After "completing" the game 100% (as far as the community knows as of now anyways), I can say that I greatly enjoyed The Witness and an overwhelming majority of its puzzles wholeheartedly. So many of them have clever solutions that felt rewarding to discover on my own. 
I found myself getting stumped quite often, but the "aha" moments feel so deserved and satisfying (*most of the time*) that I never felt compelled to search for solutions online just to progress. 

The landscapes and aesthetics made exploring the world something to look forward to, and
the architectural design and its integration into the world makes every locale feel surreal and dream-like. :)

Oh! Also, can't believe it took so long to note this but the game is so pretentious! Wow! Uh, it doesn't change the puzzles, and I mean, I personally found it exciting to wi— *see*, if not just to see how pretentious it got. There are some genuinely very profound things you can take away from the game in my opinion, but I guess it just comes off a little silly when it seems to take itself so seriously all the time. (giggle emote) 
If you like puzzle games with wonderful mysteries and challenging, clever challenges, you'll love this game like I did. 

PS: Sometimes the speed some of these transitions/animations happens at is inexcusable consider downloading Cheat Engine or equivalent software to speed up the game with a hotkey. Unless if you enjoy the wonderful puzzle of staring with nothing to do at things you've seen already! <3 

PPS: I actually wrote this review during something unskippable with a tremendous time requirement, so maybe this is all part of the developers' plan?!?!

This is one of those games where I wish I could do more than just thumb up or down.   Do I recommend this game?  Mildly yes, but there are a LOT of asterisks on that yes.     The game is beautiful and well designed.   It is also about 3 times longer than it should be.  It drags on and on for not a lot of payoff.     

The puzzles are well thought out.... UNLESS you have any kind of disability at all:   Hearing difficulties?  You are screwed on a bunch of puzzles.  Color-blindness?  You're completely F'ed.  

On the whole I enjoyed it, so I give it a thumbs up, but it is deeply, DEEPLY flawed.

The game is EXTREMELY POLISHED. They did not cut a single corner anywhere. Everything is 100% finished and perfected, like a work of art. Whoever worked on this took great pride in their work. 

The Witness is a certifiable monkey gym for your mind. Fortunately, I do not suffer from a completionist compulsion. I imagine that I would have felt frustrated if I did. 

You can finish the game while "leaving thing undone". There's a layer to this game that is always present, and always alluring. I very much appreciate that it is there. It's what makes The Witness so great. 

Still, .. I'm not inclined to scrape the bottom of that layer to get every drop of juice out of it. I got what I needed, and am happy to know that there is more should I want it. It feels better to leave it there. I think that's what the point was. That there's something left to find, should I really want to search more.

I hope you can play the game without feeling like you have to find everything. The game does not want you to feel that way

I think it's my favorite puzzle game.  Watching those philosophical videos that play after completing the puzzles in the theater room is perhaps the most mystifying experience of my life.  It makes puzzle-solving aspects of almost every other game that I've ever played seem really juvenile and pointless.  The puzzles here can get really hard too.  I think the only reason I even solved some of these puzzles is b/c I was really determined, due solely to how it made me feel like it could answer cosmological questions if I finished it - that's how powerful those videos are.  I needed to solve them all.  There are clues all over the island like keys, and when you enter them correctly onto a panel in front of a screen underground, videos play.  You can even interact with some of them in unique, mind-bending ways.  It made me feel like I was on shrooms at times.  That being said, if I encountered some of these puzzles in the middle of another game I might have just said, "screw it, I can't do it" b/c some are really that hard.  Some might see that as a drawback.  The only drawback I see is that some puzzles truly are terrible and some are way too easy, but these could mostly be overlooked without too much difficulty.

Don't get the wrong idea.  It isn't going to convert any nihilists into spiritual philosophers, it simply might give you the hope or belief that it might, eventually, if only you solve more puzzles.  Of course it never does, but this game can't be blamed for the pointlessness and simplicity of existence.  It also can't be blamed for its lack of answers that just don't exist.  The pursuit of those answers though, and the struggle through these puzzles, is a great experience on its own, if you don't mind being disappointed by the ending.  But that's life as well, as much as you might like to deny.

The Witness is simultaneously impressive, clever, tedious & terrible. The problem is that you get an  uneven experience when you combine all those things together. There are times when the game pleasantly hums along, but other times when it drags for long periods.

You start out in a somewhat restricted area, but once you pass this area, you're set loose on a semi-large open world island. You will find & solve puzzle after puzzle after puzzle. These are all line/maze puzzles (so you better enjoy those, as there are around 650 in the game). The island has various areas often containing series of puzzles unique to that area as well as some shared ones. The final puzzle in an area will open a yellow box which shoots a laser to the top of a mountain. You need to activate at least 7 of the 11 lasers on the island to get to the end game area, where you'll then proceed to hit some of the more annoying puzzles in the game.

To start with the list of issues is that the game implies that there is some grand mystery as to what is going on here. There isn't. In fact, there's no plot/story. The most you'll find are tape recorders containing pretentious nonsense. This ends with you being sent back to where you started and the puzzles all being reset. The secret ending is some guy wakes up in reality, falls over a bunch, touches some things and then taps some stuff with a spoon. Amazing!

There is no hand holding for the puzzles in this. The starting puzzles are tracing a line through the maze to the end. After this, you'll find puzzles with black & white dots, colored dots, small black hexagons, tetris shapes, sunburst symbols, etc. Some areas have short tutorial segments that teach you the basic rules for one of the rule sets. You will run into puzzles you're not currently able to solve, forcing you to go elsewhere. Most of this is fine except for the fact that the island takes a bit to get around and there is no map (except on the boat which functions as a sort of quicktravel system, except it's slower than running to your destination). The only real use for the boat is to get to one island which is separated from the main island.

The game has several issues with the areas and puzzles. It's difficult to talk about them as doing so provides minor spoilers. While you're often shown basic rules for puzzles, many of them have more advanced rules, which are completely reliant on you to figure out. Some of these require a bit of a stretch on your part. Some puzzles are based on visuals/sounds and even these will often require you to make a leap. If you fail some puzzles, the screen for that puzzle will turn off, forcing you to go back to a previous puzzle and re-solve it to get the screen to turn back on. These are usually ones based on you needing to notice something. The desert area is entirely based on luck as to whether you'll figure out how to solve the puzzles in that area. [spoiler]The solution for the puzzles only appear if you stand in certain spots, causing the sun to hit the screen in a way that it shows you how to draw the answer.[/spoiler] There was one area in the game (the jungle) where I was unable to start solving the puzzles because of stuff like this.

The worst puzzles in the game by far are the ones involving the tetris shapes, of which there are many. These don't start off too bad in the area you learn them, but you'll find plenty of puzzles which contain 3, 4, 5+ of these shapes on them. These aren't so much difficult as they're time consuming, requiring you to run through pretty much every possible permutation until you happen to stumble across the right one.

The environment also contains puzzles. Fortunately, these are all optional. If something in the environment looks like a circle (or can be combined/viewed to make it look like a circle), odds are pretty good it's a puzzle of some sort. The swamp area can be very annoying as it contains moving platforms which take a good 30+ seconds to very slowly move back and forth so you can get from one side to the other.

The Witness is an alright but uneven game. Sometimes you're going through puzzles at a good pace, other times you're stuck on one for a long while or have to go to some other area because you can't figure it out. Some puzzles make you feel smart when you figure out whatever the rule is or notice whatever it is you needed to notice. Other puzzles you'll know the rules, but are time consuming annoyances requiring you to try to fit things together in a ton of possible ways until you happen to find the one that actually works. Ultimately, the Witness goes on for far too long for what it is. The number of puzzles could've been cut in half and the game would've been far better off for it. It would've also helped to cut the time consuming brute force 4+ tetris piece puzzles.

Honestly it's hard to say whether I'd really recommend this game or not. I got to the end with only very slight help on a couple puzzles, and there are a TON of puzzles in this game that can get pretty ridiculous at times. Probably too many iterations on each with too few changes.

The game also tells you absolutely nothing. You must work out every little rule on your own and often will come to wrong conclusions. It's really bad at directing you in any way about that and you can waste a loooong time going down the wrong rabbit hole of a theory.

Ultimately, although there are some very cleverly designed puzzles, more often than not you feel relieved to be done with a puzzle rather than satisfied by solving it and it can be a very frustrating experience that the world design doesn't help by making it a sluggish pain to get around. That said, I believe that all is by design and although I don't think it was a good choice, if you are in the mood for a devious puzzle game with a slow pace and don't want your hand held in the slightest, this may be the right game for you. 

I cautiously recommend it in that case.

The first time I played through this game, I did not enjoy it and I gave up long before I reached the end. However, I revisited this game recently and despite expecting to be disappointed again, I actually found myself having a very fun time with this game. There are some very serious flaws with this game though and I think some of these flaws help explain my vastly different experiences with this game.

One of the largest flaws in this game for me was the story, or the lack thereof. There was so little narrative in this game that for most of my playthrough I honestly thought there wasn't supposed to be one, despite what the store page seems to suggest. What little story does exist is all locked behind hidden content near the end of the game and it's fairly brief and not well communicated, so even when I did finally encounter it, I found it pretty underwhelming and disappointing. There are also random thoughts from various philosophical thinkers hidden around the map to listen to as well, which don't provide any narrative, but do provide some interesting perspectives to consider, although I did sometimes find them hard to follow, especially while trying to explore or solve puzzles at the same time, and those that don't enjoy philosophy likely won't get much out of them.

The very creative puzzles that exist throughout the island of The Witness are where this game really shines. The general concept is fairly simple, and involves tracing a line through a maze from a start point to an end point, but the game quickly begins introducing a plethora of unique and interesting additional mechanics and rules, many of them making creative use of the environment to help you solve them. For the most part the game does pretty well at introducing new concepts to you with puzzles that gradually increase in difficulty in different areas, and the game does encourage you to revisit puzzles later if you don't have all the information you need to solve one. There were a few puzzles that were not communicated well or had unintuitive rules that were easy to forget, there's a few that are insanely slow or tedious to solve, and I also didn't enjoy some of the puzzles near the end of the game that relied on some annoying visual tricks that just made them really hard to look at (epilepsy warning for some of those puzzles as well). Thankfully those puzzles were by far the minority.

In addition to the regular puzzle panels that you find everywhere, there are hidden [spoiler]environmental puzzles[/spoiler] that are cleverly hidden throughout the island. These puzzles were my favourite puzzles to solve and I really enjoyed hunting for them and trying to figure out how to solve them. However, this brings me back to my first playthrough that I really didn't enjoy, as I never discovered these puzzles during that playthrough, and I think that highlights another major problem with this game. The open world nature of this game means you can easily miss things and end up missing crucial information on how to solve puzzles or even that some puzzles exist, leading to frustration or missing large parts of the game entirely. I think I just ended up doing things in a different order during my first playthrough and that resulted in me having a much worse experience. I think this game could have used more guidance to instruct players on where to go, or at least to indicate where good places to start are, as the freedom the game offers can definitely result in a worse experience overall.

The visuals in this game a very good. The island looks great and the sound design is very good as well. There's also many neat tricks of perspective hidden throughout the island, where looking at something from a certain angle reveals something neat you wouldn't have otherwise seen, which were pretty cool. The game also ran well and I didn't encounter any major issues during my playthroughs.

[b]TL;DR[/b] This is a fun puzzle game with a simple concept that is used in a large number of interesting and creative ways and a visually and auditorily stunning world to solve them in. Despite some puzzles that were poorly explained, tedious, or visually nauseating, a lack of direction which can sometimes lead to frustration, and an almost complete lack of narrative, I still enjoyed this game (the second time at least). This game definitely isn't for everyone, but if you like first-person puzzle games, I'd still recommend giving this game a try if you can get it on sale, as I think it gets more right than it gets wrong.

The main meat of the witness isn't the puzzles themselves, but figuring out the rules to the puzzles. However, it is FAR too easy to develop misconceptions of the rules, or to learn rules out of sequence in a way that allows you to accidentally complete puzzles and fulfil rules that you are unaware of until you hit a wall that just makes no sense. Additionally, some puzzles require you to interpret things in a way that it is extremely rare to do. The best moments that game has is the environmental puzzles, which in my opinion are absolute genius. The colour puzzle in the crate in the village  (Which [i]the[/i] witness endgame located directly next to the start of the game) opened my eyes as to how the colour puzzles actually worked.
It also doesn't help that The Witness is one of the most pretentious games I have ever played, even including a half hour philosophy lecture required to 100% the game.

Overall, I'd say it's a very smart game, but I just didn't find it fun.

The level design is awesome, and the island is beautiful.  Time spent exploring was great.  The sound in some areas, like the shipwreck, is really good.  Even the puzzle concepts for unlocking and traversing the world were cool, just not the puzzles themselves.  

The "story"...  I mean this game doesn't need a story, and I've played a ton of walking simulators and indie concept games so I get it, but wow is this one pretentious.  Seemingly random intellectual and philosophical quotes that remind me of Civ when you unlock a tech or build a world wonder, except with zero context.  There are some secret videos available that are sort of interesting, but they range from clips of foreign films to narrated stories to portions of 70's science specials and appear to have absolutely nothing to do with anything.  I think the devs just tried way too hard to be profound.

Best, most difficult, and most innovative puzzle game I've ever played. Better than Myst, Riven, Exile, Revelation, Obduction, Quern, the Talos Principle, you name it. Interacting with the puzzles is so simple, and although every puzzle is the same maze-like grid, the dozens of variations make sure that the puzzles never feel stale. Plus, the open world means that if you get sick of a particular type of puzzle, you're not stuck forever until you do it; you can just move onto something else.

The game sets you free in a huge, beautiful open world full of puzzles and interesting locations. There are no explicit tutorials, but every new variation of the mazes has its own "training zone" which starts you off with some easy puzzles to let you learn what the new symbols/colors mean. It does require some guess and check, but personally I love this method of teaching. Very hands-off, very indirect, but I think extremely effective. Once you've learned the rules, the puzzles are yours to do however you choose. There is no order in which you have to visit the different locations, but in most locations the puzzles have to be done in a specific order. Again though, variation and clever tricks keep the puzzles feeling fresh even if they use the same rules.

The puzzles also grow ever more intertwined with the environment as you progress to more difficult areas. In some areas solving puzzles moves machinery, in some you physically have to walk the maze to solve it, in some you have to use shadows or light or sound, etc. Trust me, making the connection between what's happening around you and the solution to the puzzle you're looking at never stops being satisfying. The amount of creativity required to take the simple concept of a maze and turn it into dozens of unique ideas and hundreds of unique puzzles is astounding. Hence the "best, most difficult, and most innovative puzzle game I've ever played."

However, if you're looking for story there's really nothing here. The environment is rife with little details and trying to piece together the story through sheer exploration is fun, but there's really nothing cohesive beyond that. Worst of all there are audio recording scattered throughout the environment that play random quotes from historical figures which cannot be stopped once they are started, and some of which are painfully long. If you're looking for an engaging story with exposition, climax, and resolution, you won't find it here. And for the love of god do NOT touch the audio recordings; they're just distracting.

That being said, there is a secret ending (I'm guessing, based on the hidden achievement and the fact that I finished the game without doing all of the puzzles) which might shed more light on the story. If I ever get the secret ending I'll update this review, but the game appears to have completely reset once I finished it, so that might not happen.

In short, beautiful, challenging, innovative, but sparse of story. If you want to test yourself against some of the most difficult and innovative puzzles you've ever encountered surrounded by colorful scenery, this is a must-play. If you want to uncover the mystery of a story-rich world with some low-stakes brain-teasers, maybe try a different game. 9/10

The Witness is certainly a strikingly beautiful game, but among the stunningly colourful artistic backdrop lies what is quite an underwhelming and rather frustrating puzzle experience that fails to intrigue or captivate. 

You wake up alone on an island where there is no music or other people, yet the landscape is littered with these maze-like panel puzzles. Your only option is to solve therm and see what unfolds. That's pretty much it really.

The Puzzles themselves are either ridiculously easy, incredibly frustrating or downright illogical. There isn't much satisfaction to be had either and moving onto the next batch doesn't really bring much excitement. 

This game lacks the intrigue of The Outer Wilds, the variety of The Talos Principle and the brilliance of Portal. Take away the island all all you've got is a load of puzzles you'd likely see in these indie games that go for £1.49.

The Witness is the kind of game whose point is not easy to explain or understand. I've played it through a few times and I still don't understand quite what the point is- You do all of these hundreds of line puzzles and [Spoilers] you get in an elevator and watch all of it undo itself.
I think The Witness is fantastic- not just because of its puzzles but because it really is a nice-looking game- but the only problem is that you can only really get into it if you're willing to play for hours and hours, not all in one sitting, but spread out- If you just can't solve something the best course of action is to spend a half hour or so doing something else. So you spend ten minutes of productivity solving puzzles, then twenty minutes of puzzling over one grid that seems to have NO ANSWER, then you give up and take a break for a while, and then you come back 30 minutes later and you solve it in a quarter of a second, and then you spend five minutes wondering how you didn't think of that before. So if you don't happen to be in the correct puzzle-solving, open-thinking mindset, you won't be able to make much progress.
The Witness is just a game that is really unusual. There are other puzzle games, but I haven't yet seen one puzzle game that takes a single puzzle to such an extent as The Witness does.
So as long as you're okay with spending forty dollars on it, and as long as you're prepared to take a lot of rests and be very open-minded and calm, go ahead.
